reviews.text: Just like montu and cheetah awsome!!!!!!!!

This is a damn ride. 

Ironically the best ride in Busch gardens from a technical perspective is also one of the oldest, as Kumba was built in 1993. It's 144ft tall with a top speed of 60mph and features a diving loops, a zero G roll, a cobra roll, and two interlocking loops. And as if that wasn't awesome enough, another thing this great oldie but goodie has going for it is that it was built...by B&M, today's number one coaster maker in the world

b&M is known for making coaster that are smooth as silk and that move like water. They flow naturally, heavily and they feel like a dream, even when they are as fierce as Kumba, trying its very best to tear your senses out of your body. 

This is, 20 years later, still, in my opinion the best full on sensory overload at Busch Gardens. 

5 out of 5 stars for Kumba

This roller coaster is a whirlwind of action packed fun.  A ton of twists and turns that will make you forget which way is up! If you consider yourself a roller coaster aficionado, then give this one a try.

Loved this coaster. Lots of speed, twists, turns, loops. Also liked that my feet weren't dangling - sitting firmly on the floor of the car.  I did feel a bit like my brains were knocked around in my skull when all done - I guess everything it should be!

Kumba is showing her age, but every time I walk across the entry bridge and the coaster goes whirling around me - I remember their ad slogan for so long - "Feel the Roar".  LOVE love love this coaster and one of my happiest memories of high school was coming to BG with my physics class.  Kumba was still pretty new and BG provided us all sort of data to allow students to take time measurements and calculate speeds, car weights, etc.  We also had some awesome "hands on" activities asking us to try and lift our feet, etc. at various points during the ride and then explain the physical forces at work.  I still think Kumba has one of the best track designs/layouts of any coaster and the "thrills" are perfectly paced to really make you feel it!

An oldie but a goodie, Kumba was once known for having one of the largest inversion loops in the country. It's pretty cool to watch, as it roars around you on the entrance bridge. I advise against the back for those who get nauseous. This coaster has lots and lots of loops that make it super fun. It's also amazing in the dark, as it adds to the fun disorientation.

Super fun roller coaster! 

Surprising and excited! 

I recommend the front row at least once. 

It was a tiny bit rough on my head compared to other rides, but I had quick queue and rode it twice and loved it!

We started our evening on this coaster at HowlOScream. The line was short and we had a thrilling ride. It was fun and got our adrenaline pumped up for the rest of the night. A good place to start and worm your self up a bit because it is a bit shorter ride than some of the others.

The first time I rode this coaster, it made me sick as a dog. I got off the coaster and tried to act like a He-Man in front of the kiddies who seemed to have had not issue with the ride, while all the while I wanted to find a place to puke and curl up in a ball.

The second time I rode this, I enjoyed every moment of the ride and felt fine afterwards, so I am not sure what the difference was.
This ride has a large number of inversions and corkscrews and is fast. It is a little bumpy for a steel coaster but I really enjoyed it.

Solid coaster. Not the smoothest of the looping coasters at Busch Gardens, but a fun time! It had some large, sweeping loops, fun twists and good speed! Busch Gardens has some newer coaster, which I end up ranking higher on my list of faves but I'd still make time to ride this coaster each trip!

This ride was not for me.  It is not a smooth ride so you will bang your head throughout.  It was three of us and everyone felt dizzy afterward.  This one got me a little sick actually.  So if you are a kind of person who gets motion sickness on some rides, Kumba is not for you.  If you like lots of loops, twists and G-force, and have very strong balance towards crazy motions, then you will definitely enjoy this roller coaster.

Kumba is a classic, award-winning roller coaster that has yet to wear out its welcome at Busch Gardens. It's one of the older park attractions yet stands the test of time with its smooth design, intensity, and various roll styles. I always aim for the front half of the train because the back can be a rough ride.

This is a great coaster and one of my favorites at Busch Gardens. The ride is very thrilling as it has several loops and it goes very fast. My only issue with Kumba is that the large shoulder harness that you pull over your body rests too high up. My head comes right between it so that my ears bang against the harness at every sharp turn. This can lead to a bit of a headache after the ride.

Zumba is a must while visiting the park. We waited in line for maybe 10 minutes and then helped ourselves to a nice seat. Comfortable and smooth ride. 

We would ride it more than once if we had time.

Omg Kumba. This review is 4 stars if you ride it once, but I rode it three times today and I have to say that it's rough. It's an incredible ride, but you can feel every bump and it gave me a crazy headache. 

It's still awesome as heck though. 

I think it's what, seven inversions, nearly four minutes of ride time, and a great drop at the beginning. This is a great ride! To think that last month I stood on the bridge wishing I had the guts to ride this guy. I will be riding Kumba often this coaster season.

Everything you expect from a roller coaster, is here. We rode it after Sheikra, so that's probably why I didn't give this 4 stars. But definitely worth the ride. Ride if if you love coasters. You won't be disappointed!  But try to ride it first!

Good thrilling ride with all the hoops and turns and speed, but that harness can be hard on the ears, physically. Your head rests between the thick harness and all the vibrations and turns makes your head bounce between these causing pain. I try putting my hands on my head to steady and minimize the bounce. That works better.

Kumba is the Old Man of the roller coasters at Busch Gardens, since this steel roller coaster was first opened in 1993. At the time this was the tallest, fastest and longest roller coaster in Florida, but of course those records have since been bestowed upon other coasters long after Kumba was up and running.

Even though this is a steel roller coaster with a "smooth" track, I still find this ride to be jarring, and it does have a bad habit of making people nauseous. I've watched people with motion sickness totally lose the contents of their stomach on this ride, and the BG crew seems to be constantly cleaning up "biological spills" after Barfing Bertha crawls off this ride on her hands and knees.

The name Kumba supposedly derives from the translation of the word "Roar" in an African dialect, but I prefer to think that it's more closely derived from the word "Barf"..... (see above).

Kumba begins with a right-hand, 90-degree turn out of the station which leads into a 143-foot-tall chain lift hill. From there you drop off to the left and then launch into a vertical loop around the lift hill. You'll go through a total of 7 inversions including interlocking corkscrews and a zero gravity roll that leaves many people's stomachs wayyyyyyyyy behind. The coaster zips along at 60 mph for just shy of three minutes, and you'll pull 3.8 G's on this ride.

It's not my favorite ride in the park, as the coaster tends to slam you back and forth against your padded headrest, and the loops and twist can be very disorienting and bang you around in your seat. Try this ride at night for a very different experience!

Kumba is one fierce mf. I didn't know B and M could make a coaster with such balls! I rode it 3 times in a row. (It was basically a walk-on, like all the coasters at Busch Gardens on the day we went.) The first time I came off pretty dizzy, which doesn't usually happen to me on coasters, even those with 7 inversions. I seemed to have acquired a tolerance after that, as I didn't get nearly the case of the head spins on my next 2 trips. The third time my father joined me, a cause of some concern for me and a lot for my mother. I recommended to him holding his head slightly forward to avoid headbanging. He held it way forward with his eyes closed the whole ride! He made it through all right, though he complained of the same dizziness I experienced. 
   The third loop on Kumba is a doozy. All in all I loved Kumba, though it rides a bit too rough for my taste, just enough to keep it out of 5 star range. It's the most intense and the roughest Bolliger and Mabillard coaster I've ever ridden, easily. I guess it's like an early album from some indie rock band that sold out to do nice, clean, polished commercial work. Rough around the edges, but rocking out with exurberance.

This is the perfect coaster for me because it's high speed with lots of loops and no steep drops. It's my second favorite in the park, after Cheetah Hunt. Lots of sudden twists and turns and at one point it twists so low to the ground you feel like you could touch the grass. Worth waiting in line.

At one point this was my favorite roller coaster at Busch Gardens and it is still good but not as smooth as it once was, but it still has a lot of great elements and is a lot of fun.  I would recommend riding in the front and make sure you keep you head back or you may bang your ears/head against the shoulder restraint.  At one point this was the longest coaster on the East Coast, not sure if it still is..

Threading the needle of a loop before you take it is one way to start a rollercoaster:)

This coaster is powerful and full of loops and twists that are sure to get your blood pumping.  I say powerful because the car itself feels heavy and you feel the pull towards the earth with every drop.

Being at the northern point of the park, you can often ride this with very little wait.

It was 1995 - I was in 5th grade and we took a school field trip to Busch Gardens for an overnight trip. There were a couple of firsts on this trip...some of which I would like to share.

1) This was the first time I heard Bone Thugz & Harmony's hit song Crossroads. My buddy AJ had a discman CD player (don't try to age me) with him and he let me take a listen. Became one of my favorite songs.

2) This was the first overnight school field trip that I ever took - and the only one that didn't include me and my buddies plotting how to sneak in booze (it was a simpler time in elementary school - though high school was a lot more fun haha). 

3) This was the first time I ever rode Kumba. And the second, third, fourth and possibly fifth - if memory serves me correctly.

Kumba will always hold a special place in my heart. Even riding it in recent years I get flashbacks to this field trip and while it's often overlooked by the brand new, shiny rides that have been added since 1995 - it still holds it's own!

It is nearly 3 minutes long - has 7 inversions - top speed of 60 MPH and the color combination of the track is one of the best you will see. That aqua and yellow (with some red) is iconic at this point.

A quick search turns up that even though it's pretty old as far as coasters go - it's still consistently ranked in the Top 50 (most recently #33) on roller coaster rankings. You've done well old friend. I hope they never decommission you - cause if they do...I guess I'll meet you at the crossroads..............

This should be my favorite ride at Busch Gardens. Great first drop. And it just flips you over and over in loops, corkscrews, I think a batwing. So much fun. The downside is this is not a smooth ride. Bangs you up a bit. Wish they could somehow make it a bit less rough.

We're here at Busch Gardens Tampa reviewing one of the most legendary and iconic coasters ever built. You know, THAT coaster that everyone raves about with the two corkscrews at the end? Yeah! That's Kumba. And this coaster is really freaking good. Plus, it's the first large scale B&M ever built! So this a very historic ride, as well as it, paved the way for many other outstanding B&M loopers such as Riddler's Revenge, Montu, and Hulk! So let's review this coaster.

We get in our old-school B&M sitdown trains and pull down the lap bar. We then head up the lift hill which not only gives us some great views of the park, but we also get to go through the first loop! So that's pretty sweet. We then head down the first drop which gives us some great speed. We then hit the vertical loop. And if you've ridden Riddler's Revenge, it's pretty much the same inversion except your sitting and not standing (which is why I slightly prefer Riddler's loop to this as Stand-Up Hangtime is just so awesome). We then hit a dive loop which is going so fast that you don't even have a moment to process it. We then hit the best part of the ride, the heartline spin. Now, if you're a coaster enthusiast, you've probably seen people RAVE about this element like it's the greatest thing ever. And it's an outstanding element, don't get me wrong. It's very powerful indeed and is so good that you just fly through it. However, I do actually prefer the heartline roll on Hulk (as that one LAUNCHES you into the thing) and Montu (which tries to kill you with forces). So in a way, I actually think this element is somewhat overhyped. Regardless of that though, the heartline spin is still pretty crazy. Easily a top 3 heartline spin. Just not the absolute best element ever like some people rave. We then hit the cobra roll which is SUPER intense, easily my 2nd favorite cobra roll. It's funny though because Scream and Kraken have similar cobra rolls, yet their cobra rolls are trash. Did B&M just forget how to make cobra rolls good after they made this and Hulk?

We then hit the MCBR which surprisingly doesn't take away too much of our speed. But unfortunately, we hit my absolute least favorite part of the ride, the corkscrews. While these weren't forceless, I did bang my head on them on 2 of my rides. And yeah, it hurt. It hurt a lot. I actually got a migraine from this, and I'm willing to call this the most painful B&M that I've ridden. Now, Kumba is almost 30 years old so I can forgive it for being rough, but it's still shocking that Kumba is rough yet Montu is smooth as glass. And it isn't just these elements, there is a rattle on a good chunk of the ride's transitions as well. But anyways, after the corkscrews, we then hit a small hill which actually gives a little pop of airtime before hitting the final helix of the ride. And this part is GOOD. Like good lord, this section is just so freaking fast. We're just tearing through it. After that amazing element, we then hit the brake run.

I've said this to my friends, but I am being genuine. Kumba is so close to being a perfect ride. If BGT can put some TLC into it or re-track it, this could be my favorite or 2nd favorite coaster of all time. Despite that, Kumba is still pretty outstanding. While it's not my absolute favorite B&M or my favorite ride in the park, it's pretty darn close to it as it still ranks among the best coasters I've ever ridden. Seriously, it's up there with rides like Hagrid's, Incredible Hulk, X2, GhostRider Twisted Colossus, and Montu in the same park which is also some of the best coasters I've ridden. Between this Montu and soon to be Iron Gwazi, BGT really does have an outstanding coaster lineup. I highly recommend riding Kumba! You will not be disappointed (unless you get a migraine)

Final Score: 98/100

Opened: April 20, 1993

Manufacturer: B&M

Last Ridden: January 12, 2020

5th Best Rollercoaster That I have Ridden

Here we go folks, number four on my list of favorite rides here at Busch Gardens is Kumba! This is what I would consider the perfect "normal" roller coaster. No gimmicks, just a fun, fast steel coaster with a smooth ride and tons of excitement. At 143ft tall with a top speed of 60mph, it sits in a perfect sweet spot of exciting enough for the coaster addicts, but not so scary that the family would shy away from riding. There are several inversions throughout, but most are big sweeping corkscrews, with only one true loop. The way every turn goes into the next is so well designed and every single motion is smooth as glass. I didn't feel uncomfortably shaken at all during my ride, something certain big coasters can do. I didn't believe it when i looked it up but this is a 25 year old coaster! I does not show its age at all. I had never been to this park before so I kind of assumed it was a new addition. Kumba is hidden over in the Congo area of the park, but its worth a little exploration as it is a must ride on your visit.

This is the first ride I rode on arrival to the park. As my friends said it was one of the best in the park. We waited in line about 15 minuets to get on the ride. I thought the ride was short but the climb is nice and the loops are fun and fast. I will ride this ride again but I would save it for last.

Falcon's Fury is a major rush and is one my favorite rides at Busch Gardens! This ride is not for the faint of heart as you ascend 335 feet above the park. 

You want to close your eyes, but don't do it. The view is breathtaking. 

For those who close their eyes, good luck because just when you think you are just going to drop straight down...the ride swings you into a ninety degree angle. You almost have no choice but to look down!

Then finally, when you think you have gotten used to the ninety degree angle you will be dropped at 60 miles per hour. 

Total exhilaration. Totally worth it.

Super fun! Lifts you way up to enjoy a view of downtown TAMPA. Then it holds you, lifts your feet backwards and you are looking at the ground. It then drops you and you plummet to your..... safe landing. Very fund ride.

My favorite ride at Bush Gardens.
I do not scare very easy but this ride managed to do just that and it was sure a thrill!
For those with a scare of heights, you would be well advised to stay away, as the view up the top is spectacular but then that seat rotates and forces you to look straight down and it is sure unnerving look at all those little people down there!
The drop is pure adrenaline inducing and the only thing I have felt that was more exciting than that was skydiving and for some reason, this was more scary than that!

Rode this for the first time yesterday. It was super fun! I especially liked the view at the top and the interesting mix of rushing colors as you plummet towards the ground from the paint job on the coaster. I do wish that it lasted longer or maybe you could do two drops, a short one and then a longer one. Nice job, Busch Gardens!

I DID NOT KNOW until I got to the top of the tower that for the duration of the fall you are FACING STRAIGHT DOWN - staring at the concrete below. What a thrill. 

Amazing ride, felt safe, recommend quick queue. 

Do it!!! Seriously, you won't regret it!

SCARIEST RIDE IN MY ENTIRE LIFE!!!!! If you're a dare devil then search no more, this ride will blow your mind. I wasn't expecting what this ride consisted of until I was dangling on my chair 335 feet in the air. The shocking part of this ride is that when you reach the top, all the seats lean forward until your body is parallel to the ground ready to drop face first. Terrifying experience, but fun/wild ride for those who are into that.

Fun. High. 

OOOOOOOOooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooOOOOOOOOhhhhh. 

The ride up is pretty scary. Up so high.. Hello Vertigo!!!  

What a view. 

And then you are shifted outwards so you face straight down while just hanging there until... 

Free Falling...... 

Super!!! Stupid fun. :) 

The anticipation going up is a real thrill. And lookin up at the top of the tower is fun. We were laughing cuz the whole thing is a little nuts. :)
One of the best rides I've ever been on in awhile, although I was scared at first. We ended up riding about 8 times, until the rain started!!

One of a kind ride! 90% of this ride is the suspense of waiting and going up. Going up almost 300 feet slowly.. If you look down it freaks you out. Then, you get to the top and your seats rotates making you face the floor. That drop is one of a kind. Free falling a couple hundred feet is a great way to spend your Sunday! Just make sure you don't eat before riding!

The 5 stars only apply to this ride when it's running and I am actually on it. Lol! I say that because it is often closed. And unless you have the fast pass, you will be in line for a long time. All that being said...THIS RIDE IS AWESOME! It is one of the most refreshing rushes I've experienced on a non roller coaster ride. It is very smooth too, so don't worry about it jarring your body.

Awesome. The only ride at Busch Gardens I felt any apprehension about getting on, probably since it's the only thing they have that's bigger and badder than the Cedar Point equivalent. I'm glad the wait was so short so I didn't have too much time to mull it over. 
   The view is great and being faced down really adds a new element to the drop tower experience. Falcon's Fury is intense! It's a 5 star attraction for sure. My one quibble would be that Power Tower, though much shorter, seems to drop you faster. That might just be me being a Cedar Point fanboy though. I really wish I had ridden this more than once, but with the early 5pm closing and it's location smack dab in the middle of this mammoth park it just wasn't doable for one last plunge.

Today was my first on several thrill rides. I have never had the urge to ride Falcon's Fury, but peer pressure got the best of me today, so on we went. 

We came right as the park was opening, so there was ZERO wait times, which I instantly regretted on this ride because I use the wait times to hype myself up. No no! Not this time! 

Once you're strapped in you're lifted up, and that 
seems like it takes forever. Then the seat tilts you till you're facing the ground and as you guessed. Drops you. I'm not a fan of drops. Today was my day for drops apparently. It wasn't terrible but it also was three seconds that I never want to experience again. This was one ride that I was excited to get off of!

Amazing attraction. Definitely not for the faint of heart. This ride is intense. The suspense builds as you wait in line. Once you're securely in, you ascend up, up, and further up until all of a sudden the seats shift and you're parallel with the ground. Your weight shifts and your entire body leaves the back of your seat and you are pushed forward, pressing up against the restraint that's keeping you from falling to the earth. Then, without knowing when it will happen, you rapidly descend and when you're almost to the bottom,  the ride swings you out in a swooping motion so that you're back to a seated position. Definitely a must!
This ride is ok but the drop is just so underwhelming and if you are scared of heights there is no worry because there are no scary parts on the ride
Its a fun quick ride, not my style since Im more of a coaster guy, but its worth it if the line is quick.  I wouldnt wait 30-60+ minutes to ride.

Soooo cool!

Many theme parks have a variation of a drop tower. You know the drill, it Bri gs you up, up up and then after a few moments of anticipation you drop to the ground. Always a good time. 

Falcon's Fury takes this model and kicks it up a notch! once you reach tha top, your seats tilt out so you go from a an upright, seated position to facing the ground! This is by no means a slight tilt, you are facing the ground ataight on! I don't know how tall this tower is, but it's billed as the tallest in Florida, so you are HIGH! After a few seconds of facing the ground you are whooshing down the tower, where, at the last minute, you are swooped back into an upright position. 

What an awesome way to take a theme park staple and make it unique and exciting! Loved it!

I have only been on Falcon's Fury once, but it is an experience I will never forget. When the ride brings you to the top of the tower before the drop and has you staring straight at the ground beneath you with your body facing downward - it's a huge rush. I remember my palms sweating like crazy and being literally scared to death. When the ride shoots you downwards you feel like it really is the end and then it catches you just in time before you can hit the ground.

Falcon's Fury is definitely a rush - one I will only do once, but can still recommend :)

Falcon's Fury is Busch Gardens newest attraction for those of us who love the rush of adrenaline much more than we love good old-fashioned common sense. The ride is officially described as a free-standing Sky Jump drop tower attraction which lifts you and 31 of your dearest friends to a height of 335 feet above the park, giving you a spectacular view of Tampa (assuming that you keep your eyes open).

I had the chance to ride Falcon's Fury during it's soft opening, and enjoyed it so much that I got right back in line to ride it a second time that afternoon. This time, it was a night, during our Yelp-O-Scream event, and it was a whole different experience.

You're seated 8 riders to a side, in a square lift mechanism that slowly hikes you up and up and up as you climb to a height of 335 feet. On cue your seat tips forward, till you are facing straight down, and it feels like only the horse collar is holding you in place. By now the screaming has reached a feverous pitch, and then there is that agonizing wait before "the drop".

You hear the click as the electric brakes are unlocked, and suddenly you are free-falling towards earth at about 60 mph. You're pulling 3.5 G's for a 310 foot free-fall before your seat tips back up to upright, and you are slowly lowered back the remaining 25 feet to the ground. The entire ride lasts about 2 minutes, and several people kept up an ear-splitting shriek of terror for the entire time.

Once you're back on the ground you're usually laughing hysterically while gasping for breath, and then running back around to get in line for a second time.

During the day, the views of Tampa are spectacular and the rush of the ground coming up to meet your face is absolutely terrifying the first time that you ride this attraction. At night, you're able to focus on the lights of the park and the City of Tampa, and the crazy blend of colors and lights on the drop tower really enhances the sensation of falling.

I've now ridden Falcon's Fury four times -- twice during the day, and twice at night. I really love this attraction, and just need to find more screwballs like me who enjoy these types of rides. 

Well done Busch Gardens!!!!

I LOVE THIS RIDE. I was super excited to try this ride out on my first visit back to Busch Gardens after several years. Unfortunately for me, both of my brothers and my mother were too afraid to give it a go. I had to wait until my second visit back with my boyfriend. I wasn't scared of going on Falcon's Fury... well not that scared anyway, but Sam was terrified. I basically forced him to go on it as he said he wasn't ready yet (he wanted to ride Sheikra first and then work his way up to Falcon's Fury). I didn't feel like walking across the park to Sheikra so I basically pushed him into the line at Falcon's Fury.

The wait to get on the ride is probably the scariest part. You see rider after rider take their seat with great fear in their eyes, and then you see them return safely to the ground taking deep breaths and laughing nervously. I even saw a grown man clutch his friend's arm and tell him "Never again!"

Once seated on the ride you get all strapped in, and I mean strapped in! They make it super tight so there is very little wiggle room at all. Safety first!  You then are elevated to the top of the ride at a slowish speed. Once you reach the top they slowly swing the seats back so that you are facing the ground. All of the people walking around Busch Gardens look like ants! Then finally, a few seconds later, they drop you! And just before you think you're about to hit the ground- splat!, they swing the seats back up to the upright position and you are safely on the ground.

Unlike the grown man I mentioned earlier, when I got off my first ride I was yelling wilth joy- "That was AWESOME!!!" I couldn't wait to do it again!

Since then I have been on Falcon's Fury 4 or 5 times and I still love it!!

The shortness of this ride is easily offset by the shear terror you experience at the top!

The wait is worth it, and usually shorter than you think as the ride holds a ton of people.  You're going to have to remove everything that isn't attached well (glasses, hats, cell phones.)

At the top, they tip the chairs so that you are hanging against your restraints and you truly feel like you're going to fall out.  Once released, the free-fall is amazing and the landing controlled and not jerky at all.

Great bucket list accomplishment if you're afraid of heights :)

I DID NOT KNOW until I got to the top of the tower that for the duration of the fall you are FACING STRAIGHT DOWN - staring at the concrete below. What a thrill. 

Amazing ride, felt safe, recommend quick queue. 

Do it!!! Seriously, you won't regret it!

Ok so I would never ride this thing in my life!! Scared of heights and scared of rides that drop you suddenly. My daughter however chose to ride this past weekend when we visited the park. The wait time wasn't long and the staff they have working the ride is very attentive to the needs of guests and ensures their safety. They check the height of young riders before they can even enter the line and are very organized with positioning riders in the waiting areas prior to getting on the ride. My daughters friend got in a panic after boarding the ride, she raised her hands and called the staff over letting them know she didn't want to ride any longer. They immediately halted things and unlocked her, escorting her off the ride. 

I felt with the level of attention and coordination of the staff that the girls were safe. There is plenty of areas around the ride where you can view riders and take pictures.

When selecting five stars for this review, Yelp said, "Woohoo! As good as it gets!"

And that's so true. This ride is perfect, no complaints. In 2014 when the ride was being built, there were many delays, but SO worth it.

The line isn't usually too long. Since 32 people can ride at once, and the cycle is short, wait usually doesn't exceed 20 minutes. The ride ops tell you where to sit (based on diamonds) so it makes it very efficient. 

You're strapped in tight and go up 335 feet. The view is great, especially facing Tampa and the Hillsborough River. It's especially terrifying realizing you're taller than Sheikra! At the top, the seats tilt and all of your weight slides to your harness. Terrifying. You can be held at the top for one to five seconds.

The mechanism releases and you fall straight down. There is so much wind and the fall feels like an eternity, but it's so liberating, just falling like that. It feels much different than riding Sheikra. This is a little less scary, honestly, but way better.

You will love this ride. When people "return" they're always smiling and laughing. Just face your fears and ride!

Falcon's fury is a great ride! It looms over the entire park. From the top, even behemoths like Shiekra and Montu look tiny. 

The ride up is beautiful and terrifying at the same time. When you face down, you literally feel pressure on the front constraints...good thing they work! 

The ride down is fast and fun. And the line is never more than 20 min!

Oh man, this ride is something else. A fairly imposing drop tower, Falcon's Fury is the tallest ride in the park at 335ft. I've been on towers that drop you before, and I've been on towers that launch you skyward before, but this is the only ride I've been on that simulates you plummeting towards the ground FACE FIRST. Approximately 3/4 of the way up the ascent your seat begins to tilt inward until you are parallel to the ground essentially hanging from your shoulder harness. Right about the time your brain starts to say "I shouldn't be in this position" you hear a click and begin to fall straight down (again, face first) at 60mph. Right before you think your going to hit concrete (about 80% down) your seat flips back out into its upright position with a woosh and you slowly come back to earth. Drop towers don't normally bother me but that change in orientation kind of freaks you out a bit. Not a ride for the faint of heart.

The scariest part of this ride is definitely waiting at the very top. You can try to calm yourself down by talking to the person next to you about how pretty Tampa looks from all the way up there, but it's probably not going to work. I can tell you that from experience. 

That being said, once the clicking stops and you know what's coming next, you might as well take a deep breath and wait for the really fun part to come... The drop. Within seconds, you're back on the ground, unsure of how you're feeling but left with a strange desire to do it all again. 

I've been on rides like this before, the go high in the air and drop super fast type, but never facing directly down. This experience made for even more butterflies in my tummy. What's so great about this ride that makes you not weary to do again and again? It's comfy! No need to worry about the harness sticking into you in weird places, your head rattling from left to right over and over, or jerking motions pulling you up and down the whole time. It's smoooooooth. 

I'm not one that's afraid of rollercoasters but would even encourage friends with the deepest fear of rides like this to give it a shot. It's definitely one of my favorite attractions at this park, if not many.

If only you could linger at the top a little bit longer. At night, the lights of Tampa make for quite the sight...

Talk about intense... Standing in line is scarier than the actual ride though. 

While you ascend it's easy to forget what's about to happen. I usually look around and admire the view. When I feel it start to slow down and start moving towards the face down position, my adrenaline kicks in and I can't help but feel like I'm about to fall out of the seat. 

I've ran out of air in my lungs while screaming before I reached the end of the drop. I wasn't really sure what to do so I just enjoyed the rush till we reached the bottom. 

I have ridden this ride over and over again. So awesome. It's a 300 ft + tall tower.

Put your feet to the sky!

This is one of my "ol' standby" rides at Busch Gardens: not my favorite, but still really fun!

Usually there is never really a line for this ride. Not sure why, but not complaining!

You start by sitting in your car that hangs under the track. The floor drops away, and you start going up the 150 foot tall hill. You get an amazing view...of the parking lot. But if you're on the right side of the train you do get to see the tangled metal that is waiting for you ;)

The drop is so fun! It's not the scariest, but its such a weird feeling to be seeing sky under your feet. You zoom through a loop, then into an underground tunnel to emerge into an Immelman loop. You swoop close to the ground before going back up and twisting in a fun corkscrew.

The next part of the ride is my least favorite. You plunge into a tight loop configuration called a batwing, which involves two loops and going into a little ditch. The loops are fine, but the g-forces in the pit are too intense for me. I pulled a muscle in my back once (somehow) on that part, so I'm always nervous.

You pull into a short break run before beginning a super fun part of the ride. You dive into a tunnel and do a quick loop before starting a quick and nimble run around the "excavation" ditches. It's just so fun going up, down, underground, and back up again. One last surprise and fast corkscrew and you pull into the station again. Whew!

This ride is fun, if a little too forceful in some parts (batwing) and not enough in others (first three loops of the ride). I feel like this ride breaks down more often than Kumba or Sheikra do (nothing tops Cheetah Hunt, though). However, there is rarley a line, and it's a really smooth ride. 

Overall, this is a nice part of the Busch Gardens lineup. Although not perfect, it s still awesome!

This roller coaster rocks.  This is a hanging roller coaster that really whips you around and shows you a good time.  It is all the way to the right after you enter and because it is in a dead end part of the park, there is rarely a wait.  Seriously, very little wait and awesome roller coaster!  I would rather ride this five or ten times than wait in the long line at Cheetah hunt.

Inverts are fun and all, but they aren't close to being my favorite style of coaster. For all the freedom they give my legs I sure find them constraining on my upper body. And I've come to the conclusion that I'll take belly tickling drops and T-shirt raising airtime over a half dozen or so loops any day. 
   Having said all that, Montu is a pretty decent ride. I'll take it over Cedar Point's Raptor any day. It rides smoother, has a much less claustrophobic layout and the batwing element that sends you barreling through a tunnel is a blast. 
   The Egyptian theming in the queue is pretty sweet, too, though Busch Gardens can't really touch sister park Sea World in that department. 
   Montu is a fun ride, but not the kind of thing I want to ride all day. And I think I need to get down to King's Island to further test my theory that I'm not a huge fan of inverted coasters.

Yes, this is quite an exciting ride. Having your feet hang loose makes it extra scary. You are taken on all sorts of maneuvers throughout the ride and it lasts for a long time. I have ridden this ride many times but do not get tired of it ever.

This is a good coaster but not the best at Busch Gardens. 
Be prepared, this coaster has 7 inversions and is very fast. This was the first inverted coaster I have been on and to be honest, I did not care for it. I prefer to see the track and know what is coming but then again others love the inverted style and so each to their own.
I admit I felt sick at the end of the ride but that could have been a combination of heat, dehydrated and the ride.
If I ride this coaster again, I may make it the first one of the day, while it is still cooler.
Fun! I love having my feet dangle while on coasters! I loved it! The line was moving quickly so we didn't have a long wait at all!

I guess I would need to ride this again. Because I didn't really like Montu. Yes it's a very intense ride wit a lot of loops. I'm also not a huge fan of suspended roller coasters, because I'm always afraid my feet would hit one of the supports. Also those are the ones that sometimes can make me nausea. Montu made me nausea, and I usually don't get nausea from coasters. So I guess seeing all the great reviews, next time I'm at Busch Gardens, I'll give Montu another shot, but Montu should probably be the last ride of the day, so if you do get nausea, it won't mess you up on any of the other roller coasters.

My best piece of advice: you must ride it in the dark! I haven't done the research but I am pretty sure that this coaster has the most inversions than any other coasters at Busch Gardens Tampa Bay. It always leaves me slightly dizzy which I don't mind because it really takes you on a hell of a ride and that's what I paid for! The wait time is never long either. I have been on this ride so many times and not once have I waited more than 10 minutes to ride it. There are cubbies for your shoes and small belongings (sunglasses, hats, tiny purses) in which you may not need a locker to purchase. This coaster is located very close to the park entrance next to the newly opened Cobra's Curse. Honestly, skip that ride and hit Montu. It's an amazing ride

My favorite coaster at BG in Tampa. This one is similar, but definitely not exactly like Apollo's Chariot at BG in Williamsburg.

The experience on the front car to any other is totally different. I would wait for the front car even if it takes another 15 minutes... it's worth it. Four riders per car usually moves the line along quickly.

The ride is fast, fun and seems to last long enough that you really feel like you get your money's worth for the wait. The track is smooth, no jerking, or side to side slam of your head on the harness. Luckily today the lines were short and I was able to get three in quickly.

I also found out if you have a Platinum pass you can ask to ride another time and not get out of your seat... now that is a really big perk if you waited in line for a long time.

On the down side this coaster is more up front of the park and can get mobbed, so hit is up early. You have to be 54 inches to ride.

I love love love this ride. I once rode this 5-6 times in a row. It looks lonely sometimes, since lots of folks don't venture to it, but it's definitely not to be missed. They have a perfect combos of twists and turns that give you a fun flying sensation.
I absolutely love the twist and turns and loops and speed!

Montu was designed brilliantly with relentless looping and twisting upside down. After three minutes of pleasurable torture the only thing I know is that I want to get right back on. Montu scares from the get-go when the floor opens and optimizes the vulnerability of its hanging passengers. The speed around the loops is exhilarating. The dated, lackluster station plus the absence of a photo during the ride may contribute to the shortest lines in the park. Fine by me. I take the opportunity to wait for the first row. It's the only row with a view since this coaster is inverted. Worth waiting the extra few minutes!

This sure is a fun one, but there are so many wonderful rides at this park it sits at number five on my list of favorites. Montu is Busch Gardens one and only suspended roller coaster. It features an impressive 150ft drop hill with tons of loops and corkscrew turns, for a total of seven inversions. Suspended coasters really do the best job of making you feel like you're flying and Montu is no exception. Coming out of a loop and into a tunnel at 60+ MPH is always a thrill, it reminds me of the Afterburner back home at Carowinds. My only minor complaint about this one is simply related to the nature of the ride. The speed and angles that give this ride such a big thrill are a little harsh in a couple of the turns, and while that doesn't mean it isn't a wonderful ride, you might not want to ride multiple times in quick succession.

I'm obsessed. I was terrified to try this ride. Everyone I know told me about how this is super rough and worse than Kumba thrill wise-in a bad way. I'm here to tell you a different story. 

The first drop looks alarming from the road. It's a pretty high drop, although I'm not going to sit here and Google the specs. There's like 6 or 7 inversions. On a hilarious side note, you get a clear view of the classic restaurant China Latina from the top. My family thinks that is hilarious and they shout "China Latina!" every time we ride. 

Anyways, this ride always has nearly zero wait because it's not the latest and greatest coaster and is tucked away in the corner. The workers will let you stay on if there's not a demand for seats. If there is then just go around and you'll have less than a five minute wait. 

I can't wait to get to Busch Gardens sister park, or parent park SeaWorld tomorrow to see how Montu measures up to Kraken. 

As far as BG goes, this is my number 2 coaster. #1 is a tie between SheiKra and Cheetah Hunt. Number 3 is Kumba. 4 is Cobras curse. 5 old trusty Scorpion. I haven't ridden Tigris yet even though I've had 7 trips to Busch Gardens since opening. I'm waiting till early entrance the first two weekends in May.

Montu is still one of my all time favorite coasters - smooth, long ride and lots of thrills.  As Montu sits at the very edge of the park, my family and I always make a game of spotting the car over in the lot across the street (trust me, my car is easy to spot).  Montu is an inverted coaster where your feet dangle and the track is above your head. There is just a special kind of magic about seeing the clouds fly by beneath your feet as you go through some of the loops.  I love the decor and theming of the area around Montu - all ancient Egypt and hieroglyphs.
Definitely the best coaster at Busch Gardens. Huge first drop. Tons of inversions. And smooth as silk. A perfect ride.

The Montu is a super fun roller coaster that's got everything! It has the drops, takes you upside down, and twists. 
The line was quick for this ride while I was there. 
Don't miss out!
Fun ride that is not for those afraid of heights or fast speeds. Ride is safe and exhilarating as it goes through multiple loops.

This is my third favorite coaster in the park, it doesn't go as fast as Kumba but it has a ton of loops and you go upside down. The first big drop slows and twists as it drops so you don't get that big sudden dropping feeling, which is great for me. Worth waiting 30 min in line.

Fun fact for those who missed it: back in the day, there used to be baby alligators at the very beginning of the ride, just where the gate opens! You would dip down and slightly panic as you imagined getting your toes a little too close to the modern day dinos. I'm sure they were removed for their own health and well-being, but I do miss them whenever I ride Montu. :)

An oldie but a goodie, Montu is a staple at Busch Gardens. When it opened in '96, it was the tallest and fastest of its kind! While drastic improvements have been made to roller coasters since then, Montu still provides a thrilling ride. My favorite maneuver will always be the tight corkscrew. So much fun!

It's not the smoothest coaster at BG, but I do find it a little smoother than Kumba, BG's first roller coaster. That being said, Montu manages to make me dizzy every time I ride it, while Kumba does not! The latter is just a little rougher of a ride.

I was a little disappointed when I noticed there's no longer a photo op after the drop. Not sure what the reason would be for this. I have fond memories of looking at my cheeks fluttering in the wind in the pictures after the ride!

If you love inversion coasters, definitely check out Montu!

Montu was a falcon-god of war in the ancient Egyptian religion, and Busch Gardens took the legend of this mythical God of flight, and turned it into a swooping, swirling, and incredibly fast steel roller coaster. Montu opened in 1996, and at the time it was the tallest and fastest inverted roller coaster in the world.

You start by walking through a section of the park just beyond the Crown Colony Restaurant. Tucked back in the corner is this area that looks like an archeological dig in the sands of Egypt. Passing though an archway, and you've discovered the temple of Montu. When the ride was first launched, a Nile crocodile exhibit was located underneath the first section of the ride. These animals were later relocated to the park's main animal habitat.

You wind around inside the pyramid before being loaded 4-across onto your cars. Once everyone is locked into place the floor drops away, leaving your feet to dangle freely. The cars swoop out of the station and then you begin the long chain lift climb up the first hill.

Without hesitation you swoop down towards the ground and into a large vertical loop, before you're whisked back up, and go through a series of inversions, twist and turns. The specs for this ride say that you'll go through 7 inversions, including two vertical loops. You'll reach top speeds of 60 mph with 3.8 G's and LOTS of airtime. The ride lasts about 3 minutes, and it is one of my very favorite rides in the park.

I can, and have, ridden Montu several times in a row, and never grow tired of the excitement. This ride is fast, smooth, and extremely exhilarating.

Another Busch Gardens special attraction that should not be missed!
Epic coaster.  Tons of inversion and the smoothest track. Very dizzy after though. That's a me problem I guess.

Have always loved Montu since the first day it opened. Great ride. Purchase the skip a line feature - so worth it! We had a normal wait of over 1 1/2 hours and it was cut to 5 minutes with the skip a line pass.

This is one of my favorite roller coasters of all time...

Montu means the falcon god of war in Egyptian - and this ride is an all-out assault and war on your senses.  From the first drop you're plunged into a high-g loop that immediately gets your blood pumping.  You're barely out of that loop when you're bombarded with a series of horizontal rolls and loops.

The ride is a longer coaster experience and your senses are engaged almost completely the entire time.  The drops are thrilling, and by the time you disembark even the most experienced rider is feeling some vertigo from all the action.

A thrill-seekers dream ride!

For someone pretty terrified of heights - I feel rather comfortable on roller coasters. Not those rinky dink coasters at the Dade County Youth Fair - I'd never ride those - but I'd ride almost every coaster at major theme parks.

With a fair share of rides under my belt Montu continues to be one of my favorites. I've always had a weird obsession with Egypt (and Dinosaurs?!) and this is located in the Egypt section of the part -so perhaps that has something to do with how much I love this ride....but it really is a great coaster!

Feet dangling. 7 inversions. 3 minutes long. 150 feet tall. Speeds up to 60 mph......and that color scheme is pretty sick (beige and purple). I don't know why but I really get a kick out of awesome color schemes on coasters.

This is a must do front row. I've come to BG a few times now and every time I have done this one front row.

2003 - Came on a field trip - me and my buddy rode it 3 times straight: front row!

2008 - Came with my wife and managed to get her to ride it. She loved it - mainly because it was a lot smoother than the one we went on before this (Gwazi...yikes!). Front row!

2014 - Came with a big group and rode front row with a couple of buddies (Yelp event) - it was night time and pretty awesome....oh yea, FRONT ROW!

It's hard to believe this coaster is almost 20 years old! It's withstood the test of time and a must do coaster at BGTB!

FUN FACT: Montu is one of only seven roller coasters to appear in the top 50 for all 15 years in Amusement Today '​s annual Golden Ticket Awards!

Great ride.Definitely go front row for the best experience.Even though front row is a longer wait it's still very worth it!The ride is much better at night,it feel definitely more faster.The ride has a very short line,I would say about a 5 minute wait time(waiting for front row would be about 10 minutes).While in front row you can see mostly everything that's right in front of you.I recommend to take off your shoes because it makes the ride so much better.Taking of the shoes makes it also very stress-relieving,if your shoes aren't/feel very tight then take them off,the ride will feel way much better!Montu is a very enjoyable ride when wanting to have a favorite roller coaster where you can never get bored of.This roller coaster is a ride where you can never get scared of (maybe get scared in the first time you ride it).I usually get on this ride first because it is a very nice ride to start with and gets the excitement going to get on bigger and stronger roller coasters the park has to offer.If you want to get thrown around I would recommend to get on the back row!I would very much love to see you try both of the rows and maybe also in the middle to see which one is the best and most comfortable for you.The quick queue is not worth it on this ride!i really hope I helped.please excuse my horrible grammar and punctuation,this is my first review.

If an extra star were possible, Montu would get it.  I have to say for a roller coaster lover this is the end all if you love those loops.  

It has:
Immelmann 
Zero G-Roll or Heartline spin
Batwing (one of my favs)
Corkscrew (another one of my fav loops)
and a 60' loop.

PLUS it is one of the longest roller coasters in the world.  What is NOT to love about all of this?  It is smooth like butter, fast and totally loopy!  This is one of the finest rides in Florida!  Hands down.

If you like to feel like you are flying, this is definitely the ride for you.

We're here at Busch Gardens Tampa getting ready to ride. Montu, their legendary B&M inverted coaster.

Now, if you look at this ride from the ground. It looks amazing. I mean, it's very pretty, the inversions look great, it's well themed, it looks great. However, this ride is not good. No, no no no. IT'S FREAKING AMAZING! LIKE OH MY GOD, THIS RIDE IS ACTUALLY FREAKING INSANE. This ride blows literally every other B&M invert that I've ridden out of the water. It makes Batman and Dragon Challenge look like SILVER BULLET! It's THAT GOOD! So yeah, this ride is flipping amazing. Now let's get into why this coaster is as godlike as it is.

We first exit the station and head into the lift hill. Apparently, there used to be an alligator pit below the pre-life section. But this was removed for unknown reasons (my guess was due to stupid GP people thinking it was funny to throw stuff at them (OMG SERIOUSLY I HATE PEOPLE)). But anyway, we then head up the big lift hill and get a nice view of the big twisted mess off to the left and Tampa itself off to the right. After this, we hit the first drop, while it's not Twisted Colossus or X2 good, it's FAST and gives a nice whip to it. We then soar into the vertical loop. And unlike most, this one is FAST. We just fly through this thing with some awesome forces. Don't worry, the worst part of the ride is over. (Yes I said the worst part, the terror of Montu has only begun). We then head into a dark trench with a ton of speed until suddenly *BOOM* we shoot out of it through an Immelmann. Not only is this moment insane on its own due to the crazy speed and forces we get, but we get a CRAZY foot chopper moment since the entrance to Egypt is mere inches away from us. So yeah, that moment was awesome. We then hit a zero g roll which is insane as this thing is POWERFUL. Seriously, what's with the Florida B&M's and having powerful Zero G Rolls. It's like they all formed a blood pack or something. So yeah, this moment is crazy. However, the madness is not quite over as we then get into one of the most intense moments on any coaster out there. The Batwing. DEAR.... FREAKING.... LORD.... They put a batwing in the middle of a trench which sounds insane already. But the fact that you have almost ALL OF YOUR FREAKING SPEED FROM THE ZERO G ROLL INTO IT CREATES SOME OF THE STRONGEST FORCES EVER. LIKE DEAR GOD. THIS IS JUST INSANE. THIS IS LITERALLY X2 INSANE RIGHT HERE. We then get a small breather by gliding into the MCBR (which doesn't take away much if not any of our speed) as the then head into the 2nd half of the ride. If you're worried that you're gonna lose your speed here, don't worry. Montu's not one of those coasters that dies after the 2nd half (I'm looking at YOU Mako). In fact, this is still probably as intense as your average Batman clone (Which is still one of the more intense B&M's ever). But anyway, we then hit another vertical loop. This is even better than the first as it's smaller so we are still flying through it. After that, we then hit a fairly strong helix before hitting a corkscrew (which is pretty dang strong as well and is made even better since it's in a trench). We then hit the brake run, and out of breath.

Have I mentioned I love this ride? Yes? Well let me say it again, I FREAKING LOVE MONTU. THIS COASTER IS SO FREAKING NUTS! This is unquestionably the best coaster in Florida (well at least it is until Iron Gwazi Opens) and it's easily the best coaster I have ever ridden (out of the 90 that I've ridden). Montu is THAT insane. On top of everything that I mentioned, this is also the smoothest B&M I have ever ridden. There is NO RATTLE ON THIS THING AT ALL, ON TOP OF NO HEADBANGING. IT'S SO SMOOTH. Anyways, I cannot recommend Montu enough. Ride Montu. I don't care if the line is somehow absurdly long or if the apocalypse is about to happen. RIDE MONTU. YOU WILL REGRET IT IF YOU DON'T

Final Score: 100/100

Opened: May 16, 1996

Manufacturer: B&M

Last Ridden: January 12, 2020

Best Rollercoaster that I have ever ridden

This coaster is in my top 3 at Bush Gardens and in good company with Cheetah Hunt and Sheikra!

Smooth? Yes
Fast? Yes
Great drops, loops and twists? Yes!

A classic coaster that's tons of fun!

Awesome roller coaster! Lots of loops and quick turns! This use to be my favorite ride at Busch Gardens... That was when I was too afraid to go on Sheikra. Now that I am fearless at that park, Sheikra and Falcon's Fury are tied for my favorites. Montu is such a thrilling coaster though. I highly recommend riding in first row.
My all time favorite ride in Busch Gardens. Dangling feet, fast speed, and smooth turns and loops. Everything that makes a great roller coaster.

This is a great roller coaster at Busch Gardens.  I would recommend riding in the front for several reasons.  Since you are dangling from the top visually its a better ride in the front and due to the nature of the ride itself, riding in the front provides very unique ride feeling almost as if you are motionless during some moments.  In the back, it will feel much faster as you get whipped around.  Try it from both and see what you think.

Who doesn't like a great roller coaster!  The Montu rocks it with its super smooth curves taking you a an fighter airplane type ride.  Loops and twists and ups and downs.  Great times.  Trying to figure out how to install one of these at the house.  Did I mention your legs are hanging the whole time?  Even cooler.

This has got to be the most under-rated ride in the park. Every time I ride this coaster I'm completely taken aback by how intense it is. The drop is not so high,  but the loops and spins are ferocious. 

The best part is that there is hardly ever a line.

I love that this roller coaster really looks like it may be in a place that you might find a cheetah (even if it is a little abstractly).  The speed going up hill in two places is incredible and a good shock.  The length of the ride and the number of twists and turns make it one of my favorite rides.

Holy COW! errr, CHEETAH! We finally made it up to the front. We were in line for the front row. Then... they had a mechanical issue. Ugh. To wait or not to wait. We waited and we were SO glad! 

Half an hour later, and after they cleaned the back seats of each train they let us on. 

It truly is like a cheetah. Great ride. I would ride it over and over and over again. Smooth ride too. Doesn't yank you around and smash your head into the head rails.

Just couldn't get past the Cheetahs being housed directly under part of the track which makes them suseptable to listening to screaming humans all day and night.

Couldn't they have found a more humane way to do this? Just kind of put a damper on it for me

A really fun coaster, but about as big of a disappointment as a four star review can be. I know, I know, I'm a fool for having such sky high expectations, and it's totally first world problems. Cheetah Hunt rides nice and smooth but just doesn't pack anywhere near the visceral punch of that Intamin launched masterpiece up in Sandusky, Maverick. 
   I had watched a YouTube pov of this coaster so I knew Cheetah Hunt doesn't put it's elements in rapid fire succession like Maverick, as it's trying to mimic a cheetah rocketing across the savannah rather than a wild bucking horse. But I also knew the YouTube video of Maverick doesn't come anywhere close to capturing the exurberant thrill of actually strapping in and riding it. So I thought Cheetah Hunt would hold similar uncapturable wonder. And it was really good, but not 5 star great. And this might be splitting hairs, but cheetahs can reach speeds of 65 MPH while this high tech piece of humankind's machinery only hits 60. Couldn't you have boosted these cheetah-themed trains another 5 MPH, guys? 
   Cheetah Hunt also has the hard restraints that Cedar Point wisely swapped out for a softer variety on Maverick. And they're not as bad as some of the CP fanboys have made them out to be but the soft restraints are clearly superior, especially if wait times are short and you want to reride again and again without accruing a sore pair of shoulder blades. As for me, I squeezed in 2 rides on Cheetah Hunt on a February Wednesday when Busch Gardens closed at the early hour of 5pm.
   Cheetah Hunt is a fine roller coaster, but just isn't in the same league as Maverick, or even Sheikra which sits elsewhere in the same park. If your time is limited and you have to choose just one to ride or reride I recommend Sheikra.

Like a Cheetah -  Accelerates 0-60mph less than 4 seconds.  Unlike other coasters can accelerate at any time even when going up steep hills.   First of a kind electromagnetic propulsion system for a roller coaster is amazing.  Quiet smooth.  You will wind through canyons in the jungle.  Well Done.  The best coaster ever.  Great theme and deserving of the name.  It is also a longer ride than most coasters.

I love this ride!
While it may not be as thrilling as some other coasters, as it has very few inversions, I loved the initial speed at the start of the ride. Rather then the slow climb to the stop, this shoots you forward right away and there are about 3 more sections along the ride, where to get a speed boost.
For those that want a roller coaster experience without being upside down, this is a great ride!
I liked the ride overall. It had some nice unique elements   which I will not reveal here. The seat was very uncomfortable to me and dug into my shoulders, making it a rather painful ride.

Awesome. This coaster is truly one of a kind as I've never been on anything like it. The only problem is they hold back pretty hardcore because its designed as a starter coaster, meaning its mainly for early aged teenies. It's got three launches, and all of them are awesome. It's also got some really cool elements that I've actually never seen on a coaster before simply by the nature of the ride being designed to simulate a cheetah running through the Forrest and stalking its prey. 

The only problem that I have with the ride is that it's about 13 mph too slow. Notch this bad boy up 13mph, and it would easily go from 4 out of 5 to a very easy 5 out of 5 stars

I give cheetah run a swift 4 out of 5 stars

This is Busch Gardens newest roller coaster scheduled to be open in Spring 2011.  The hunt will begin with a launch--a first for Busch Gardens--propelling guests from 0 to 60 mph.  The ride will sprint down over 4,000 feet of track across a Serengeti plain and through a canyon.  It will open with a sister attraction called Cheetah Run, which will feature close-up encounters with Earth's fastest animal.

Busch Gardens says that Cheetah Hunt will have the largest footprint of any attraction yet built at their park.

Even though it is tough not to get excited about another roller coaster in the Central Florida market with the design style of Disney's Rock 'n' Roller Coaster and Universal's the Mummy, not everyone is excited about the name.  In fact, many fans believe that the name suggests that guests are hunting the cheetahs, which obviously goes against the park's conservation efforts.

Nevertheless, I plan on riding it once, then again, and then several more times.
I rode for my fourth and fifth time today!  I got to the park right at opening (9:30) and walked right on.  Rode both the front and back row within 10 minutes!  Great job BGT!
It was closed due to computer, technical, or other misc problems....... disappointed.

This was our first ride at Busch Gardens and boy did it set the bar high. Talk about fast! There were so many turns and loops that I had to close my eyes (as a non roller coaster rider). I loved that you passed the cheetah habitat before you get to the ride. It is a 90 second ride that takes you on some fast turns a breathtaking drop. My friend loves this ride and my little person screams in delight as it sped us the park like a quick cheetah. It was one of the rides that is worth the wait. I liked the strapped down harness that gave me a sense of security in the fast paced roller coaster ride.

This rides wait was 45 minutes I'm still waiting because it's been over and hour and we have been sitting at the front of the line for over 20 minutes they shut down the ride and tested it three times they left the cart with the harnesses closed for 15 minutes they have stopped testing and I'm still in line
Indifferent . Lots of stomach tossing in not a good way... like you'll need to take a crap after

A world-class roller coaster that is also really accessible to folks who aren't into the more extreme rides. A long wait, but it was worth it. My kid and I loved it so much that we ponied up for the Fast Lane/line skip for a second ride, and then used all the time we saved to wait for a front row seat. It was amazing, and totally worth the money. 

One complaint: on a really hot day, the ventilation fans in the queue area are just not up to the task. Hydrate and hit the bathroom before you get in oline.

One of the smoothest coasters I have ever been on. There are three separate linear induction launch points on the coaster that really make it fun. The emphasis is on smooth forward quick motion rather than the ups and downs the traditional coaster. Travels about three quarters of length of the park over a very short period of time, and it one point actually goes over the sky ride. Smoooooth and comfortable. If you're afraid of coasters, don't let the first tower scare you away, cause after the figure eight, that's the only real drop, the rest is fairly close to (and sometimes below) the ground. If you try it, I can almost guarantee you'll like it and want to do it again.

Oddly, this may be one of my least favorite coasters at BG.  While the speed and twisty track are fun - the ride is just so short that it's over right about when I start enjoying it.  Fun idea and I do appreciate BG's fun themes/animal tie-ins for their rides.

Being the first time I've ever been on the ride it wasn't the best experience.We had a handicap pass meaning we were able able to skip the long line.But heres the part that I didn't enjoy that much.The ride broke down! It literally took about 30 min for them to sort out the problem.Then they threw in some tests to see if the ride was functioning well enough for us to ride on. That was about another 15min then finally we were able to get on the ride.I was hoping the ride wouldn't take long because I had to use the bathroom like BAD.Everything went fine on the ride until the end.We were ahead of everyone and so I think they experienced worse.The ride stopped and according to what I heard, the ride broke down again and at this point, I needed to GO to the bathroom like BAD! But luckily they got me out and I rushed out and felt relieved.

I've always had fear of roller coasters because of my fear of heights.  But I wanted to face my fears So today my 31st birthday I decided That I would ride Cheetah Hunt as my first ever Roller coaster ride. Let me say I had no idea the physicality of the G forces from this ride were staggering. It was going so fast the turns I could barely breath The adrenaline was at an all time reaching the summit and looping up down left and right Amazing ride completely terrifing Id recommend highly for coaster enthusiasts.

I really enjoy this ride because it offers slightly more comfort than some of the older roller coasters. BuschGardens has a wooden roller coaster that just makes you so nauseated by the time you're done and then you get on this roller coaster and it's like night and day difference.

The technology that went behind this roller coaster to make it launch and accelerate you like it does is very cool.  There are two different types of motors that can be used for the launch process one is a linear induction and the second is linear synchronous motor.  Now the motors can be powered either pneumatically or hydraulically I believe this ride is actually pneumatic just from listening to the pressure release when you're launching.

I have ridden this ride enough to notice that if you sit in the front it seems to go a lot faster to sit in the back it doesn't seem to go as fast but the big humps you go over deliver a lot of airtime.

The only complaint I have is there aren't enough inversions I mean loops upside down the cool stuff! Besides that it's a good ride and something you would jump back in line to ride again.

One of my favorite rides! I love launch coasters, and this one has several launches along the track. Cheetah Hunt is really a beautiful ride of technical splendor. I especially enjoy riding in the dark, as it adds a bit more excitement with all the banking around curves without being able to see. I used to dislike what I have named the slowest inversion ever, but it's grown on me. Totally worth the wait if you have the time.

This coaster is awesome!....and well named.  Fast, sleek and smooth.  I enjoyed every bit of this ride, love the feeling of hitting the turbos as we hunt our pray and run across the park.  This baby is a long ride for a coaster and feels like you have slipped Into a Cheetahs skin.  I'm ready for the next hunt.....

Bravo Busch Gardens for a perfectly executed theme!
Very smooth roller coaster with awesome boosters! Def. One of the top 3 roller coasters at Busch gardens.

Such an awesome ride !!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!! It's smooth and easy going. If you have never looked up the ride, it takes you as a surprise because it's better than how simple it looks by the outside. Definitely recommended to ride and experience.

Cheetah hunt is conveniently located near the main entrance of Busch Gardens, and is my favorite "warmup" ride -even though it always feels faster than I had remembered. Inspired by the way the Cheetah runs in explosive bursts, this coaster includes three launch sequences. The ride thrusts you out of the station at 30mph and travels quickly through the neighboring Cheetah habitat. There aren't any loops but there is a heart line twist that is quite thrilling. There are calmer moments when you can actually observe the esthetic landscapes and wildlife. The photo snaps while you're twisting and turning through the dark rock caves.  A newer addition to the coaster family at Busch Gardens, Cheetah shares a station with the Sky Ride and tends to have long wait times. Take advantage of any wait time under 30 minutes.

Cheetah is my 2nd favorite ride at Busch Gardens. Sheikra is my first. This coaster is a lot of fun. It's very fast with some hills and a few speed boosts. While riding the ride I actually felt I was a Cheetah going on a real hunt. If you have the Quick Queve, then use it for this ride, because the lines can get very long. If no quick queve, then make this ride the first one you ride during your day. So have fun because this is a fun roller coaster. It's a blast!!

I do not understand why people like this coaster. I love roller coasters. I want to ride then till I get shaken baby syndrome. I would ride them till the day I die and then have a coaster take me to my final resting place. I just hope that coaster isn't Cheetah Hunt.  The ridiculously long lines aside, this coaster is BORING.  Some coasters try to shake you up.  Some coasters like to rock you or spin you for loops.  This one is long, low, and fast.  But I am not out for scenery even if it is the African Seregheti whipping by.  But if I want that, I will take their train.  I want thrills and chills.  There just aren't any thrills with this ride.  And some of my friends think that they noise could spook the live cheetah nearby.  I don't know but it just isn't that fun when I can go to any other coaster here for 15 minute waits or less and a better ride.

Love it!!! You really feel like cheetah with whooshes of acceleration in flats and even up slopes. Zooming around and whirling too is fun. 

Rooooooooaaaaaaar!!!!!

This has to be my new favorite coaster in the state. The seating is comfortable, the ride isn't too jarring, the line is tolerable, and totally worth it. The speed is puzzling, and keeps you guessing without making you want to puke. I'm an old lady but this ride has me asking if we can do it again!

This is second hand review, my crazy A%^&*S sis loved this ride. She was hoping to go again but we were stuck at the Elmo area w/ the kids forever. LOL
P.S. To all the people that love these kind of rides...my hats are off to you all. I am the biggest pansy and you couldn't pay me to ride this baby !
This was a great coaster for BGT.....The speed was awesome and smooth....shout out to my Bro! Cupps!!!!

This has probably been the worst coaster in the entire park, didn't even get a chance to ride it. With the ride breaking down three times for some "unfortunate weather conditions," it had its chance. We've waited for a total of 3 hours and it's been a total waste of time waiting in line. The last time we tried, the ride shut down and none of the workers knew when the ride was going to come back up. Just ridiculous.. Worst line for a ride ever. Good luck getting in without it breaking down, you'll need a freakin miracle.

Great roller coaster!   Ride it as soon as you walk in the park and the lines will be short.   The coaster accelerates like a cheetah does and then does some good drops and twists.   The ride is longer than most coasters, so even if you wait a little, it's worth it.   It's not as crazy as many of the other coasters in the park, so good for those that are a little fearful.

I came here Monday morning as soon as it opened and the wait was about 40 minutes , it was definitely worth it! Very fast ride lots of turns and drops they take your picture at the worst time when you think you might loose your stomach! I loved it was very fun and I'd go again !

Disappointing all around.  The first two times we tried to ride it it was broken.  When we finally got to ride it we were underwhelmed.  The ride isn't all that fast and it's just not as exciting as the other coasters in the park.

It almost feels like the ride isn't going as fast as it should.  There's a hill just after the first launch where you just about come to a stop.  And during the one inversion you're going so slow that you feel like you're hanging from your restraint.  It feels like something just isn't right with the ride.

For something advertized to be all about SPEED, it's pretty boring.

Maybe they will speed it up in the future and make it the ride we all want it to be!

I finally got to experience cheetah hunt for the first time and think this roller coaster is definitely as good as it gets!  First, it takes off and builds speed right off the bat, none of the click click click all the way to the top stuff. It has the scary, heart jumping drops, but also extends out over animal exhibits. I think this roller coaster has everything great rolled in one.

My entire family LOVED this coaster!  I felt like a cheetah on this ride. We did have about an hour wait but it was definitely worth it. I read some reviews of complaints that the ride was boring; I feel like I'm pretty hard to impress with roller coasters so I'm not sure what they're talking about. This is the first coaster I've ever been on that uses the magnets to speed up multiple times throughout the ride; all the other ones I've been on, IF they do use the magnets to speed back up, I've never felt it. This ride makes it a point for you to know you're about to attack something like a cheetah!

The second best roller coaster in Busch Garden, in my opinion.  It is a long ride compared to others and takes off fast.  Not only the takeoff, they give you accelerations a couple times during.  They are some loops and twists also.  Surprisingly, even with all the crazy motions, the ride is pretty smooth and I didn't bang my head or anything.

Best roller coaster at Busch Gardens! There was a time when Gwazi was my number one coaster, but Cheetah Hunt stole my heart. Had a chance to ride this recently thanks to a Yelp Event in Tampa. 

So this coaster, it's fast, it's slow, it's like a cat ready to pounce. If you are afraid of coasters, just try this one and you will be pleasantly surprised at how thrilling it is, but not terrifying or scary. This is pure fun. Also, this is a long ride, so it's nice to stay on the ride for a while and enjoy yourself. The ride is so smooth, there is barely any bumping along, it feels like you are gliding. The line is a bit long, but so worth the wait.

This coaster is an awesome addition to Busch Gardens!  I've never been on a coaster like this... It only sits two people in a row, which leads to a much smaller coaster and thinner track - which really messes with your mind when you are riding!

Don't pass this up - it's worth the wait!
Great ride!  Effortless and pure fun.  Totally worth the two hour wait.

Cheetah Hunt is one of the newer rides at Bush Gardens , the ride it self is pretty cool and it starts you off sitting in the ride and then you take off like a Cheetah going from zero to 60 mph within seconds. The ride it self has a lot of turns and twist not many upside down turns but you do go fast at one point and then you drop making you feel your stomach rolling back. 

Over all the ride is good and I have nothing negative to say about it and will like to come back and ride it again, I am not quit sure why everyone rates it only four stars as oppose to five.The lines were long but what can you expect? it is BushGardens and it is the first ride you run in to when you come in to the park, over all I like this ride.

Cheetah Hunt is my new favorite roller coaster. It starts off with a crazy 0 to 60 mph jolt. You definitely will feel a bit weird in your stomach on this ride. It has upside sown loops and a great scenery. There are two cheetahs outside of the attraction that are magnificent creatures. While on the ride you are able to see the gorillas, giraffes, zebras and many other animals that are around the attraction. I was a big fan of Montu but this has taken over as my favorite ride. It is basically the perfect mix of Montu and Kumba. I was recently on Manta at Sea World and this blows it out of the water. Enjoy!

Cheetah Hunt is the best coaster that I will ride in Busch gardens. That's cause I'm a wimp and won't go on the others like Sheikra. 

It's a smooth coaster with a good boost at 30 mph at the start, and top speed of 60.  It has a 130' drop, and nice corkscrew turns. After the initial climb, it stays close to the ground, making you feel like a cheetah on the hunt. 

As we were at the park when they opened, we had no lines to ride!  It tends to get real busy later in the day, so get there first and you will have no problems getting a few rides in before the lines get annoying.

I had a really high expectation before getting on the cheetah hunt.  I saw signs saying that you'll feel a force of up to 4G, which is more than what astronauts feel during launch into outer space (3G) so I wanted to feel that.

However, when I finally got on the ride and it launched. It went super fast, but I didn't really feel that "force". Even the "Mission Space" ride at Epcot made me feel the pressure more.
