Yeah, it's a longer ride, but it's just ok for me. I'm glad I didn't wait too long for this ride because I used the quick queue ticket. I personally thought that Sheikra was A LOT more fun!

I'm sorry but this ride has the most ridiculous wait time ever. It's as if they make you wait in purpose. The clock outside is NEVER accurate. If it says 45 minutes expect an hour and a half. If it says 80 minutes expect 2+ hours. The ride is constantly malfunctioning too. Also, the attendants take leisurely strolls while checking that all seatbelt a are safe. It appears that they don't care at all how quickly people get on and off. 

Ugh
I am scared of most roller coasters, but love this fun coaster. It's fast, smooth, and gets your heart pumping. I only wish it were a bit longer, and the lines were shorter! Favorite ride at BG.

Most coasters just look to break ya neck. Cheetah's Run, though; it tells a story. 

You're a young but aware cheetah, perusing the Serengeti plain in search of a Thomson's gazelle. What's that? Run. Run now!

Byew! 0-40 in three strides. 

It's a series of dips and zips, a heartline flip and an electronic growl or three. You dodge cavern walls and skim the surface of watering holes. You beat the cheetah's burden and reap his reward: a freshly killed digital candid, available for purchase in the gift shop. 

It's long, smooth and exhilarating. Chee(tah)rs to a winner of a new attraction.

This may be the most fun coaster in the world! Moderate thrills. But the 3 launches are fantastic. The 2nd one makes you think you're going to fly of the track! Lots of dips and banks and changes in direction. Super smooth as well. And a very long ride. I just laugh and laugh all the way through it. It is amazingly fun.

I give this roller coaster 3 stars because the ride is really long. I believe they said that the track is 3/4 of a mile long! Other than it being a long ride, it was pretty boring. I go on roller coasters for the thrill, not to enjoy the scenery. The ride was so slow!! The only real fast part is the beginning where they shoot you out. There is also only one real drop, and even it isn't that exciting. 

This ride isn't worth the long wait. Experience it when you go to BG on a day when the park is dead.

My FAVORITE ride! The operators kept the coasters moving very efficiently so the lines kept moving super quick. There was always a coaster unloading & loading so we maybe waited 20 minutes tops for the ride. I loved ITV
If you have a bad back, DO NOT ride this!   It stops suddenly at the end of the ride.  I could hardly walk after this ride.   You would think it being a newer ride it would be smooth.

TLDR: Although the wait times can be long, they are well worth it for the best roller coaster at Busch Gardens.

With the gradual addition and removal of rides at Busch Gardens over the years, I think Busch Gardens has a real gem in Cheetah Hunt. As noted by the name, this is a more unique type of roller coaster that starts off with an almost instantaneous launch instead of your traditional big drop. There's a variety of twists and turns throughout the ride and it makes for a great experience in a roller coaster that makes you want to ride again as soon as it's over.

With the lines sometimes getting a bit outrageous here, I would highly recommend getting the fast lane pass for this ride. From my understanding, if you don't use the pass for the other rides listed, you can use the pass again for a second on Cheetah Hunt. It's a really great way to save 30-60 minutes and experience the roller coaster more than once. 

If you don't mind waiting a bit more, there is a separate line for the first row. I didn't get a chance to ride in the first row, but you do have a great experience either way on any part of the ride.

This is my favorite roller coaster. I love everything about it. I did not at all feel dizzy. It felt like it lasted a while, and it was just so much fun. It's the first time I've been on a coaster that when it's over you can literally hear everyone saying the same thing "THIS WAS AWESOME!". Everyone sitting in front and behind me had the same reaction. And it really was awesome. The way it shoots you out. The smoothness. The length. I really can't wait to ride this again!

One of my favorite coasters in all the world! It's most especially fun at night when the only thing you can really see are the tracks and the soft lighting and hear the screams of those around you due to it being Howl-o-Scream.
If you are looking for a Speed ride, this is the one. Get ready for the long lines because this one is always packed on your regular weekend day. Very smooth ride and pretty long.
Amazing coaster! Our family really loves it. We recently visited the park and bought the skip line pass. So worth it! The normal wait was 55 minutes and we were in within 5 minutes!

I cannot believe that I haven't reviewed my favorite coaster at Busch Gardens yet.  I have a paralyzing fear of heights but Cheetah Hunt doesn't trigger me at all. This is a launch coaster so there's no agonizing slow climb up a lift hill where you go higher and higher.  You just go flying around a nearby corner as you are launched.  What's really fun is that there is a second launch that gets you going 60 mph as you are propelled up into a really unique looking part of the track that wraps around itself.  This is the part you see in the Busch Gardens logo! After this part there's one last launch and some fun sections where you can get some airtime. On some of the other coasters such as Montu your view isn't so great if you're not in the front, but I think sitting in any part of Cheetah Hunt is fine. Another nice feature is that instead of the huge horse collars you have to wear for other coasters the overhead restrains are smaller and more comfortable because there's only one inversion on the track. I love this coaster!

One of my very favorite roller coasters across the country, Cheetah Hunt simulates the explosive speed of a cheetah on the run hunting for a meal. The ride starts with you strapping yourself into high-tech seat with a pull-down shoulder restraint that locks you in place into your seat. After a quick thumbs up from the ride attendants you burst ahead with a blast of speed and then start the looping and twisting motions as the cheetah dodges and weaves around the park.

You soar up to look out over the entire park, and then suddenly blast down as if the animal is chasing it's prey. Along the way coaster aficionados will get plenty of air time as you crest the heights and then chase after your stomach as the track drops away for a steep dive.

Be sure to stop and watch the Park's cheetahs at the exhibit near the entrance to this ride, and pay attention to how they seem to zoom back and forth as they run. That's what this ride will feel like!

This launch coaster is packed with thrills.  At the get-go, the coaster eases forward slightly then launches you 30 mph (feels faster!) out the station.   It is the second launch that propels you up to 60 mph literally straight into the sky!! We did this at nighttime and WOW, what an experience!  There are so many different ride elements on this coaster that make it unique.  The next time I go, I definitely want to ride it during the day to take in the amazing views.  The coaster is pretty smooth, although I was wearing earrings and my head was bouncing back and forth between the shoulder harnesses and when the ride stopped, my ears were a bit sore.  Other than that- A++++
This is my favorite ride. Unfortunately when I came to the park today it wasn't running. This is why I give o my three stars.

Wine tipsy review time! 

Cheetah hunt was my first roller coaster ever in 2016. I mean ever. I lost like 100lbs to be able to ride a rollercoaster and I was stoked to be able to ride, but that all changed when I went on Cheetah. I was shook. It was over. 

Enter 2019 and several baby coasters later (thanks scorpion, my old friend!) Anyhow. A glass of wine, 50 Baby Shamu rides at Sea world and a few Scorpion warm up rides and my coaster balls were once again a force to be reckoned with. Awww yeah. I was ready. Okay this was like four days ago. I rode it twice on Sunday and I'm good to go. It's a top 3 favorite. 1) Baby Shamu at the SeaWorld Orlando kiddy park - do not judge me! 2). Old trusty Scorpion, 3). Cheetah. 4) Manta at SeaWorld, and that one is scary af to me, but I'm still a coaster newb. If you want an exhilarating ride, do cheetah hunt. It's AMAZING. 

More to come later this week. I plan on tackling Kumba and Sand Serpent. I know that's a kiddie ride but let me do me.
Definitely the best roller coaster in Busch Gardens.  Its smooth, its fast and has a lot of different elements.  The surprise launches make it fun as well.
I CAME I SAW I CONQUERED!!!!! Let me stop lying i dont get on rides and after i saw what this ride does i never will ride again!!!!!!!

Love this ride!

As Busch Gardens' newest roller coaster, it has set the bar high! Simulating the run of a cheetah, this coaster has awesome acceleration! It gets off to a fast start, but keeps up the speed and excitement throughout the entire ride. I thought the ride was a great length too.  I loved the quick turns and drops. One of my favorites at BG, for sure!

Our favorite Busch Gardens coaster! Smooth, fast and exhilarating! My absolute favorite part of the ride experience is when the track snakes back and forth as if you are a cheetah bobbing and weaving on the hunt! You can see it about 39 seconds into this video link of the ride, but experiencing it is so much better: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=skez9_TTJb4  
or at the 1 minute : 26 second mark on this ride experience video: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=bwDDIACHwg4

The ride takes off in a 40 mph burst of speed from the very moment you begin, then into a curve and down underground. It's so smooth it's ridiculous!  I hate those sorts of coasters that are so bumpy and jerky that I feel like I have a headache after riding them. Cheetah Hunt delivers all the thrills without any of the headaches! It is truly a fantastic coaster and has similar elements from Cedar Points amazing Maverick coaster (one of my all-time favorites).

But what makes this ride even more awesome is the 48" height requirement. There are very few rides that have this sort of speed and thrill that younger children can ride. It makes it very easy for a mom or dad to take their younger children on the same ride experience with the older kids! THAT is awesome!  



RIDE FACTS

Max speed: 60 mph
Duration: 4 minutes
Track length: 4,429′
Height: 102′



FINAL THOUGHTS

AWESOME, AWESOME, AWESOME... and to quote Forrest Gump: "That's all I have to say about that!"



2016/53

My favorite roller coaster ever. 

This is the most popular ride in Busch Gardens. The line frequently exceeds an hour! But its for good reason. 

The ride starts out with a pretty fast and powerful launch, quickly followed by a faster one. You rise to the top of a tower. You have a few seconds to admire the view before you plunge into a pit!

The rest of the ride soars over the Serengeti Plain. If you aren't screaming, you can admire the view of the park. I love the part where you zig zag over a river, dodging rocks and waterfalls. 

That's followed by a THIRD launch, pushing you over an awesome airtime hill before bringing you back to home. 

This ride is just amazing. Be sure to either ride it super early or super late if you don't want to wait in line. Awesome at night :)

Could this be my new favorite roller coaster at Busch Gardens? It might be. I mean I have some long standing favorites (spoiler alert: Gwazi is not one of them!) but this new coaster is smooth, fast and pretty awesome.

So I quickly learned that 60 miles per hour is pretty freakin' fast. Apparently it feels especially fast if you are doing front row! Yep, me and 2 of my buddies (and one random dude) all rode front row - you know, YOLO. We got launched off the platform (awesome!) and whizzed through the track for what felt like forever. I read that the ride lasts 3 and a half minutes. I promise it feels extremely long....and every second is worth it. The ride climbs to about 130 feet (then drops you down) and there's one inversion. 

This is a great addition to Busch Gardens and if you haven't been in a few years they have a couple cool rides that you might want to come check out - this being one of them.

While I didn't see it, I read there is also a cheetah exhibit near the ride to tie in with the theme of it. You get to watch as the cheetahs sprint after toys, showcasing their insane speed.

This coaster is incredible. It's not quite as smooth as SheiKra but nowhere near as jostling as Kumba. Just like the Hulk at Universal, it starts with a launch (a boost) that jettisons you out of the loading bay at 30mph. There is then a second launch that shoots you up to the coaster's top speed of 60mph. A third launch toward the end boosts you back up to 40mph before the final brake run and end of the ride.

The ride is thrilling and so much fun. I absolutely love it! You can really tell that the engineers researched how cheetahs actually move and hunt in the wild. If you haven't watched any cheetah documentaries, cheetahs are known for quickly switching directions and using their tails for balance, flicking them from side to side as they move. You can literally feel this sensation during the ride, and it's wonderfully immersive.

If you love roller coasters, don't pass this one up. It's unique from all the other offerings at Busch Gardens.

Hands down the best roller coaster at Busch Gardens! I loved this ride I rode it twice on my best visit here. The line first time was short maybe fifteen minutes but the second time was around forty five minute wait. I really think this ride feels the longest as well because all the others feel like seconds. My favorite part of this ride is the speed at first take off. Next a big part of the ride I loved is how there's so many slight turns in the track it adds so much to the experience and acts like a cheetah running. On my next trip to Busch Gardens this will be my first choice of rides.

This is it folks. This ride right here is the one. Cheetah Hunt is hands down the best ride at Busch Gardens Tampa.

Just walking into the waiting area for this ride is pretty neat. It's a like you're inside a giant temple, and the huge stone cheetah in the center really adds to the epic scale of things. Lines were not that bad, though to be fair I don't think mid December is peak theme park season, even in Florida. 

Each train can hold sixteen thrill seekers per run, lined up two by two. Over the shoulder restraints keep you nice and snug, but the seats are still comfortable. Any seat is a good one on this ride but if you have the time do yourself a favor and ride front row at least once. Maybe it's childish, but being up with the custom designed cheetah head on the front of the train makes the ride seem just that much more fun. 

Once your locked in it's time for an incredible roller coaster experience. Less than ten seconds into pulling away from the station the first set of electromagnetic launch motors shoots you into a sweeping left turn at 30mph and into a dip. The curve straightens out and just as you think you might slow down you hit the second launch, the largest and fastest of the ride. You rocket onward and upward 100ft into the air at 60mph and once you crest the hill you ease into a figure eight with a wonderful view of the park. The curve completes and you drop back down into a trench that leads into another hill. You soar over the top of the Skyride gondolas and  some of the larger animal enclosures and twist into the ride's only barrel roll inversion. Up and down over a few bunny hops until you sweep right. This curve leans into alternating dips up and to either side. Right, left, right, left. It's like going through a slalom ski course but much faster. Two more long arcs over the grasslands and one last 40mph launch up a small hill before you finally slow and approach the station. I know that's a wordy description but there's just so much to this coaster. The ride time is over a minute and a half, which is fairly lengthy for a coaster like this, and I loved every second of it. It's smooth but still exciting, and fast but not scary. I was smiling constantly through every moment.

I can't say enough positive things about this ride. Every bit of it is so much fun and it makes you want to ride over and over again. The lines had died down by the time our visit was coming to a close and I ended up riding Cheetah Hunt six times in that one day. Yes, it really is that good. 

Every ride at Busch Gardens is fun, and a handful of them are excellent, but Cheetah Hunt is the crown jewel that sits above the rest. If you ever find yourself at this park you absolutely must give it a try.

The first time I rode Cheetah Hunt I learned what is means to die of anticipation. Waiting for 2 hours killed me. So much so that I hardly enjoyed the ride.

After coming back several times and experiencing shorter lines I began to change my mind.

As the ride begins you are slowly pushed towards the beginning of the track. The second car has to wait for a while before being launched, the first car is nonstop from the get go. Sometimes I forget what's about to happen. It's always a shock when they launch you. 
After launching you swoop around a curve and then downward. This part of the track accelerates you to 60 mph and up a steep ascent. This is by far the best part of the ride. You then twirl around a bit unnecessarily and go down a pretty sweet drop. 

The ride is very smooth. It includes some 'heart line' rolls, which adds to the smoothness. There are three total acceleration magnets. All of them are awesome.

Overall, it's a fairly innovative coaster. It's not like any other that I've been on. The line is frickin' ridiculous though most of the time, seriously.

Great ride if you want thrill and lots of loops!
This is what I called a roller coaster ride!

You get the best feeling a night time with the wind breeze! 
Yes, you do wait a long time for it when you go on holiday breaks but I think it's worth it!
Your hands automatically wave up high and scream your lungs out. 

Definitely don't ride it if you don't really like speed and loops.

You don't wait long on non busy days and on hallow-scream.

Try out this crazy, fun ride!

I'm reviewing this ride from the eyes of a first time rider 7 year old. Is your first time at a theme park being tall enough to ride. You've waited all winter long to grow that extra two inches to be tall enough for the upcoming year. The time has finally come and you are only tall enough for one coaster, but damnit, you're getting on it. 

That coaster is Scorpion, and for this kid, it will be amazing. He will give it a 5/5 rating. For the rest of us in our young adulthoods, it's a simple ride.  All of 90 feet high, one vertical loop, a quick double vortex, and your back in the station. This ride is modeled after a ride buit in a popular 80s theme park called Boblo Island, and its age shows. That int to say it isn't worth a quick ride if you are here on the off season and the line is only 0 to 5 minutes. 

If you have kids and want to ride something with them, this is the one in this park. If you are an adult, keep it moving lol

I give scorpion a very middle-grounded 3 out of 5 stars

Far be it from me to buck the trend of giving Scorpion 3 stars. The granddaddy of all Busch Gardens coasters was surprisingly decent for a ride I almost skipped. Hell, it may have even been more fun than I remember it being when I was just a kid. Scorpion wasn't all that rough either. It's over pretty quickly, and it's small in stature, and sure it's got nothing on some of these modern coasters Parks drop over $20 million on but I'll be damned if Scorpion isn't worth a spin or two. I wouldn't wait in too long a line for it, but somehow I doubt the queue ever gets too deep. There must be a reason why Scorpion still stands while Python is long gone, right?
This is a decent roller coaster with minimal loops.  Be warned, The Scorpion is very fast.

I love the other review that advises thinking of this ride like you are a 7 year old kid.  I was probably literally 6 or 7 years old when I rode this for the first time nearly 30 years ago and let me tell you - it was a super scary, thrilling ride.  Honestly, I still find it a really scary coaster, partly because it is SO small - the cars are tiny, how close you are to the track, how much you can feel the track moving with you - all of it is REALLY intense compared to the modern super coaster.  Still a great little ride and one of the few still remaining from back in the day (RIP Python - I loved you).

When this coaster opened, it was probably state of the art. Now, there are probably better options, but it's worth a ride if the line is short!

There are some speedy turns and a loop,  but it does shake you around more than some of the newer coasters.

Scorpion is your typical, no frills, sit down steel coaster. A somewhat small lift hill immediately drops you into the rides one and only loop which is followed by one long wide left turn and a switch into a tighter "whirlpool" style turn where you get completely horizontal before coming to a stop. It's not amazing, but there is nothing wrong with it either. You can tell its an older style of coaster, but its still a smooth ride and it has a certain charm to it. I wouldn't wait in a huge line for a chance to ride this one, but it is certainly still a fun experience.
This roller coaster is decent. It's got some quick turns and a few small drops. If there is a line longer than 20 minutes, don't bother. It's not worth it!

Scorpion was my starter coaster and I love it. So much. It's old. It's rough. It's rickety. The ride is short, but it's a blast! This one is great for the littles and I personally just laugh on it. 

I'm the only one in my family that enjoys it, my kids are grown so they're waiting for the thrillers while I'm riding Scorpion. 

If you're new to coasters, have littles or just want to go back in time and feel a bit old school, Scorpion is your coaster!
This little thing is deceptively fast! Could be fun but it is so rough on you. Really bangs you up. And short which is a good thing. Not really worth doing is my opinion.

To rickety and not worth the wait. I was so hyped to ride this, but it turns out it's just a short, slow ride. If your going to Busch Gardens Tampa, just skip it. Not worth losing the time you have to go on other rides.

It is a very short ride that is over really fast. I like the loops that it takes and the upside down turns. It would be cool if it were longer. It is cool for kids to ride, but not if you have to wait 30 minutes for it.

Five stars for the thrills! It's a short ride, so if I was going off of full experience after the long wait, I would give four stars, but this ride is thrilling! 
 
It started with a 40 minute wait. It's a new ride, so well worth it for my first experience. So anyways, we get in, my teenager was like...nope! Too late! We launched forward quickly. Then backwards. My guts went jiggly inside of me and I shouted "OH NO! Oh. My. God!!!" And on we went forward, up, looped pretty slowly in the air, back down, the rest of the ride went quickly and it was a blast!

I will ride again for sure. I won't spend more than 30 minutes waiting though. There is only one car so during peak hours the wait will be pretty bad. Thankfully I have passes and we visit often for cardio and thrills!

I yawned. Drop is small. Line is long. Cars are ackward to get out of (I'm 5'5 and a size 2-4). If your wait is less than 10 mins go for it. I feel like BG was so close to having a really great coaster of this kind but missed the mark completely due to size. On a good note, I love the whole "here's a fanny pact for your stuff".  Pls do this on all rides! A drink holder would be nice ( duh on the loading dock not on the coaster).  Cheetah still is tops, it's just out and back fun!

This ride boasts the tallest coaster in FL...

It is a closed-loop ride, meaning only one car in motion at a time, which makes the wait a bit longer.  It's also a bit short, coming in at around a minute for the whole experience.

Heck of an experience though!  This ride starts at the ground without a launch hill, so assisted slingshot start is how it rolls.  You actually slowly roll upside down at the peak of this ride, getting a feeling of terror for a second as you're inverted!

Not sure how it equates to a Tiger, but it's a really fun ride and worth the wait.

At the time of this review, this is Busch Garden's latest thrill roller coaster. It does t occupy a lot of terrain and the track itself is not very long but the trick and the whole point of this ride is that it goes forward and backwards. Its fast amd there are so many twist that us hard to keep up where you are. Ride though is over fairly quick. Not bad.

This was a first time ride for both Ben and me. A heads up on the line... the ride only has 2 seats per row and there are only 9 rows so you can only at max get 18 people per ride so this line moves pretty slow compared to other rides that sit more per row. Then take in count the fast pass (or whatever they call it at Busch Gardens). 

They have an employee at the ride to tell you what line to get into to help make things go faster but you can request a specific row. We chose the front row which on this ride isn't the front the entire time. The ride goes up and then quickly goes backwards a few times. The design of this ride is like one big circle so they also cannot pre-board riders for the next ride. 

I had a giant goofball next to me (Ben) so I was pretty much laughing the whole time but I did notice that while going up and around a curve that you can get a great view of the sunset. LOL. I was like "man, where is my camera?!?!"

It was a fun ride but I couldn't imagine waiting in the long slow moving line in the summer months.

I've never been on a coaster like this before. Super huge rush accelerating in both directions! And the slow barrel roll at the top is terrifying! Honestly I wish it was bigger and faster. Fantastic ride.
Not a very long ride but it's a great ride nonetheless. Worth the wait and the slow corkscrew at the top is the best part.

Waited far longer than advertised. Busch Gardens is ruining their park with too many quick queue passes that delay the standby lines considerably. 90 min wait time end led up being close to 2.5 hours.  This will be the last year I renew my pass.
Interesting 'spin' on a roller coaster. The cars themselves spin. So you end up forward, backward and spinning around and around. It was a lot of fun.

next to sheikra this is my favorite! great new ride!!!i will say that line is long and well worth the wait.
It doesn't look like they took much time into making the inside where you wait in. They have a danky projection screen and idk it was next to effortless when they made it not cute.

Line moves VERY slowly and the queue is very misleading (just when you think that you are close to the end it opens up to a new room with greater space for the line to weave). It didn't help that after 2 hours of waiting and finally being close to the door that takes you to the loading platform the ride went down.

The newest ride to be added to Busch Gardens, Cobra's Curse is completely new concept to the park, it is a SPIN coaster. You don't go upside down, but you do spin like you're in one of the mad hatter's tea cups if you're situated properly!  

When I rode the ride the other day, the wait time was 70 minutes, however the wait was made longer by several malfunctions.  People wanted to leave and they were made to go through the entire line backwards, not allowed to go through the emergency exits or allowed to exit through the front. I think that needs to be fixed.  

The interactive portions of the ride are pretty fun. The projection Snake king is awesome. I loved the 2x I saw it, the rain and the fire aspects were nicely done. It's clear that they put quite a bit of effort into the themeing and lay out in the queue line.  The new snake fountain and artifacts are gorgeous.   While it's sad to see Tut's tomb gone (And the Experiment..so sad) this is a nice addition to the park.

While in line for this ride.. I noticed there was a lot of toddlers waiting also. We figured the ride must of been mild?!  Well a little bit but not quite.  After waiting for about 60 minutes to ride.. we arrived at the platform. We are taken up by an elevator type lift to the top and then the cars spun around as we went down some hills - then back up again - backwards .. this is when I didn't feel so good (turns my stomach). going backwards down a hill.  Yikes. The ride was over in a minute - very short ride.  I don't feel it was worth the wait but how do you know until you do it..

One of the most underrated, unexpected and thrilling rides in Busch Gardens. Almost a best kept secret. This ride has it all: twist, turns, drops, and spins. Yes, spins. You will be in for a surprise when you ride this roller coaster.

My second favorite ride at Busch Gardens goes to the Cobra's Curse. It's easily one of the most unique coasters I've ever had the pleasure to ride, and that's anywhere, not just at this park. The instant you clear the line its an experience. You don't just wait to get in a cart, sit and get your belt checked. It's a little more complex than that. You're put on a continuously moving conveyor belt where you have to quickly move over to your seat and get settled before the ride starts. There is constant supervision from park staff, but the hectic nature of this set up kind of gets the adrenaline going before the real ride even starts. 

Once you're locked in you move through a short tunnel and then you get the first good look at the FREAKING ELEVATOR in front of the giant cobra statue. I've never encountered a lift system like this before. Most rides have a chain driven lift hill, some have hydraulic launch starts, not the Cobra. Cobra's Curse has 70ft tall elevator with complicated internal mechanisms that lift a cart full of guests on a floating piece of coaster track while simultaneous lowering another piece of track to meet the next cart below. It's pretty incredible.

This ride can be split up into three stages. Stage one begins when the elevator finally reaches the top and you come face to face with that giant cobra statue. You start curving into the first drop and go through two or three big sweeping curves before you slow down. Just as you come to a full stop you hear a click and stage two begins. Your cart turns a full 180 and you start down the next hill backwards. A few more twists and turns in this new orientation and you slow once more. At this point you go up a little hill and you hear another click. Stage three. Once you come over this hill the best part of the ride starts. Huge high banked turns and twists and all the while you're SPINNING! That last click undid whatever pins kept you in place and both sets of seats (two per cart) spin wildly and independently for this last section. It's like being on a tea cup ride while simultaneously being on a roller coaster and its an experience I've never had anywhere else. 

Cobra's curse isn't the biggest ride in the park, or the fastest, but it has so much style. It is an absolute must ride if you're visiting Busch Gardens.

I love this ride! 
It's one of my favorites! 
You go pretty fast on this one and there are some twist and turns.
It's super fun and exciting. I think it's worth the wait for it!

There isn't much fear riding this ride.
Best time to ride this is on non holiday breaks and during Hallow-scream. On holiday breaks, you will wait over 70 mins. 
If you are looking for a good ride with some excitement, this is the ride!

This rollercoaster, probably cool and exciting in its heyday, seems a bit dated now against the backdrop of the more modern rides at this amusement park.

A kind of neat aspect of this is the elevator start.  Not sure it's technically a rollercoaster, as the ride consists of individual cars allowed to a long train.  

The decorations and details feel like they're peeling away, and although the ride screams ancient ruins, it feels a tad bit under maintained.

The ride spins as it falls, not my favorite with rollercoasters.  Loops and corkscrews are great with a train, but this individual car spinning is a bit much.

Fun roller coaster at Busch Gardens Tampa. While waiting in line you are inside in a building that has the feeling like the Indian Jones ride. It has AC which is a nice change during the humid summer. 
The majority of the roller coasters in the park are bigger. This one is mouse trap style and better for all ages. 
It said it was supposed to take an hour to get through the line but we got through much faster than that.
This is a serious coaster.  If you are fearless go for the front row.  It is breathtaking.  Lines are shorter than in the other parks.  Yeah you know what I am talking about.
Pretty fun ride. It is a conveyor belt of people maybe 8 wide? It did bash my head around a little. I am not sure why someone can't make a soft cushioned head rest.

Falcon's Fury was intense, but I have to say Sheikra is my favorite ride at Busch Gardens. It gives a nice view of the Tampa skyline on the way from the lift hill to the 90 degree drop. The first drop is stomach dropping good fun, even if slightly less intense than Cedar Point's Valravn, which stands 30 feet higher. Sheikra rides nearly as smoothly as Valravn, though, surprising to me as Sheikra is 11 years older and Valravn is the absolute smoothest roller coaster I've ever ridden. 
   Where Sheikra really has Valravn beat is the second drop. Dropping into a tunnel is a cool effect that Valravn really could have used to spruce up the second, shorter dive. I even got a little splash of water on one of my tunnel drops. (I rode Sheikra twice, on the right end, front and middle rows.) 
  Sheikra sure is graceful for it's unweldy width and it's force. It's like you're a giant metal ballerina pirouetting around through massive loops and turns. 
   Sheikra was my first coaster with a splashdown and it really seems like it's more for the spectators than the riders. It looks cool from the adjacent food court and there is a splash zone my mom was careful to sneak past, but while riding it doesn't seem too different from a regular brake run. 
    Sheikra is the best coaster at Busch Gardens. I really didn't expect it to blow Cheetah Hunt out of the water like it did.

This is my all time favorite ride at Busch Gardens.
Due to the stadium seating on the coaster, you are sure to get a great view, so it does not matter a whole lot where you sit.
This is tall ride, around 200ft high and so if you do not like heights, then you may want to give it a miss but the view is spectacular at the top.
The 90degree vertical drop is fantastic. The 4 second delay in the drop at the top, really gets the adrenalin going. 
The ride is smooth and fast. My only complaint is that I wish it had at least another inversion and was a little longer but they are only minor grips on what is a excellent ride experience.

Great ride...but the concept is better than the execution. Actually, let me say that differently.  If you are from central Florida, and this park is what you have access too, this ride is a 10 out of 5 stars. It's amazing in that sense. 

However, if you are like me, and have been on 140+ coasters in your lifetime, then you already know, an amazing hook, does not make an amazing ride.  There are two drops on this coaster, and they are both great drops, one of them bordering on excellent, and there is a lot of power in the first diving loop. However, outside of those elements, the rest of the ride is just, well, kind of just there. 

This is to no fault of the engineers. I mean seriously the elements are great, but unfortunately because of the uniqueness of the actual trains on this thing the layout can't be too much more than it already is. 

If you we're to ask me is it a reason to come to this park, my answer would weigh heavily on how much coaster experience you have.  If we are talking Florida coasters only, then it is a top 10 coaster. If we are talking the county, then it isn't even on my top 25. If you've never been on a coaster this will make you poop on yourself from fear. You decide. 

SheiKra is a great ride and should you find yourself in Tampa Bay, it's not to be missed. I give SheiKra, a 4 out of 5 stars

You must ride this. I demand it. It also does not matter where you sit, although the front row gives you more of an "OMG I'm gonna fall out" dangle. But sometimes the wait for that can be ridiculous. SheiKra is a very large coaster and the line usually moves quickly since they have several cars going at once and each can hold 24 people. It's not a ride with a long duration so people are on and off pretty quickly. The first drop is awesome and you get breathtaking views of all of Tampa when you get to the top. The second drop is really awesome too and you are whipped up and over a water area which is pretty cool. The thing that I love most about this ride is the size of the track. It's huge! Very very smooth coaster and a must ride if you are in the park. My friend hates it, but I always get her to ride it....and she laughs and smiles every time we do :)
As someone who absolutely hates drops, I still loved this ride; the drops are quick and there's so much to look at when you're up there that you don't even notice the height until you drop

Stopped at the Gwazi Park for the final night of Kenetix.  Let me just say that when Busch Gardens puts on a party, they REALLY put a party on.  There was a packed audience, there were top 40 songs, singing, dancing and a little girl balancing on a man's forehead -HOLY CRAP!  

The singers were amazing, FRANK has an awesome, soulful voice! I liked this year's version better than last, but each year just keeps improving.  Thanks for the wonderful Summer Night's Programing, Busch Gardens! Keep up the good work!
Super super short ride. I liked the 90 degree drops, but other than that it isn't worth the wait.

This ride was awesome. The 90 degree angle is definitely had be at a shock and was extremely fun. While in busch gardens you definitely need to try it if you like roller coasters. The only issue you may have is that there may be a long wait. But it definitely is worth it. !

I used to not like Sheikra that much, as I felt like it was kind of short, but I realized that there are so many cool things about it. The water braking is super nifty as is the first big loop. You also get to skate by the employee parking lot during the last loop back to station, so I always like to give a wave and a thank you if I see anyone.

Best ride in Busch Gardens. Hands down. 
It's exciting and thrilling. You experience two high altitude plummets, one initially, one that goes underground. Epic. Don't leave the park without riding it.

I absolutely loved this ride! 

We got there at 10am, this area didn't open til 1030am. Ride problems caused us to wait til 11am for them to open the line. Ugh! ... BUT it was worth it because the line here gets long. Glad we waited it out because they solved the problem quickly. 

We also had 'quick queue' which you MUST get ... so we used our quick queue on it immediately after we rode it through the main line since we were at the front of the line. Two times in a row!

Another fun part...At the end of the day I stood where the water sprays onlookers! So worth it and a nice way to experience the roller coaster and the bystander versions of Sheikra!

For roller coaster lovers, it's hard not to love that first drop.  SheiKra's biggest claim to fame is the seemingly endless pause before the riders plunge down the first big drop.  The rest of the ride goes a little quickly, but the second major drop sneaks up on you and is pretty good as well.  Overall, really fun ride.  I've never been on fire to ride in the first row, but I am sure it would be really intense.

Scary good in front. But tuck in your VIP pass so it doesn't fly away if you have one. And my 3D glasses from Howl o Scream almost flew off but it was a fun way to see the ride in a trippy visiony way.

Definitely a rush and plenty of whooshes.

Sheikra is definitely my favorite ride at Busch Gardens, probably my favorite coaster I've ever been on and I started riding coasters in 2011. I know it looks scary, but if you have done roller coasters like Goliath at Six Flags Over Georgia that go up 200 feet, you can do this. It's a very intense ride, they hold you about 4 to6 seconds before they let you go. So much fun! The 2nd drop, which I think is 130 ft., isn't bad either, you then go across water, with the back wheels splashing the area behind. If you stand close to the coaster, you will get wet. so after that the ride is pretty much finished. This is definitely a rollercoaster that you have to ride when at Busch Gardens. Don't be afraid to ride, it because it is a really fun and intense ride. I could ride this ride multiple times. Overall, Sheikra is a coaster you have to do and it's a fun roller coaster.

I rode this ride 6 times in 1 day. 4 times back to back. You must get on the front row of this ride. It's a different feeling on the front row. You get to see what you're about to go through. I love this ride.

They don't let you chose your seating row. So if you are in the front row they just let the VIP's come sit in the front row. May as well kiss your time goodbye. We waited 45 minutes to get in the staging area and another 30 waiting to get on the ride. Disrespecting 100's for 1-2 people.

SheiKra is the roller coaster I always save for last. It's all about the drop. Waiting in the longest line to experience the front row is a must. The worst part is the ascension to 200 feet. This is where my head spins with regret -every time. At the top of the hill you can see most of Tampa, which is beautiful and terrifying. The train pauses slightly before it hangs the first row over the edge of the 90 degree angled track. Not knowing exactly when SheiKra is going to "drop" you down is intense. Four to six seconds later you feel as though you're helplessly falling while reaching a speed of 70 mph! There are turns and loops and another drop. The second drop isn't as scary but thrilling nonetheless. SheiKra is only a couple of minutes long but provides an exhilarating rush. I always get right back in line afterward. 

One of the best rides at Busch Gardens!

Awesome, scary, and fun ride. I kept my eyes open with you are held hanging high in the sky looking down before you drop. The drop was crazy with the wind blowing. It is a favorite ride at Busch Gardens as the wait was 70 minutes when we went to visit. This ride is not for the faint of heart and I did punk out and close my eyes at some points.

A pretty good ride, especially with that first drop. The best and scariest way to experience SheiKra is at night, in the dark, front row. For sure.

Just be careful after the ride. You have to walk down a spiral staircase directly after getting off, and if you get dizzy like I do, you might trip on the way down!

My only complaint is that SheiKra is too short. Now that Falcon's Fury will be at Busch Gardens (if they ever open it), SheiKra's drop looks smaller in comparison.

If you are a roller coaster junkie then you will love this ride!Just sitting there before you drop just makes you get the chills AND makes a fews seconds feel like an hour.When you finally drop your in shock and awe. Would definatley reccomend!

Hey hey hey.... this is my FAVORITE ride at Busch Gardens! There is a long Ascension and 2 steep drops. At the first drop the ride pauses for what seems like mins before quickly dropping riders.. and then on to the remainder of the ride. Very smooth and fast! Ride this one.

Man oh man....What a bad $&& roller coaster!!!!  We rode this beast two times in a row. The second time, me and my family tried not to smile or laugh on the first drop; which is almost impossible!!!  We tried to do this for the sake of a funny family photo :D  you absolutely have to ride this if you are in Busch Gardens!

Oh. My. Gosh. 

As a rollercoaster newb I've been on a few lately just to get my feet wet. We went for the pass holder quick queue for Tigris today, BUT it wasn't operating, so my friend was like "woooo SheiKra" and I was like "wooo! No!" Anyways. She won, and so on we went. 

Today is a Wednesday and we came at opening and guess what? Zero line. So that also meant that my first time riding SheiKra was also my opportunity to ride in the front. I was terrified. 

I asked the little dude buckling us in if it's scary and I'm gonna die. He basically shrugged it off, and I made the Rocky reference "k, then. If she dies she dies?" Yes. That's it. If I die I die. 

On we went to the top. I literally almost died just rolling. And then. Then they hang you over the edge and my friend pops off "here we go! 5,4,3,2..." And I was like...you sound like our personal trainer but it dropped us before I could say anything except the F word, so we just went with that. The initial drop was the worst part but the rest was magnificent. The second drop was also intense but not like the first. 

I'm glad I worked myself up to SheiKra, but I really wasn't prepared to ride it this early in my coaster career! I'm about this life now! Next time we will do Kumba.  And maybe Tigris if they have their crap straight.

Ever go bungee jumping? Me neither, but I imagine this ride is as close to that feeling as it's safely possible to achieve.

The idea is this: take a car of 24 people, hang it on the edge of a 90 degree vertical drop, and let go!  Instantly, you're falling and weightless and pulling g-forces as you again climb into a loop and up a hill to drop vertically, yet again.  

You whip around the landscape of the Southwest portion of the park to end the ride by splashing bystanders with rooster-tail water spouts.

A ride all too quick is the only thing, for me, that keeps this from a 5-star rating.  Exhilarating!

SheiKra is definitely the best ride at Busch Gardens.  If you enjoy a free fall experience, then you would love this!  They will keep you hanging at the top and drop you with no mercy.  The front row would be the best to experience the fear.  I actually enjoyed the fantastic view of Tampa bay between the initial climb and the first drop.
It should be considered torture how they hang you there for 5 seconds! What a drop. Glad I finally conquered my fears and did it. Fantastic!

Very smooth and exhilarating ride!

It holds you at the top of the first drop then you fall unexpectedly like a drop zone! 

If you have been to the Williamsburg Busch Gardens it is similar to the griffin. The main difference is this one has a splash zone area. The kids love getting soaked but be aware if you don't want to get splashed, the wave goes quick a distance.

Probably my favorite roller coaster in Florida (not that there are that many to choose from...) I love the adrenaline rush that you get as the coaster clinks up the initial climb. I especially love when they dangle you above the close to 90 degree angle drop. My absolute favorite thing to do on this ride is make my whole body go limp right before the drop so that it feels like you are free falling! For a second there your whole body feels weightless. I definitely recommend trying that out! 

My only wish is that the ride were longer or maybe had just one more drop :)

I'm terrified of roller coasters, but I still somehow gather the courage to ride them. My first time in Busch Gardens was this past Friday for Yelp's Howl-O-Scream. I always avoided any Busch Garden trips as I had no desire to go on roller coasters, but after a good convincing from my friend, I decided to give it a try. I remember a few years ago when I heard about Sheikra opening I thought to myself - I would never get on that! 90 degree drop? You can't pay me to ride ride that! But guess what? I rode it, for free, and it was AWESOME. The only shitty part was that literally right when it took off, it started pouring. Not light sprinkles of rain, I'm talking massive freezing drops of rain. Hitting me in the face at lightning speed. It sucked, my eyes were closed the entire time. I only opened them right at the top of the 90 degree drop (they leave you hanging for what seems like eternity). My heart felt like it was going to stop lol. But it was over so quickly, and once it was done I was sad about it! I actually loved it! I can't wait to go back to Busch Gardens!

It was a weekday and the front of Busch Gardens was slammed with people. We eventually made our way to the back after waiting 30ish minutes for another ride. To our surprise there was no line. You read that correct NO LINE. We rode the front and the back in under 20 minutes. INSANITY. We were in a tight schedule and had free tickets so it was a wonderful treat to not only get to ride it once but twice and still have time for BBQ.
Ok ride but it is not worth the ride because the first drop is not even that bad so if you are new to rides this would be good

I loved this dive coaster!!  We arrived early to the park and make sure we rode this coaster first.. since there was no line. After putting my little purse in a locker nearby we were clear to ride it.  The front seat is a must !!!     What a great ride.. two dives too. What a great coaster..  its a must ride people!

I hate this ride. I have a fear of heights and it takes everything in me not to have a panic attack while I am on Sheikra. When I am going up the nearly vertical lift hill I genuinely question the life choices I have made that put me in that moment. When you reach the top it is so high that you can practically see Canada. Some people might enjoy the view, but all I can think is "I am going to die". Then as if they haven't tormented you enough the sick designers of this coaster have another surprise in store for you. They dangle you off the edge of the first drop. After what feels like 20 minutes you are finally released to plunge almost straight down. One thing is certain: I will be screaming louder than a 12-year-old girl at a Justin Bieber concert. It's at this point when I realize that I'm actually enjoying myself. Once the ride is over I'm tempted to go on it again and the whole sick cycle starts all over.

So, Sheeka finally rode Sheikra.

Probably one of the scariest rides ever! I was terrified of getting on this ride as I'd heard of the height and drop. You go straight up to the point you feel you can't go any further, then you hang precariously over an edge. Which is all I remember because after that I became so afraid that I shut my eyes as tight as possible. There were some loops. We were speeding. I was splashed with water. I had a heart attack. Then it was over. Never riding again, but the thrill seeker in me knows that isn't true. I love coasters, and this joins the list of one of my faves.

Wait to get a spot in the first row. It's worth it. 

As a Busch Gardens virgin, I was pretty naive to any of the park rides. I had heard about SheiKra but mainly chatter about how it has a pretty scary drop and used to have a floor. Basically, I was unprepared for what was coming my way. Not until after we slowly climbed 200 feet in the air and were tilted downwards to take off did it hit me... This was going to be one wild ride!

Why the front row? That first drop feels so much more exhilarating when there is nothing between you and the ground below. From there, we went flying down and around. It was nighttime so even harder to see where we were going (in other words, all the more fun!). 

Like Falcon's Fury, I am ever impressed by how comfy this ride really is. No need to worry about your head getting banged around or the harness poking into your body. Once you get a hang of the track, you can have some fun with the photos. If you're anything like me, your first take will reflect pure terror.

Never have I ever been on a roller coaster and thought, "Wow, this is excellently engineered," as I fly through the air at 70mph - until SheiKra!

This is the smoothest roller coaster I have ever ridden, and I've been on quite a few in my day! Whereas some coasters are known for jostling you around or even smashing your head into the sides of the shoulder restraints, SheiKra is a pure joy to ride, smooth and effortless. I'm not kidding when I say I mentally praise its engineering the entire 2:20 I'm on it!

The "splashdown" element about halfway through the ride is so fun. You don't feel a single drop of water, but those on the ground walking too close will find themselves soaked as you pass!

This coaster is also the first dive coaster to feature a true 90° drop! And it. is. BREATHTAKING! I refuse to ride anywhere but the front row. Creeping up to the "edge" of the track before the drop and hovering completely horizontally above the ground is an amazing experience. The anticipation wells perfectly before the plummet and kicks off a truly memorable and exhilarating experience!

I want to ride it right now!!!!
One of the best roller coasters at Busch Gardens but it is definitely too short.  It would suck waiting an hour to go on this ride.

*Click, click, click, click, click, click*
That's the sound of you going 200 feet in the air. Inch by inch.

You can hear every single click as you face the sky and get to the very top, take a curve...get to the end of the track....FACE STRAIGHT DOWN - AND STOP. Just hang there...looking down - or out over Tampa Bay if you care for a decent view. 

It feels like 5 minutes at least you are just hanging there. It's probably a few seconds. But I swear to you my palms are sweaty as I write this.

Then you drop straight down - 90 degrees. It's about a 2 minute ride - much shorter than the others at Busch Gardens. 

I have never been front row - and might never do it - but you still get a crazy view as the seats are "stadium seating". Other than the initial stop - mid air suspension - and drop...there isn't much else to this coaster unfortunately. 

The colors (I touch on this in other coaster reviews) are pretty blah too. They have one section where you fly over people walking on the path through the park, and that's pretty cool - not so much for the passengers since you don't see anyone, but for the folks walking under it.

All in all I'd say do it! It was the first dive coaster in the US and that looong ride up / quick dive down is worth the wait.

This ride is is definitely a ride where seating is key. I sat in the back of the coaster so when it comes time to the big drop everyone hyped up you just have a few moments to look around Tampa with a good view. But the wait at the drop was a lot longer than expected so being in the front would have been insane at a stand still for such a long period of time. The wait time was surprisingly fast I got there at the perfect time being it only took about fifteen minutes or less to get on the ride. Overall the ride was fun and fast but on a day where the wait time is a hour plus wait I wouldn't pick this ride.

This is Ben's favorite ride at Busch Gardens and I had previously been on it before so knew itbwas a fun ride to go on. 

Pro tip: If you are on the shorter side like I am (5ft) then ride in the front... I know, I know some people don't like the front but this ride is set up like stadium seating and the middle and back rows are higher up so us shorter people have to basically jump up to get in them and over the leg harness which is just a pain. The back row is way too far up for me to do alone and feel like a little kid being picked up to get into it. 

Honestly, the front row wasn't anymore heart racing than the other two rows but but you get a great view of everything when you are there. The ride slowly takes you up to the top and then it lets you sit there for a few seconds before it drops you. The coaster goes in a little on the drop too which makes you feel even more weightless. 

The ride is short of time compared to others but super fun.

Holy Crap! Scary and thrilling at the same time - I've got an extreme fear of heights and the fact that this coaster stops at the top of a 90 degree drop for about 20 seconds (which feels like a lifetime) - scared me half to death. But the thrill of the coaster itself was worth it. Just do it!

SheiKra is THE Mac-Daddy coaster within Busch Gardens, and in my opinion within the entire state of Florida.

Nothing can quite compare with the sensation of being strapped in and hauled up 200 feet in the air, and then dangled over the edge of the first drop for an agonizing few seconds while looking down at the ground below you. Yeah baby, this ride is intense!

I love sitting in the front row on SheiKra and savoring the delightful torture of looking straight down the 90 degree drop before the brakes release and the car drops.......straight down at about 70 mph.

From there it's a high-speed series of loops, twists, and drops before the splashdown finale when you finally catch your breath. This is a high-speed, adrenaline-pumping experience for thrill seekers.

Oh, and for a totally different and terrifying experience, try this ride at night when you can't see what is happening and your imagination gets the better of you!
Awesome ride. Best part is when it stops when it's about to drop. The wait is never long because the car holds so many people. 100% worth the  5 minute wait. We went on it 5 times.

There is nothing more intense than the feeling you get as you are sucked into your seat while quickly ascending this relatively tall roller coaster. Then it swings you around, with complete silence you get to admire the view for a short time. Before you know it, you're dangling above a 200+ foot vertical drop. Just when you think the ride is stuck.... WHOOSH! You're flying.

After the first drop, there is a zero G roll that is just insane. Honestly the rest is kind of a blur, but there is one more close to vertical drop. 

The only downside is that the ride is a total of about 2 minutes long.

This is probably the best, extremely thrilling ride that will have your heart pumping fast no matter how brave you are. That feeling that you get when you are dangling looking at the drop that is to come and anticipating the second you are released, is second to none. I truly love this smooth, fast ride. It is well designed and you always come out of there accelerated and shaking of emotions.

Not going to lie, I had a TON of anxiety while waiting in line for this coaster. I knew the drop was intense and I tend to get anxious waiting in line for ANY coaster, regardless of the fact that I always end up loving them. 

As usual, once I made it through the ride, I loved it!

For a coaster, the seats were pretty comfy and entire track was relatively smooth. Rather than being a long train of cars, this vehicles are simply 3 rows of about  8-10 seats. What's nice about that is that whether you are in the front or back you have a great view as they utilize stadium seating!

As noted, the first drop is the most jaw dropping part of the ride as you rapidly make your way up the lift hill, get to the drop point and as you are just far enough over the edge to have a great view of the ground below, you STOP before a nice drop down. The pause is just long enough to really get your heart rate up! The rest of the coaster is a ton of fun with great drops and loops. 

My #1 favorite coaster at Busch Gardens, for sure! Definitely worth a ride (or two)!

Everyone has their preference as far as where to sit in the cart on a roller coaster, but this is the one ride at Busch Gardens where I strongly encourage you to wait the extra few minutes for the front row. 

Sheikra has an incredibly unique design and is such a fun ride, it's my third favorite at this park. Sheikra is a floor-less dive coaster and that means a few things. First, sitting at 200ft above the ground it's pretty tall. Second, the dive part means the first hill takes you into a full 90 degree drop straight down at 70 mph. Third, the floor-less describer is pretty literal. The carts are designed so they hold you from behind and even though they are mounted to the track underneath, they're is nothing directly below your feet. It's like being on a suspended roller coaster but there's nothing above you. In the heat of the moment it really is like you're just flying through the air held by nothing. If it weren't for being able to see the track you'd think you were sitting in a magic chair, which is especially true if you're on the outside edge of this giant eight wide, three deep wing of a roller coaster cart.  

My reason for encouraging front row is apparent when you get to the top of that first hill. Right before you drop the cart stops for about three seconds, and if you're in the front row you're seat is stopped over the crest of that hill. It's an insane rush literally hanging from a shoulder harness 200ft in the air right before a true vertical drop at highway speeds. This goes into a full loop and then up a smaller yet still impressive second hill. Two more curves and then a dive into a piece of track nestled in a pond that spews water out both sides (onto to other park patrons if their not careful) before coming to a stop. 

This is an incredible thrill ride and ranks among my favorite coasters of all time. It is an absolute necessity to ride Sheikra!

Good times. We got the annual pass - good for entry to the park all year long. We upgraded to free parking too. The coasters are fantastic! The park was fairly empty for both days we were there. We ate at the Zambia Smokehouse. For $13 and change I had ribs, chicken, and beef brisket. More than I could eat, and it was delicious! Buy the souvenir cup, and get free Ice-water, or .99 refills all day of sodas, or icees. 

The park was easy to get into, and easy to get out of. Sheikra was the best coaster. She won't disappoint. Looking forwar to booking the specialty tours. Theres enough of them to last me all year. Check them out before you come. As several of these require a reservation.

See you there!

It was one of the worst decision I have taken in my life, going to Busch garden. It is way behind Disney resorts and the universal studio. Despite the fact that you have to wait almost an hour to get in a game, the game will last for almost 5 minutes. I stepped in a line for almost one hour and then they said the game is temporary closed!!! 
Will never recommend this garden to any one .
Great night time acrobatics and fireworks show.

Sensationeller Achterbahn Park mit Safari Ausflug.
Die Bahnen sind alle sehr gut ausbalanciert und abwechslungsreich. Die Wartezeiten halten sich im gesunden Rahmen, sofern man unter der Woche dort ist. Der Eintritt und die Parkgebühr sind angemessen, wenn auch die Preise für Getränke und Essen wie üblich zu teuer sind. Man kann dort gut und gerne einen ganzen Tag verbringen. Es wird nie langweilig. Die Cheetah Hunt fährt gemütlich durch den angrenzenden Tierpark und man bekommt schonmal einen Eindruck von den dort lebenden Tieren. Gegen einen geringen Aufpreis kann man eine Jeep-Safari buchen und Giraffen füttern. Ein unvergessliches Erlebnis! Der Park ist auf jeden Fall einen Besuch wert.

This place is extremely family friendly.  I have lots and lots of little ones in my family, and the kids areas are great! There's a sesame street section, and a dino section, and the zoo is just wonderful, especially now that they've added in Jungala.  It's fun for older people too, the rides are fun and there's a lot of really entertaining, educational shows and services.
Horrible, all dirty, over population of animals, I felt horrible about the conditions they held the poor animals, no organization at all, in a few words messy, dirty, chaotic

Ok!!! Where do I starts??? I have been to Busch Garden many times but this was my first time to Busch Garden for the Christmas Town event!!! 

My hubby n I planned the whole weekend trip with our children.. We got room at the Hyatt place.. We were really excited to see some cool Christmas stuff.. We were willing to paid the full price too but glad we didn't.( groupon offered half off tickets) thanks groupon:). 

I loved the lights!!! It was really pretty!! My children was looking forward to some snow fun but was disappointed in how small the actual area really were.. The waiting was crazy.. You get a beeper.. Most waiting time was 45 to 1 hour n 20 mins..the event itself was 5 hours!!!.. So you can imagine there is not much to do if you have to wait around!!! After 20 mins, we left snow play area.. Didn't have time.. We also bypassed the Santa house cuz over an hour wait!!! Other people was complaining as they waited over an hour n not been call in to see Santa himself:(.

Other than that the roller coaster.. No waiting time.. My 12 years old son got on n off rather fast.. He got to go on all the rides that he couldn't during normal hours.. He was happy:)

We took family pictures with those photographers.. Only one was in the system.. How disappointing!!! N we left at closing time!!! 

Not worth it if you are paying full price!!!

Hmmm....ride roller coasters all day or go to lame-ass Disney...is there really a question of what you'd rather do?

Busch Garden is hands-down the best amusement park I've been to. It is far superior to Six Flags. All of the Six Flags locations I have visited seem to have this underlying theme of "wholesome redneck family fun," and they always seem to have either obscure country stars or former American Idol contestants playing in the park on the day I visit. Busch Gardens doesn't rely on crappy singers...why? Because they have a collection of top-notch roller coasters, water rides featuring the finest of   Tampa Bay area's teenage girls in wet t-shirts and lots of beer. It's true...you know those old men hanging out by the Tidal Wave have an ulterior motive. The food offered here is also surprisingly good for a theme park...they actually have a very nice restaurant where you can sit down and pretend to be classy. Oh, and I think they have something to do with animals...like a zoo or something? But, really, who cares about that....roller coasters rock!
Best place ever for have a lot fun and different things to do. The Falcon Fury in my opinion is the best drop in the park

I love and have always loved the mix of thrill rides and animals in this park.  My only real complaint is that the rides tend to break down quite a bit which leads me to believe they need better maintenance.

Just returned from my day in the park. I have not been to Busch Gardens for at least 20 years.
(I have vacationed yearly with my family at Walt Disney world.)  As I had a few days in Tampa I thought I would check out Busch gardens for the day. 
Few thoughts
We ordered tickets online and glad we did for the cost savings.  I Thought admission was on the high end as many kiosks and snack venues were closed and a very limited amount of entertainment available.
Staff-- at the animal exhibits the animal keepers were awesome.  At the tiger exhibit - we had a great experience with Jody. She was so interesting and we learned a great deal .
In the parks most staff appeared less than happy to be there and did not engage the guests. Many were not able to answer questions regarding how to get to a particular attraction. We took the train ride around the park and were less than impressed with our conductor.  Guests on the train did not appreciate the "humor" and would have far more appreciated a narrative of the animals we were seeing.  Election jokes were definitely a taboo topic based on yesterday's results.

I recall seeing more entertainers and a far more exciting atmosphere.  ..... I know it has been many years but overall I was disappointed  - and my family that joined (first timers)were even more so as our day did not live up to their expectations

Ok, this is an amusement park, so you don't expect the food to be very good.  However, the food at Busch Gardens may be the worst of any amusement park I have ever been to.  After that everything is excellent.  Great rollercoasters.  Wonderful people working all over the park.  Really well done animal habitats and safari rides.  Finally, I have never seen a better rain out policy. We were there for two days and it rained both afternoons and all night.  We were given full credit to use our Quick Que (fast track at other parks) on another visit.

Some of the best, most thrilling, make-me-scream roller coasters I've ever ridden have been here. Plus, there's a wildlife refuge so when you don't feel like roller-coastering you can go look at hippos.

Great experience! Sesame Street Safari was PERFECT for our 17 month old.  The parent swap option at the roller coasters allowed me and my husband to enjoy the roller coasters. Lunch with Elmo was AMAZING! The food was yummy and our son had a great time, including our picture with Elmo and Zoe, which was included in the cost for the lunch.  

The "Zoo" portion was beautiful and I really feel we got our money's worth.  Can't wait to go back!

We opted to buy annual passes to the park as we live close-by and can visit frequently. I may have been disillusioned as a Disney passholder and feel that this park does not live up to others. The entrance of the park is a bit scrambled and the 'Zone B' ticketing area needs an employee present at the line to prevent line jumping due to the confusion of the line set up. The park itself is very segmented and most of the day is spent walking in circles trying to find the right way to get to a ride. Maybe this is intentional to make you feel like the park is bigger than it is? The roller coasters there are fun and the animal areas are well kept and clean. The kids area is small but my children love it. I feel like the food options are somewhat limited but that is the norm at amusement parks. We have fun when we go but I would not want to travel to Tampa solely to visit this park.

I can gladly say if the option of watching paint dry whilst listening to "I want my baby back" by Jimmy Cross or go to Busch Gardens for the day. I would gladly choose the paint drying option and Jimmy Cross music. Busch gardens has to be the biggest waste of time since Tim Tebows attempt at an NFL career. 

To start some roller coaster were literally closed at 1pm. Ok well that's awesome due to the fact they have a total of 6 rides. Secondly, if you want to see animals and go on maybe 2 rides then yeah go ahead and waste 90$ for the day. Thirdly, everything in the gift shop and markets were absurdly over priced, Busch Garden already robs you of your time and money, least they can do is reduce some prices. 

The "roller coasters" are more so geared to 9 year olds, a new born baby may actually be safe on these "roller coasters" while I don't advise to bring your baby on roller coasters, any young child wanting to overcome their fear of roller coasters this is the place for you! 

Alright so I wouldn't waste my money ever again at this garbage amusement park, some roller coasters were closed, and all the roller coaster are not thrill seeking at all. Save the 90$, take the kids to the Buccaneers practice for free, get some autographs, grab dinner and call it a day. PASS ON BUSCH GARDENS.

Never had a bad time here. While on a ride, I let my wallet slip out on a 2011 senior trip to Busch Gardens. I was given a food voucher thanks to a staff member who referred me to the service desk. They found and shipped my wallet to my house a few weeks after I was home. Friendly and helpful staff.

I went today for my birthday hoping to spend the day riding rides, eating delicious food and getting drunk! (Turning 27) 

We got here early to make sure there was not long lines and as we entered it was a complete mess to get through the ticketing section. No organization whatsoever. We wanted to get a snack before riding the rides and ALL the concession stands were CLOSED?!?! why open the park If the food is not open and ready??? 

Then we find a bar that is open... we grab a whiskey and she fills it the smallest amount.... and the margaritas were low on the cup. I asked her to fill it a little more and she gave me attitude. 

Finally.... hoping to make the day better we get food to eat. We can hear all the employees loud as hell, cursing and fighting behind the kitchen. How trashy. I wish I went to Disney. 
Don't recommend this park for adults, especially for their birthday. Not worth the money or time.
terrible customer service at guest services. as a teacher, i am appalled at the horrible service. wow. never coming here again.

I had to seriously think hard when deciding to give 3 or 4 stars, and I will break down why. 

Pros: 
1. Great variety of roller coasters- REAL roller coasters, not those mediocre ones. Cheetah Hunt was really neat. Loved the rapid acceleration at different intervals throughout the ride. Sheikrah also rocked! Incredible ride! My husband really enjoyed Falcon's Fury, too! If you love roller coasters, you will love Busch Gardens. 
2. Affordable and well-kept. It was a good deal and worth the money. 
3. The animals and wildlife areas were very nice, and the park is large enough to keep you busy and entertained. Unfortunately we got rained out before getting to ride most of the rides, but they looked good. 

Cons: 
1. TOO MANY RIDE CLOSURES! Kumba & Stanley Falls flume ride were closed, and the Congo River ride failed to impress. We barelyyyyyy got wet. The ride needed more water falls to provide opportunities to get wet, and maybe some theming. It was visually boring. The Tidal Wave ride had been closed permanently, leaving a serious lack of water rides. It's Florida and it's HOT, so a couple of good water rides are in order. Tried to get on the sky ride and it was closed. 10 minutes later as we were walking we saw people riding it so that was annoying. 
2. The park has areas with rides that have been permanently closed for years, but nothing has been done with the space (Gwazi and Tidal Wave). From a PR standpoint it just doesn't look good. Tear it down or open it up, but don't just leave it sitting there. It's kinda sad seeing a beautiful wooden coaster abandoned :(
3. Not all areas of the park are open at opening time. They stagger the opening of the areas, which is a little annoying. The entire park should be open and accessible when be park opens its doors. I guess it's their way of controlling costs and if it keeps ticket prices reasonable, I guess I can't complain too much. 
4. Hours of operation are limited. Wish they were open a little later into the evening and a little earlier in the morning. Again, possible cost control and I can deal with it as long as tickets prices remain reasonable. 

Overall, I will return, but I really hope they will improve on some of the cons...

Absolutely not worth the money, they charge 105,-- plus tax per person at the entrance, untill noon the weather was fine, nevertheless almost every rollercoaster was closed (for example cheetah hunt, cobras curse) because they had mechanical difficulties, and they couldn't tell us, how long they would be closed. At afternoon then rainy weather, then they closed every attraction, even the train that surrounds the property. At least we could only ride one rollercoaster the hole day.

Super fun! My favorite time of year to go to Busch Gardens is for Howl-o-Scream. 

You can ride all the roller coasters at night, and still hit up the haunted houses for a bit of extra scary. 

And their roller coasters are awesome! They have probably the best group of coasters in Florida. I could ride Shiekra all day.

Wife and I were there for our 16th anniversary I gave 1 stars because some of the attractions were ok. However the only thing that went smooth was Friday checking into the hotel. Once we got to park it seemed the mind started spinning trying to figure where to go and what to do with the passes that was never instructed to me and the park employees didn't seem to know the right directions also sending us all over the place wasting our first day did better shopping then enjoyment. My wife and I argued on our anniversary from such a crappy vacation it was not worth the money and we will never return. Then Sunday we went on a safari truck thing wife and I enjoyed feeding the giraffes and all but that seemed to the main attraction and excitement  I paid $800 for 4 different safari animals seems I paid this much for feeding the giraffes and fuel to run the truck. Again the only thing this day being Sunday that was good was the day we checked out and went to the Clearwater beach that we didn't have time to stay just travel there to see the beach because I wasted my time at a safari and fuel show. Sorry to be so honest but if i were able to get half of my money returned not just for the money but because it truly was not worth the full amount I paid.
My favorite place to go in Tampa! I love how close it is to Mel's hot dogs and also love that they have great deals on Groupon!

DON'T GET THE ALL DAY MEAL VOUCHER.  Busch Gardens clearly is only interested in taking as much of your money as they possibly can.  With a great roller coaster, Sheikra, and a so-so one Cheetah, the rest are lack luster and aging.  We have multiple annual passes to several of the Orlando area parks and thought we'd venture out to Tampa for a day in Busch Gardens.  Desiring a hassle-free experience, we bought the passes, the line hopper ultimate passes, along with the all day meal plan (Unlimited food and beverage).  The meal plan, we mostly wanted so we didn't have to drop $5 an hour on bottled waters or cokes.  Well, after several failed attempts to find a kiosk or stand that would honor the voucher, we eventually learn that you can only use it in the actual cafeteria/restaurants which are limited to one per park area.  These cafeterias have the longest lines because they serve full meals.  ...so for refreshments, this $30 option is a total waste.  We saw one such cafeteria with a twenty minute wait in the food area, but no one in the refreshment section, nor at the checkout counter; we proceeded to grab a bottle of water and see the cashier - but were immediately 'SCOLDED' in front of everyone and told we needed to wait in the food line.  The amount of time they spent trying to dominate us and embarrass us in front of others, they could have just said, have a great day!  --- there's no transaction that takes place otherwise, you simply show your band and walk out.  -- but instead, the cashier and the manager seemingly got off on a power trip by forcing us to put down the water and smirkingly instructed us to follow their rules for no other purpose than there being 'rules'.  What a joke.  Worst customer service I've experienced in ANY theme park.

Love this place. Been coming here for decades.
My daughter cant wait to go back!
The pricing, on line, is fair, the rides are great fun & we had a ball!!
Love the water rides, just bring a change of clothing...you will not dry off as quickly as you think you will...ha ha ha!!
Parking is easy, pricey but easy & the tram runs every 3-5 minutes!

Biggest reason I am writing this.  We did the park yesterday, line were ok, few rides down, overall good experience.  But assume this is just simply a product of seasonal business.
