 Fazit: insgesamt sehr empfehlenswert, auch wenn der Preis erst mal ein wenig schockiert :-)

With regard to parking, there are over 5000 parking lots available. General parking costs $20 while preferred parking (spots closer to the entrance of Busch Gardens Tampa Bay) costs $26. After we parked our car at the general parking area, we took a short walk to the tram station which takes guests to Busch Gardens. Probably a 2 minutes ride. The frequency of the trams were pretty good (less than 5 minutes) and soon, we were entering into Busch Gardens. Take note that the parking areas are on the opposite side of the road of Busch Gardens. The tram enters Busch Gardens via an underground pass. So don't be surprised if the signs direct you away from Busch Gardens.

All day dining is the only way to go! Also if you get a season pass and do the EZ pay, it is only 13/month! Worth every penny. We go regularly just to walk around and hang out. Beware of ride shut downs...they happen often. Which if you are there a lot it isn't a big deal, but if you go only once per year I'm sure it is aggravating.

Awful experience. Everything costs. $89 for their version of fast pass per person. Waited in 3 different lines for roller coasters and all 3 broke down. Then it stormed for 2 hours so everything shut down. Once everything opened it was a 70 minute wait. I got to ride nothing. Lots and lots of walking. No way to know wait times till you walk to the ride.

I'm a pass holder and bought a fun card for my daughter and her friend.  The friend is not interested in going.  I called customer service.  I know on the card it says that the cards are non-refundable or transferable.  So I am losing out on $110 that I just paid after Christmas because it was a Christmas present and it's very upsetting losing out on all that money.  I unfortunately cannot ride roller coasters, thus my daughter has to ride alone.  As far as I'm concerned, I am the owner of the card.  It is in my possession.  I didn't want a refund.  Too bad the customer is not number one.  There should be exceptions to the rule or special allowances.  I could see if the other person was in possession of the card but I bought it.  It was redeemed but my daughter and this person that it was bought for weren't even there for two hours.  It was the day after Christmas and it was so packed they left without riding any rides and he said he would not go back.  Buyer beware.

Honestly do not waste your money. Every single ride we went on broke down as we were waiting in line. I wouldn't mind if it happened 2-3 times on different rides. I understand that things happen. However, this happened on literally every single ride we tried to go on. The park is literally a huge circle and has a poor layout/place of rides. The only reason I gave it 2 stars was because of all the animals. Save your money to go to a better amusement park.
The entrance procedure is awful! The guard checks bag by bag to each guest, unbelievable... making the entry go reaaally slow. I hope they can change this soon.

I looooove roller coasters so I was excited that husby and I had the opportunity to come here during our recent trip to Florida.  I am not sure what it is like normally but since it was around the holidays and a bit chilly, the park was pretty empty!

They do have a good number of roller coasters and my favorite was Shreikra.  I also enjoyed Kumba and the other newer loop-de-loop roller coaster.  It was too cold for the water rides but we did see some brave souls on them.  However, they absolutely need to get rid of the wooden roller coaster!  I literally was afraid we were going to fly off the track and it was so bouncy, I thought my head was going to snap right off the top of my spine.  I used to love American Eagle at Six Flags in IL and that was made of wood so I am not sure what is going on with this one.

They also had animals and a ski-lift type ride, as well as a "safari" ride.  I saw some bands play and they even had an ice skating show that was Christmas themed, which was pretty good!

The park was very clean and well kept.  I think this is definitely a good place to spend the day!
If you like rides, you need to go here!  Always clean and nice employees. The animal exhibits are nice and lines for most rides are long. The newer Jungala area is nice.

Such a scam, you buy an annual pass at the door. The annual pass includes free parking. But you don't get reimbursed for the 20 dollars you paid for parking today. It's a sham. I parking is included in the pass I just purchased!!!
We love this place. Military gets in free once a year. There was so much to do we only was only on one side of the park. So much Entertainment. We will go back.
The parking situation at this park is a nightmare. It took me 1 1/2 hours to get 900 feet into the parking lot. No exaggeration.It is so not Disney. They need to work on this.

The best amusement Park around. If you like roller coasters, this is the place for you. My 4 kids are finally old enough to ride the rides, so instead of Disney or Legoland, we finally got year passes to Bush Gardens and the water park Adventure Island. Both are just the best, we take a weekend trip up there about once a month. It's cheap too. We got the year tickets for a little more than $100. A piece.
 For. The. Year! 
Parking is expensive, $20.00 a day. So, may as well get a hotel cheap and walk our take the shuttle. We also pack a backpack full of sandwiches in ziploc baggies. We buy the reusable cups, soda refills are a dollar and we bring the cups with us all year. 
Can't beat it with a stick!
Great place to visit big and scary roller costars must go if in Tampa area

I hadn't been to Busch Gardens in over a decade, but a friend wanted to hit the coaster circuit for his 39th birthday. So our gang of seven guys, ranging from late 30s to early 50s, trekked over to Tampa for the day.

I tend to think of Busch Gardens as more of an "amusement" park and less of a "theme" park. While it has themed areas in terms of the design of the buildings, it's not as full-on thematically as areas at Disney or Universal can be. But that's not why you visit here: you visit here for the rides.

We were in the park about eight hours, with a couple of leisurely cocktail stops along the way. In that time, we got on seven rides, on a day with extremely short waits. (Our second-longest wait was to get off of SheiKra, which apparently was on the verge of breaking down just as we were second-in-line to return to the loading platform.) I can't imagine getting much more done in a full-length, fully packed summer day.

We had a good time, but we also noticed a little "run-down" look in many areas of the park -- most notably Gwazi, which has had one half shuttered (this being the "new thing" last time I went), with its whole structure looking really aged. And regrettably, age has caught up with my equilibrium, too, so I ended up a spectator as others went on what used to be my favorite coaster in Florida,  Kumba. Sigh.

Part of me would like to go back to do the half of the park we essentially skipped in our quest to hit all the coasters -- take a slower pace, take in the shows, all that. But I figure we'll wait for the next new big thing to open to justify the drive, the time and the cost.

I will preface this review by saying I may be slightly biased, I receive two free annual passes every year because my father works at the park.

Busch Gardens is one of my favorite parks. There is a great assortment of rides, animal attractions, and shows.

As far as rides go, BG is a must for roller coaster fans. I'd rate it as probable having the best roller coasters in the southeast, and BG gives the rest of the parks in the country a run for their money. The best part about the coasters is they have varying degrees. You can start out on one of the older slower coasters, giving new riders a taste of the fun, and work your way up to faster, more intense experiences. The rest of the rides in the park are all fun, wait times are fairly short, and most importantly, the rides all appear clean and upkept.

I love BG for the animal attractions. The Edge of Africa area has some really unique animal exhibits, and you can really get up close to some of the animals. The new animal nursery/surgery area is really neat also, and again, its fun to get right up near the animals. The variety of animals at the park have decreased over the years, but for the past several years, BG has maintained the animal exhibits at a fairly steady level.

The only reason that I am not giving BG five stars, is for the restaurant selection. Like any theme park, there is your selection of quick walk through lines if you want to just grab lunch and go. Sadly, there is only one really sit down option, the Crown Colony House. Now don't get me wrong, the Crown Colony House is great, and the family style meal option is perfect for big families. I would like maybe one or two more options though, just for some variety.

Overall BG is an excellent park and I make sure to visit several times a year.

Who doesn't like Bush Gardens? I mean...animals, rides, entertainment, all around fun. Wear walking shoes because you are bound to put your feet into a frenzy...walking and standing in line.
However, in saying that, we went on a Wednesday and hardly had any lines what so ever, but we walked about 6.5 miles around the park looking at animals and getting to rides.

This is NO Disney and they have shorter hours of operation. But there is NO shortage of friendly helpful staff and things to do. 
It has been YEARS since I had been here, and so much has changed. I enjoyed the animals and the feeding/petting more than the rides. (It is due to my age I believe as I could not tolerate the thrusts and spins)
My grandchildren ran, laughed, rode, screamed....and overloaded on icees....it was a great day!

I enjoyed feeding of the Flamingos, kangaroos, and birds...I even had birds land on my head and arms...as did the grandkids. We all loved it so much we didn't want to leave.
There is the cutest kids section, so there is fun for everyone!

Food is typical amusement park food and prices. I had to wait an extra long time for a burger, as they ran out at the time....but then it was hot and fresh! Just the way I like it!

Parking is 20.00 a car or 22.00 preferred parking which parks up by the gate. Trams are there for getting you back and forth to you car when needed.

They have photographers all through out the park taking pictures of your day...so be prepared to smile a lot! :)

Take sunscreen and later up as the hot sun will get you....but if you forget...they sale it there in the gift shops. OH...and if your phone battery is dying...they have charging stick stations to purchase, which I understand that you can exchange also at Disney....what's not to like about that!

Great rides but the map they give out and the signage is super confusing!!
I went with my friend despite having a lot of fun we were having a hard time following the map. The name of the places were replaced with Christmas terminology so it made hard to follow or understand.
The park was not as busy as I anticipated which was great because we got on rides in a short amount of time.
The other thing that was not so good was the amount of rides that broke down while we were standing in line for over an hour. My new favorite ride is Cobra's curse... what can I say, a ride that takes you up, spins and then goes backwards!! Wow... Sheikra was fun as well and that first drop.. I screamed my lungs out but I will do it again.. so much fun! We also had a chance to tour the park and see different animals in the "wild". In all honesty I'm not a big fan of animal kept in parks but from what the tour guide was explaining the park is sort of a sanctuary for these animals..however my views still haven't changed..
My overall visit was fun!! If you love rollercoasters, thrills etc. You will definitely enjoy Busch Gardens!

also ich hätte es ja nicht wirklich als zoo bezeichnet, sondern als themenpark, wo man zwischen den rollercoastern tiere anschauen kann. eine loopingbahn geht sogar direkt über das tigergehege. für die tiere vielleicht etwas stressig.
der name busch kommt von der anheuser busch brauerei und bedeutet auch, dass es im park an einem stand freibier gibt. zwar nur in 0.1-bechern, aber bei dem preis muss man sich wohl mindestens ein bud gönnen. 
besonderers cool fand ich die neue loopingbahn, wo man 30m steil bergab fährt. der wagen ist so konstruiert, dass beim runterfahren alle freie sicht haben. außerdem wartet er oben in gekippter position 20min (ok 10sek, aber gefühlt seeehr lange ;-) ), bevor es denn in die tiefe geht. von orlando ist der park aber noch eine gute autostunde entfernt. für besucher der tampa bay oder fort myers ist der park dann schon näher.
I saw two workers over the entire park. And no one knows what they are doing. Does not have a theme park feel to it at all.

After research on which amusement park to choose in Florida, Busch Gardens won out. I haven't been here in over 30 years the last time I went to Busch gardens it's was associated with  Anheuser Busch. What a nice surprise. We went on a Thursday afternoon. The only draw back is that all the rides were closed at about 4:00 due to inclement weather. A lighting and thunderstorm hit the area. The ride lines move fast and all the staff that we stopped and asked questions to were quite friendly. 
Another great thing was that most of the animals were out and about. All were in range to get good pictures.
We are at a theater where a rock and doo woop show was being put on. Shout out to the performers they did a great job. I had a blast singling along with them although my daughter kept asking me to stop.
One last note, due to the weather we could come back tomorrow show our ticket and visit the park again. Great deal.  This is definitely someplace to visit in Florida, we will come back  again.

Ps-the roller coasters are pretty great as well.

My wife and i finally got a chance to visit Busch Gardens without our kids!!! It's a family theme park, but for parents who wish to ride the bigger rides, but have smaller children with them, it can pose a challenge....Busch Gardens has world class coasters! I'm a big fan of Kumba (my favorite), Montu, Cheetah Hunt &  Sheikra. Out of all the coasters, Cheetah Hunt's line was the longest @ 60 min. All others were 30 min or less. Cheetah Hunt is still very popular. We didn't get a chance to ride the new Cobra's Curse. The wait was 75 min when we thought about riding it, so we decided to skip it this time. We bought annual passes so we'll have more chances to check it out.....My one big gripe about Busch Gardens is the park's layout. Its very difficult to navigate. There are quite a few dead-ends in the park that force you out of your way to get to certain attractions. There are signs with arrows throughout the park that will lead you to popular attractions but they aren't consistent enough. Busch Gardens is like a zoo and Theme Park combined, so the layout is more organic. I feel like the signage needs to be better and it needs more shortcuts to make getting from section to section easier. Busch Gardens is a great place overall though. I'm fortunate to live about 30 min away. It goes without saying that if you're a local or visiting from out of town, you have to check out Busch Gardens!

Busch Gardens is not exactly conducive to families with little kids, despite it's many zoo attractions, simply because almost all of the rides are rollercoasters. However if you are a thrill master (or have a bunch of teenage kids) this place is a must visit!

The Good: 

Thrills not found anywhere else: This place has some amazing rollercoasters, including the most amazing SheiKra. This rollercoaster simply cannot be described. It has a completely 180 degree drop where you can't even see the track. It is truly exhilarating, and I have been to several thrill parks in my day. Trust me, this one ride is worth the ticket price for thrill seekers.

Great Zoo attractions: Although this place is primarily known as a thrill destination, their animal attractions are equally amazing, especially the new Jungala attraction, which features monkeys, alligators, and tigers, oh my!

Free Beer: Go to the hospitality center, check out the horses and knock back a cold one. What more could you ask for??

I love going to Busch Gardens, and even though my daughter is not tall enough for most of the thrills, she still enjoys the different zoo attraction, and I love tag teaming with the husband on the rollercoasters.

Overall 8.9/10= Busch is Best!!
Not quite as good as Disney but cheaper with awesome coasters.

Finally got to go to Busch Gardens after wanting to since I was a child (for whatever reason). I enjoyed myself. The coasters are fun and the idea of mixing an amusement park with a zoo makes it all an even better experience. I do wish that it had more adult rides because I don't believe the ticket price(s) should be the same as Universal Studios and/or Disney.

One of my favorite places EVER has turned into a rundown, half open amusement park ... but for full price.  What use to be a blend of beautiful gardens, wildlife and fun rides had turned into worn, overpriced tourist stop. Incredibly disappointing and sad.  Half of the attractions today were closed for 'maintenance' but appear to be deserted. No one in sight working on them.  The 'safari' appeared to be in poor condition with minimal animals in sight.

We have been to the gardens and adventure island before but this year me and my wife got season passes.  I'm kinda glad we did considering when there is nothing to do its a short drive and not too busy yet and i say yet hahaha.  We also enjoyed adventure island very clean water park with plenty to do.  Being from Arizona you would think lots of water parks well hardly and the ones they do have are very sad compared to what Florida has to offer.  I have heard that some of the food if not most of it is not good but the restaurant near cheetah hunt is good.  I have never really been a fan of amusement park food I've always made it a tradition to go out some where afterwards that is very tasty.  Our last visit we stop at the red lobster and got filled up on cheddar bay biscuits lol.

It's always great fun. Through the years my kids have had a wonderful time. As toddlers, they loved the shows, rides and animals and now as preteens, they still enjoy rides and games. The annual passes make it easy to go whenever we like and paid for themselves after three visits.

I Like Busch Gardens.

I am a huge roller-coaster fan. I am a huge amusement park fan. I even like the scary corner carnivals and state fairs. So it would follow that I like an amusement park with 4 large Coasters.

I am also from Miami, so I am used to and know how to dress/what to bring to deal with the heat and humidity. (They also sell hand-held "squirt fans" which are awesome.)

Good Stuffs:
If you buy their "Souvenir Cup," you can get cheap refills in it, even if you bring it back another day.
Cool animal attractions, where you will actually SEE animals. Both walk-through and Safari-Type rides. (Rhino Rally)  You can also see the animals from the Montu and Kumba coasters, and from the park-wide train.
Decent food. For a park. Expensive? Yes. But edible.

Specifics:
The Skeik'Ra coaster is amazing. It has a full 90 degree drop. Sit up front. It's amazing and terrifying. It's floorless, so your feet are dangling and you are held to your seat at that first drop only by the shoulder bar, staring STRAIGHT DOWN before the drop. Whooooosh. To the Max.
The Montu is an Egyptian-themed inverted coaster. It's smooth and twisting, looping through landscaped grounds and with killer views of the "Safari" animals to the north. The first climb and drop are killer. This is a coaster you can ride again and again.
The Kumba is one of Bush Gardens' first "legendary" coasters. It's a steel track, with loops, barrel rolls, and corkscrews. It, too, is a must.
The Gwazi. I am not a fan of wooden coasters.  At all. But this one seems bumpier and rougher than most. I generally skip it.
Congo River Rapids: You'll get soaked. It's fun.  But try to hit it at the end of your visit, and have towels in the car. (Always have towels in the car for a Florida Theme Park visit anyway. It rains at 3:30 pm every day in the Wet Season. The "Dry Season" is "Winter" 3 months out of the 9.)
The Scorpion: A cute kiddie-style coaster. Not a true Kiddie Coaster but much gentler than the others.

There are exhibits and shows, too. The Clydsedales are impressively massive. (And smelly) But still a sight to see.
The Tiggers (ahem. "Tigers") are gorgeous.
There's Elephants, Hippos, Lions, Hyenas and more in the "Edge of Africa." And they are usually OUT. VISIBLE. It's great.
The Serengeti Plain has free-roaming Zebras, Girraffes, and other African Animals which you may observe from an aerial tram or the Serengeti Express Train.
Alligators in the Pond. They're HUGE. And they're RIGHT THERE. Very Cool.
The Monkeys. (Apes?) (Gorillas?) Whatever. Walk through. It's neat.

The Tips:
It's Florida. Bring Sunscreen. Have towels in the car or in a locker. Perhaps a change of shirt and socks as well, in case of rain or sweat. I usually wear a bathing suit under my shorts and tank top.
If you'll be in the area for an extended time, consider their multi-park pass for Sea World in Orlando as well. (And don't miss the Kracken Coaster. OMG!)
Bring Ponytail Bands. Crazy Coasters can turn long hair into a birdsnest very quickly. Also it can help you cool down.
Drink lots of water. 
Bring a disposable camera, or hold on to yours REALLY tight. There are no lockers at the rides, and they're pay-per-use in the park.
Get there early. Remember: It rains at 3:30pm in Florida. They WILL close rides if lightning is in the area.
Wear COMFORTABLE SHOES. Flip Flops tend to fly off on roller coasters, and they often make you take them off. Keep that in mind.
Oh, and the ICE CREAM PARLOR near the FRONT GATE?  Yeah, It's AIR CONDITIONED! Sit there for a bit if it's sweltering.

Lastly, HAVE FUN! It's an AMUSEMENT PARK and there's lots to do, but the experience is what you make it. Enjoy what Busch Gardens has to offer. It's a great place, with something to amuse everyone, from the kidlets to the crazy coaster enthusiast and everyone in between.

Busch gardens, while clean and organized, is not at all what it used to be. 

We went on a Tuesday during February school vacation with the kids. We looked online for discounted tickets and we're not able to find any, so we used our AAA card for $5 off each ticket. Sadly, that didn't make much of a dent in the price - we paid approximately $370 for a day of disappointments. 

First off, while this sounds petty, it became important throughout our day, the map sucked. It was not designed to actually help navigate the park. I won't go into detail, but just be prepared to spend a lot of time staring at it and not really knowing which way to turn to get where you want to go.

We were with our two kids, age 4 and 10. We were really looking forward to a ride we could go on together, which was almost impossible to find, unless you want to ride the little kid rides in the Sesame Street area over and over again. 

The Congo River Rapids was closed, which was one of the few rides we would have been able to go on together. Apparently it had been closed for several weeks, and they did not know when it would open again. 

My husband made a good point: we paid a ton of money -- and they can't fix their rides more efficiently? This is their business, it should be top priority to fix the rides that are broken.

There were quite a few incredible looking roller coasters - though we would have to ride those separately, since the kids couldn't go on them... But that was to be expected.  

Sesame Street was good, and it was nice that they had the characters available to take pictures with. 

In all, we spent $370 for the four of us, which was just the tip of the iceberg. They get you for every cent you have when you are in there. They charge for every little thing - beers are $8, a slice of pizza (ONE slice) was $8, and slushy drinks for the kids (NOT in one of their super expensive Busch Gardens plastic tumblers) was $4. Oh, and you can't get a lid for the kids cups. Apparently this is due to the wild life. But it makes no sense, because they have plenty of other items that could be dangerous to the wildlife. How about straws, or beer bottle tops? It just all seemed like a ploy to get you to buy the reusable, and much more expensive, memorabilia cups, which, oh yeah, did I mention they were all out of the kid size at both locations we visited to get one? So it was either an adult size cup - you guessed it - for $8, or a plastic cup without a lid for $4. Caught between wanting to have fun and get a few cups for the kids to bring home and not wanting to feed into their ridiculous money making scam.
There were other rides that were closed, but we weren't as sad about those as we were about the Congo river ride. 

One last point: if you do end up going and you have the time, at least buy the tickets so you can return again (they were the exact same price as the one day tickets - which makes sense I guess because they make so much money off of everyone when they are stuck there to eat and drink away all of their money). You will find that one day isn't really quite enough time to get to a lot of the rides. Especially if it's busy, the wait in line will eat up a lot of your day.

And also: the train ride was actually quite good. You could see a lot of the animals - pretty close up. The sky ride was fun for all of us, but you weren't able to see many of the animals from there. 

The "air Grover" ride in Sesame Street was fun, and it surprised me that it was actually quite fast and a bit scary for smaller kids. Thankfully, our 4 year old is more if a daredevil, when it comes to rides, than our 10 year old.

For roller coaster and thrill ride enthusiasts there is no place better in Florida and certainly not at such a reasonable price for annual passes.  The park is laid out in a somewhat mazelike circle so be sure to bring a map or you may end up back at the beginning without having experienced everything it has to offer.
The reason I only give 4 stars is because the animals on site always seem a bit depressed.  Their enclosures are small and seem cramped especially the elephants which never seem happy.  On specialty nights like Howl O Scream especially the animals don't seem to understand what is happening and seem upset.

The rides and food are 5 stars but they should either get rid of the animals by sending them to places where they can have bigger enclosures or build a separate park.
I highly recommend Busch Gardens for the thrill seeker visiting Tampa Bay.

I have come here before and of course if u know the rides it pretty much speaks for itself. There's no way u can't have a good time. I came here on christmas day for the second time with my son for the first time but this time I went to the animal side, it was awesome! My 1 yr old son loved the birds since they were much more active compare to the other animals lol. I would say he's favorite was the sesame street show (his favorite elmo of course). To our luck, elmo was the only character who even came up to him, even though my son froze lol, it was awesome, I even teared, it was his first show. Above all, good walk, good sight seeing, great experience!

Great park!  There is a coaster here that takes your breath away out of fear.  I loved it!!  Sheikra!  This thing is a floorless coaster that takes you on the craziest ride.  Possibly the scariest part is the first hill.  That is one huge drop and right up into a loop.  Check it out on You Tube if you want a glipse...

http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=DFZ_hve5K2s

The other coaster that is worth riding is Cheetah Run.  Smooth!  

We opted for the all you can eat along with the day pass and i do think it was worth it.   It's been a couple of weeks now but I believe it was about $10 extra for the all you can eat wrist band.  Parking was another cost- again it's been a couple weeks but I think it was about $15.  Book your tickets online and there is a small savings and skip the lines at the gate go to the quick print on the right side of the gates.  

FUN DAY!!

Parking lot E needs to be paved.It looks like the last time it was was in the 80's.  B Gardens needs to tap into their Trillion dollar account and get it done.The park is very over rated. O nly 8-9 adult rides and the rest is all kids stuff. Hershey Park is a million times better.
Giving them 3 stars instead of 1 because they did make things right and were sincerely apologetic for my last visit. I'll review them again after I go back for a second visit.

Park is starting to look aged, animal area starting to feel too old zoo-ish.  Rides are good but several not working every time i go.  OK food to be found, typical theme park fair at best.  I miss the free beer line, thanks inbev lol.

This review is for people who don't like roller coasters.

I had a good time at Busch Gardens watching other people have fun.  I'm not a roller coaster person.  Feeling my stomach in my throat and being dizzy all day just doesn't do it for me.  If you like crazy rides, this is the park for you.

I went on three rides at the park and here's the scoop....

1.  Congo River Rapids = LOVE on a hot day.  My clothes were soaked, my purse was soaked, and my sneakers were sloshy AND I loved it.

2.  Montu- I finally got the courage to go on a stupid roller coaster.  This ride will make you dizzy. 

3.  Family Safari - don't waste your time.  If I waited an hour for this ride, I'd be pissed.  The ride is a small circle, looks at a few animals, and then you finish up.  Do yourself a favor and check out the animals on the walking path.

I ate lunch at a table where I could watch Shekira.  I loved watching the roller coaster while enjoying ribs, coleslaw, and a salad.  I split a meal with my boyfriend and we were both satisfied.  Oh and ask for tap water if you're cheap, they'll give it to you.  

The animals were great.  If you're an animal lover, you'll enjoy walking through the animal exhibits.  My favorites were the elephants and flamingos.
Very long and slow-moving lines for everything from rides to animal exhibits.  Would be an okay place but I've spent more time in line than doing anything else...there are much better things to do.

Loved the roller coasters, great animals, friendly staff. My only complaint is you spend $95 for a ticket to get in and they have a hero safari ride that is really cool, but it's not included in your ticket. You have to pay an additional $39 to take the safari ride, and I think that's absurd. Needless to say, I want spending the additional money after already throwing out over $250 on tickets and lunch. Disney's Animal Kingdom had a jeep safari ride that's a lot longer and is included in the ticket price!

I came here with my friends during a weekend in the middle of summer and it was pretty packed. Even though there were a lot of people, the lines moved very quickly! The wait for Sheikra was only 15 minutes. 

I really appreciate that because of the scorching hot day, the employees doused us with sprays of water periodically throughout the theme park to ease the heat. Bringing a lot of sunscreen and/or an umbrella will really improve your experience at Busch Gardens. 

The rides are very exciting if you are an adrenaline junkie, but if you are easily queasy, then I would go to a more child friendly park like Disney world. 

Unfortunately during our visit, there was heavy rainfall for a couple for hours that made us wait for the rain to stop so we could ride the rest of the rides. 

Tip: I know that a lot of people who come to Busch Gardens travel far to experience the fun but when it rains, you're able to let the employees know to get a raincheck for another day!

We received a rain check to attend the park again. This was a very pleasant experience!

A great overall family park.  We have an 8 and 7 year old and they loved the experience.  Don't waste your time on the train, simply because the stops are way too long.  Also don't eat the ribs at the smoke house on the left side of the park, forget the name of the town.  All rides for the most part were kid friendly and the lines moved faster than expected.
Staying in line for 1.5 hours is an incredible fun. Lines are everywhere. Bush garden should think about limiting number of guests, so everyone feels comfortable.

It seemed like a poor man's zoo.  The roller coasters were great, the all-day food pass was well worth it.  The pass also gets you a buy-one-get-one free at the small non-restaurant type food places.  The train was down which was very disappointing.  My family had a good time but I will not go back again, I don't feel it is worth the entrance fee.

Family and I came on Sunday 12/10/17. This was my second time here. My previous visit years ago was when Cheetah Hunt did not exist, so needless to say I was really excited to ride this coaster first. We got to the park when it opened at 10am. We ran to Cheetah Hunt, only to find out it was a delayed opening due to an unknown ride malfunction. We waited in the line for it to open for about an hour until we got fed up and decided to walk through the rest of the park and come back to it later. Next we went to Cobra's Curse, same thing. This coaster was also closed due to an unidentified ride issue. Kumba was also shut down that day (looked like they permanently retired it, with no notice to the public). Sheikra and Montu were working, but we wound up watching shows our entire visit and eating. Cheetah Hunt finally opened near the end of the day and we were able to get one ride on it before leaving. I was slightly disappointed we paid full price only to be able to ride a few select rides and not all; so hence my deduction of one star. Some of the food venues were also advertising for kettle corn only to find out that they didn't have any made for sale. We love the animals and Christmas decor around this time of year. I'm sure I'm season, it's a fabulous place when everything's working!

Ich kann mich hier nur den positiven Stimmen anschließen, war ein superschöner Tagesausflug. Hatten wahnsinnig tolles Wetter und es war nach den US Ferien, somit nicht überfüllt.
Steht wieder auf dem Programm.
Aber nicht nur die Fahrgeschäfte, auch die ganze Anlage mit den Tieren und Vögeln und Blumen etc. ist sehenswert. Klar, der Eintritt schmerzt, wenn man nicht so der Fahr-Freak ist, aber was tut man nicht alles für's Kind ;-)

Bought two tickets, 4 roller coasters were closed. No mention of such, upon entering the park. I get that things happen, but one was worn and being painted (so this was known to management, prior to opening the park) -- and 3 others were closed for "unknown reasons". 

I've been coming to this park for years - wow, things have changed -- and, for the worst. I'm guessing as a part of the SeaWorld acquisition,  some change was anticipated -- but the experience was NOTHING like it's always been. We will likely never return and chalk Busch Gardens, Tampa up as an old past time. Very sad.

I have never been to a Busch Gardens before, but I LOVE amusement parks and roller coasters. My husband and I were lucky enough to go on an overcast day, so we basically walked right into the park and onto every ride.

The first ride we went on - SheiKra - was by far the best of the day, and possibly the best roller coaster I've ever been on! The first drop, where you're basically hanging vertically at the top? Whoa Nelly!!!

We didn't get to go on every ride, as it started raining about an hour and a half before the park closed and one or two were closed for maintenance anyway (note to park employees: do NOT tell guests that a ride is having technically difficulties and that it will probably be open later in the day!). Beware the River Rapids: we thought we'd get a bit soaked but ended up DRENCHED. We looked as if we jumped in. We were so uncomfortable, we ended up buying a change of clothes at the park! (Only to then get rained on...)

Our biggest complaint was the employees. You could tell that most of them did not want to be there/did not care about their job/were just waiting for the day to end. No one was mean, but most of them were just very nonchalant and sort of brushed us off and went back to their cell phones/friends.

Our other complaint was that there's no quick way to get around. When it started pouring, we had to run back to the locker where we'd stored our stuff. Yet to get to the locker and back to the exit, we basically had to walk the ENTIRE park. There should be one or two "shortcut" trails for situations like this. I wouldn't have minded the long walk - it's good to get exercise - but it was annoying in this situation.

Another complaint: you can't bring bags on ANY rides, so you need to pay for a locker. If you don't want to pay 50 cents every time you go on another ride, you can keep your stuff in the same locker, but then you are without everything and have to run back to it every time you need something. VERY annoying.

Ultimately we had a great time and the rides were good (one or two were great), but we don't feel the need to ever go back.
Well worth it to purchase annual passes to get free parking. Love Busch Gardens, we like to take the family several times a year. Something for everyone.

Looking old - service mediocre- lots of rides closed - the map is not easy to read - websites doesn't inform of wait times or closures 
I have been to Busch gardens for almost 30 years - sad to see how this has gone down hill

It's awesome that they have a zoo, but let's face it you hear bout the rides and on a non crowded day you can do all the thrill rides multiple times in maybe 2-3 hours. The water rides are ok, but that's not why you go to Busch Gardens. The zoo is really cool way to beat the heat but the overall lack in thrill rides keeps it from beating any 6 flags in my opinion.

One of my favorite theme parks in the South!! Family friendly, loads of animals and tons of thrills to be found. If visiting during the summer, be prepared for Florida's daily afternoon showers. It's always wise to pack a poncho just in case. Also, I'm not one for roller coasters, and I love this park because while I'm waiting for my friends to ride there is always something to see or watch close by their attractions. Also, great entertainment within the park as well. Make sure you take the time to catch the shows.

Busch Gardens rocks!  We went on a day that it rained early which was great because the park was extremely slow.  We did all the shopping during the first hour during the sprinkling rain.  Don't miss the garden decor/plants for sale when you first enter.  The gift shops had a lot of really nice gifts that were resonably priced.
            One thing I don't recommend doing is the All Day Food for $30.  We did it and felt obligated to eat.  Even when we weren't hungry.  The only place I would recommend eating is the BBQ place. 
            We did the day Sarengeti Safari for an extra charge that we enjoyed so much that we came back for the Saturday night Safari tour.  The night tour is a small group with tour guides( Go Mori, Charles and Gabe you guys were awesome)  who take you to various animals.  The keepers are there feeding them so they're right up front.  The lions were my absolute favorite.  The night tour is 21yrs+.  You start with FREE beer and a picture with the tour guides.  Take the picture that comes with your package too!  There is also a camp fire that everyone gets around to tell stories.  At the end of the tour you get desserts and hot chocolate.  
             There is also a bird/animal show that has scheduled hours.  If you can make it go!  It's free and a lot of fun.

Ein riesiger Park mit vielen Attraktionen, Shows, Bahnen, Tiere, Restaurants.
Die Bahnen sind Hammer, jedoch mit vielen Loopings und Schrauben nichts für schwache Mägen ;-)
Wenn man an einem Wochentag im Dezember den Park besucht hat es kaum Leute, da lohnt sich ein Quick Access Pass, wo man nicht so lange anstehen muss, nicht. Für Tage mit mehr Besucher ist das ein muss für Achterbahn-Fans, denn die Bahnen sind so cool, dass man nicht nur 1 Mal fahren möchte.

Die Tierattraktionen sind auch sehr gut. Wir hatten die 30 Minuten Safaritour gebucht, da sieht man die Tiere von Nahem und kann sogar Giraffen streicheln. Die Tiere auf dem offenen Feld (Zebras, Nashörner, Giraffen, Antilopen, ...) machen einen "glücklichen" Eindruck. Die Geparde, Löwen, Tiger, Affen eher weniger, aber scheinen trotzdem gut umsorgt zu sein. Die Affen hatten eine Decke, da es doch eher kühl war für Florida.

Die Preise sind sehr hoch, 95$ pro Ticket, die Verpflegung im Park ist auch eher teuer. Wir hatten aber einen sehr schönen Tag verbracht. Ist auf jeden Fall einen Besuch wert!

I recently went back to Busch Garden's for the first time in 20+ years so naturally it was all new to me.  It's like a giant zoo with animals from mainly Africa with a few roller coasters thrown.  I went on 2 of the roller coasters and maybe it was because it was only in the upper 60s/low 70s but the wait for both rides was less than 10 minutes!  Loved it!!!  Also paid extra for a Safari which included a ride on a flat bed truck out to see the antelope, zebras, rhinos, giraffes, and plenty other animals I now cannot name.  The highlight of this safari was getting to feed "Becca" the giraffe lettuce.  Plenty of Budweiser influence in the park with the Clydesdale's and the Bud & BBQ area.  I tried some BBQ ribs and they smelled better than they tasted.  If you are over 21, you get 2 free drinks (Bud products naturally).  They do not give you tickets or punch a card or anything so if you don't have much of a conscious, you could probably drink your admission (there is only a sign asking you to adhere to the 2 drink policy).

Been here 2 hours. A easy to park Sunday.  First ride broken. Second ride waited 45 minute and broken too.  Left to get on skyway to other side of park. 

$99 to get in. $20 to park and find it is run by hacks. 

How do I get me money back.

My brother and I finally decided to go to Busch Gardens because our friend was visiting from NY. The drive to Tampa was not as bad as I thought it would be. We purchased our tickets online. Our tickets included the all day dining deal, which was great because it felt like we were thirsty every 10 minutes. The food was decent, some places better than others (Desert Grill was cool, good food and live entertainment).

The park was not too crowded. The rides were not that great but the wait times were no more than 25 minutes. I was so excited about all of the roller coasters that Busch Gardens had to offer, but not many made me excited when I rode them. I guess my expectations were too high. Congo River Rapids was closed for improvements, so only two open water rides and it was a really hot day! The "Iceploration" show was really nice.

The best part for me was all the animals! One orangutan was trying to tighten the net he was resting on, it was so cute. The other orangutan seemed so sad which in turn made me sad. One elephant was having an awesome time cooling off under the water sprinklers. I won't keep going on and on about the animals, but that is the reason I gave this park 4 (4.5) stars.

Great theme park the employees are very helpful and nice.  The rides range from not intense and family friendly to off the charts petrifying there is something to do for everyone there.  Most people don't know this but there are also a lot of animals there go to mambo junction and curiosity caverns they are between Cheetah hunt and Timbuktu close to rhino rally they are by the tortoises.

BUSH GARDENS ist kein ZOO!


 Es ist ein Themenpark der auch ein paar Tiere hat, so würde es passender beschrieben sein. Allerdings tut das der Fazination keinen Abbruch. Für uns persönlich ist BUSH GARDENS die bessere ALTERNATIVE zu Disney World in Orlando. Der Park ist gut zu erreichen, aufegräumt preislich wesentlich günstiger (wenn man bitte beachtet dass man für Kleinkinder seinen Buggy bitte selber mitbringt). Das neue Sesamstrassen Camp ist toll für die 3-5 Jährigen. Insgesamt ist es der familienfreundlichere Park für Familien mit kleinen Kindern. Er ist überschaubarer als Disney, die Attraktionen sind kindgerechter.


 Unser Eindruck:


 Kinder 3-10 = BUSH GARDENS
Kinder 10-99 = Disney


 Es gibt übrigens als GEHEIMTIP Kombikarten aus BUSH GARDENS und SEAWORLD diese kann man sich in jedem Triple A (AAA) Büro kaufen, AAA ist sowas wir der ADAC der USA. Dort bekommt man auch mal gerne gute Karten der Region umsonst.


 Viel Spaß! Und ja die Jeep Safari unbedingt machen!

Love this place. All day dining deal is great.  Lines suck, but thats expected.  I love the wildlife and ride combination.  Staff have all been great every visit. Ohhh and watching a live show while you dine is a great addition!

We went there in March of 2015. This is a very solid theme park. They don't have a ton of rides but the ones they do are really good if you like roller coasters. I liked the sheikra the best but also the cheetah hunt is a really well designed ride and a lot of fun. We did that one over and over again.

After my family's visit the other day, I feel that this company is strictly in it for the money. The four of us went and spent well over 400 dollars on just a one day pass. The rides were at first available, but refused to let my girlfriend ride because of her hand bag, stating she had to place it in a locker or she could not ride. We checked locker prices and they were 18 dollars for the day. When we returned her hand bag to the car, the rides had closed down due to inclement weather. The rides remained closed down for the rest of the day. The weather was cloudy, with no rain or lightning. They even closed down the animal attractions. The only parts that were not closed were the food stands and games that costed money. In conclusion, we paid all that money to walk around a closed amusement park. I had thought they would try to redeem their customer base by offering a discount to come back another time, but that is not the case. I will not be going back to get swindled again. Hope the animals are well taken care of since they don't get a choice in the matter.

Since I am moving out of the state pretty soon, I thought I should take advantage of the free military admission at Busch Gardens.  

First, I noticed the parking fee went up to 17 dollars.  Seriously??    The regular admission is 90 dollars.  Then we waited over 30 min in line at the ticket booths.  

There are many roller coasters but they frequently stop for a while or are shut down completely for maintenance.  The lines are pretty slow because there are not enough staffs working and it is inefficient.  

Thank god for the military  passes.  I certainly don't wanna pay 100 dollars for this place. So for that, I give Busch Gardens an extra star.

This is the best amusement park. PERIOD. There is something for everyone. There aren't many places you can go with a kid, adult, and senior citizen, and everyone have a blast. 

There are great, I mean GREAT roller coasters. There's a zoo and safari ride. There is FREE BEER. Yup, free beer. There are amazing grounds, and the price is less expensive than most of the other parks in Fla.

This place has figured out how to add value to fun and that's awesome in my book.

Theme park and zoo heaven!
This is hands down one of the best zoos in the country and I've been to several top flight zoos including the National Zoo and Cincinnati Zoo. 
The rides here are GREAT. I may be biased because I lived in Tampa, and my boyfriend's dad works here, and am a pass-holder...hummm  
Love Montu, my favorite ride of all time. Ride this in the front at night. I dare you not to duck your legs or scream! Sheikra always gives me butterflies in my stomach and I've ridden it about 50 times. It is always a rush and always awesome. Kumba never get old either and is a pure ge force giant! Cheetah Hunt is quite fun, and is even better at night! Gwazi is rough, but personally I like it. The Phoenix is a crazy looping Viking ship that I personally love. I always think I'm going to get stuck up-side-down, which is part of the fun! 
You will get WET on the Tilalwave water ride. The log flume ride is good ol classic fun, and Kongo river rapids is a classic tube ride (warning, you can get very wet on this too. This one is a real gamble). 
The animal exhibits are beautiful, and very up close and personal. You can pet kangaroos and wallabies! if you go on the Sunset safari tour you get a cold beer and can feed the giraffes! This was an amazing experience. It was on the pricey side, but worth the money!The Jungala tiger enclosure is crazy insane and you can walk into a dome and usually there is a tiger next to it or sitting on top if it!  Lots of tropical landscaping, waterfalls, and even performers on stilts! The scenery is great. There is always something to look at. This park beats Disney's Animal Kingdom hands down! 
The Kinetics Summer Nights show is cirque du soleil worthy and the music is great. Iceplorations is a lovely and top-flight ice skating show and a must see. Madagascar Live is so cute and great if you love the movies as I do! You can get your picture with the characters after the show. 
The Holiday events Howl-O-Scream and Christmas Town are very good as well, and a great way to get in the spirit. I enjoy both of them for different reasons, but riding the coasters at night is the highlight of both events! 
Lots of kiddie rides and things to do for kids.
All in all a beautiful park, and a must do if you are one of the following; in the Tampa area, a coaster fan, an animal lover, a show lover.
On your next Orlando vacation, it may be  an hour out of the way but is totally worth the drive and the theme park price! I'll always be a huge Busch baby!

We enjoyed our day at Busch Gardens.  There is ample parking and we didn't have to wait long for anything. The park is very clean and well maintained.   We really enjoyed the Serengeti Plain safari where you close to a lot of animals, especially when we were feeding the giraffes!! The fact that you could see and touch a lot of animals made this park really special.  We saw two shows, and both were very entertaining and professional...especially the Ice show.  Food isn't cheap, but it is good.
This has been my home town adventure place for over 20 years. You can have an amazing time here and it is worth the money. You will love this place and have no regrets about it.
Had a great time at Busch Gardens seeing all of the various types of wildlife and the Serengeti Tour is definitely worth the extra money.  Riding along and feeding the giraffes was a hoot!
Best amusement park ever.  Animals + Beer + Rollercasters = Good Times.  FYI- they let veterans and family in free.

This place is great! We love the roller coasters and all the animals.  We went this past weekend and the crowds were low and really no waits for any of the rides.  If you have a large family like mine(five people) It pays to get the meal deal if your doing to be in the park all day.  We defintely got our moneys worth there.  With the meal deal you can also get bottles of water which were great to walk around the park with.  Plus before we left we got several bottles to take home.  

The entire family had a great time and we all look forward to going back.  There is a huge kiddy Elmo area where the small kids can play.  My four year old had a great time.  

We cant wait to go back!
Love love love this park. I have a yearly pass and get so many benefits with it. This park has entertainment for all ages. Animals, roller coasters, gaming area, shows. Always have a great time!

A little pricy for entrance and food and drink, but what amusement park isn't?

Busch Gardens has a handful of exceptional roller coasters, a scattering of water rides, and several options for children--especially the new Sesame Street themed section.

The staff is friendly and accommodating.  There are several food options, including restaurants and concession stands.  

The park has most of your standard amusement park attractions--though I don't recall seeing a Ferris Wheel.  In addition, they have Safari options and several shows.
There is a train that circles the entire park with several stops to make getting around the park a bit easier.  They also have a sky ride that will take you from one end of the park to another.

Unfortunately, the brewery is long since gone, and they don't seem to have the beer school anymore either.

I was excited to find out that Busch Gardens has special hours and events for Halloween. They call it the howl-o-scream nights. The ticket prices were a little steep even though a majority of the rides were closed, but the entrance fee includes all six haunted houses and you can ride a few of the roller coasters and thrill rides.
The haunted house were pretty great. They didn't do the normal clowns, zombies, and chainsaws. While those things were within the haunts, the haunted houses had more unique themes like Death Water Bayou, The Black Spot (pirates), and Insomnia. All of them were great but Motel Hell was probably my favorite. The lines weren't too long for them either. We did buy the fast pass and wound up not using it for half of the rides or haunted houses. It seems like once midnight rolled around the park was empty and the lines had no waiting.
We had a really good time and loved all of the rides. We were a little disappointed that Cheetah Hunt was closed unexpectedly, but we will definitely be coming back next time we're in town.

Good place family fun . I bought year passes and it's well worth it . My 3rd time here this month . Food lines get a little long but in all if u have time to come back you will get to experience all it has to offer
Before this park was bought by Seaworld it was great. Now......not enough employees, not enough show times & the train doesn't run frequently. Won't be back!
This Busch Gardens was a lot of fun to go to. I had a great time with my nephews and I will definitely be coming back. All the animal areas where clean and kept up very nicely!

Used to come to Busch Gardens just about every year growing up but this was my first time coming as an adult (21+). Outside of the beer garden and the cheetah hunt ride, the park hasn't changed much since I was here 8/9 years ago.

Although it was hot and humid, I still had an amazing time. I came with a large group and we had fast passes so we were able to ride almost every ride while also being able to stop for drinks/food at just about every corner with the all day dining/BOGO drink package.

First, let me talk about the food/drinks because I feel like that is at the heart of most yelp reviews. My favorite thing to eat in Busch Gardens is the ribs at Zambia smokehouse near Shiekra. I cannot express how much I love them. There is nothing more that I look forward to when I go to Busch Gardens than shoving those savory pieces of meat that I firmly believe are cooked by God himself. However, I was very disappointed to learn that the "all you can eat" package specifically EXCLUDES this entree. Not sure if that was always the case, but unfortunately I had just spent $35 on the package and didn't see a need to spend another $20+ or so on the ribs.

Anyway, the package does include a BOGO drinking perk. Every beer that you purchase entitles you to another beer. So you can get two beers for $9 which I think is a pretty good deal. After a few beers and a meal or two, you would have made your money back and some (CURSE YOU ZAMBIA).

My favorite rides growing up were Montu and Kumba and now that I am bit older and wiser, I was able to objectively evaluate the two again. I think it's fair to say that the two are the best in the entire park. They are are fairly long and full of sharp twists and turns that make up the long waits. Although I knew what I was getting myself into, it almost felt like a whole new experience because it has been so long. You almost forget how great the two rides really are. Be wary of Montu as it is a bit extreme and might catch you off guard. Towards the end of the day, my girlfriend and I decided to ride Montu back-to-back because there was no line and she came out feeling very nauseous and with a pretty strong headache.

Overall it was a great time. Had a ton of fun even though it was my 10th+ time going. I am not giving this theme park a five star review until they add the ribs to the all you can eat dining package.

In my heart of hearts, this should be a one star review. The animals' conditions were at time reprehensible. Those hyenas should probably have more than ten feet to roam around. There is a humane part of me that just wants to break all the animals out and hold their paws on their journeys back into the wild.

But that part of me only came out after I was gone and mulling over the experience. While I was there HOLY CRAP WE HAD SO MUCH FUN!

We went on Christmas Eve, so your mileage will vary considerably. I would have had a different experience if I'd had to wait in a line for any more than six seconds, but I didn't and it was awesome.

My girlfriend screams like she's being murdered for most of any roller coaster ride. It's hilarious. We rode Montu enough times, back to back, that she was yelling in a way that seemed more appropriate for signaling to family members that she had indeed come out of her coma. The highlight of our trip was when we rode Shikra twice in a row. That is a very, very intense 200 foot vertical drop you have there, Ms. Shikra. 

What's great about the park is that you can break up the exciting rides by seeing all these cool animals you never get to see, and vice versa, when you're bored of giraffes and alligators and tigers, you can challenge your bravery on super-fast and crazy vertical roller coasters. 

But I sure am glad I'm not a hyena.

Oh boy. Closed rides. Animals aren't active at all, I sort of felt bad for them. Seemed as if they were drugged us. Just a lot of technical difficulties during my visit. Rides are sub par. No big drops on any rides just somewhat speed and loops. Be sure to get fast pass for rides (highlight of the day). My wife and I just visited and we spent no more 5 Minutes in lines. Also if you plan on eating a lot it is good to get all day dining. We only ate once so we didn't purchase but I'm sure with a family it may be beneficial.

Everything here is is a ridiculous waiting process it took about 45 minutes to get in and then over 30 minutes to get on sheikra just to be told that something came up with the ride and they dont know how much longer it would be until its up. There are already three rides down so any other ride so far is about a hour wait after driving 4 hours to get here its the most upset situation to deal with

So much to see and not enough of time in the day to see it all. Had a wonderful time. Have not been on a roller coaster ride in 25 years and got on the Sheekra not only once but twice and both times in the front row. Talk about a blast from the past. I totally enjoyed my time at this establishment.

If you haven't you should go... remember if you have a florida resident with you you can get an annual pass for the price of a day pass and it's like 60-70 instead of the hundreds for disney. great for children with the zoo section and the kid's section with tike rides as well. Definitely has some good roller coasters as well. Go mid week and ride he ride with almost no lines.

Halloween portion is a bit expensive but very cool. 6 haunted houses to scare you and also haunted sections of the park. Some rides do still run during the scare hours. Seems like a completely different park during this event.

We visited Busch Gardens today as a group. I brought my dad, my sister, my husband, and 3 friends. This is going to be a rather long review, but I hope to cover all the areas of our visit. 

I am a huge fan of the passport pass with Busch Gardens. Upon arriving, only I had a pass with admission for the day. My husband purchased a passport pass (for Busch Gardens & Adventure Island), we purchased one for my sister (with her upcoming birthday), and one of our friends purchased one too. My father and other friend purchased a funcard. During this month if you buy a Busch Gardens funcard, you get Adventure Island too. The perks of having a passport over a funcard? You receive parking for free, as well as other perks year round. You receive free $10 giftcards every few months, a ticket for a friend during the month of your birthday (how my third friend came), extra discounts on tours, BOGO deals, all sorts of specials (they change each month). No other park I've held a pass at gives special rewards like these each month. They are nice little surprises that make you feel appreciated.

The tram was busy, so we decided to walk. It was truly a short enjoyable walk for us, not more than 1/4 mile. Once we arrive to the front we got in line to purchase our tickets. There are plenty of kiosks available, if you can do self-service you can use these. You can also purchase dining bands and quick que passes there. We got in line with all the passes we had to buy. We waited about 15 minutes and were ready to go into the park. Security check was simple and fast. It you bring food, skip using tupperware... You can't bring that in, we heard someone else.

We purchased Dine All Day dining bands for 2 of us. We personally felt it was worth it, for the water bottles and snacks. They have changed their dining bands recently, so be ready for changes. Now you can get 1 entree an hour, and they scan. You can get unlimited drinks (including bottled water), salads, fruits, and desserts. They also now need to ring your items up, and scan your band. Annual passholders receive discounts on these, so they are very affordable. If you plan to eat twice, they are worth it. Now with your band you get BOGO on things like dip n dots, churros, popcorn, beer (yes BEER), and other various snack cart items.

You name it we ate it! We ate at Dragons Grill, for lunch. My favorite is the warm cherry/apple tart they make, but I couldn't find it today. We had dinner at the smokehouse, and that was delicious! The lines were a little backed up. But I really think it is people learning the new band system, and spring break crowds.

We took our time, and spilt up since we had so many people. Yet we felt very accomplished with our visit today. We visited several shows (Opening Night Critters, Motor City Groove, Treasures of the Mirage, and Iceploration). All were great, my favorite is the baby elephant in Iceploration. We also rode several rides (Kumba, Cheetah Hunt, Monteu, Falcon's Furry, and the train). I am not a huge fan of their new locker system. They ran out of lockers at Kumba, and it was a long wait for a locker... We ended out having my husband hold the bags so we could ride. Busch Gardens will not let you ride with bags for safety purposes.

My Husband and I did the Elephant's Insider tour upon first arriving. This tour with Noel was a truly awesome experience! It was very organic and real, which we really appreciate. Not a song and dance, and misrepresentation of what daily tasks are. We felt involved and educated on what they were doing right in that moment, as if none of it was "planned." Knowing how such beautiful and large creatures are cared for while being able to learn neat things hands on is great. I encourage this tour for all who love elephants. It was an additional cost after admission, I thought it was a very reasonably priced tour ($26 per person w/ annual passholder discount).

We visited the kangaroos, and fed them for $6. I wish we got more lettuce than other things like pellets and hay, because they are only interested in the lettuce. I appreciate this exhibit, it lets you interact and pet them up close.

Overall Busch Gardens is a great experience. They really do deliver a great day at the theme park.

Being from Miami, we have visited Busch Gardens 2 years in a row, and in my very humble opinion, one of the best parks nowadays!!!

What we like is you have everything there:  an excellent zoo, attractions and when hunger strikes lot of choices to eat...And every now and then if you visit in July/August (like we have done) there are plenty of places to get some refreshments for the kids and for us the adults, few beers as well!

Compared with the overcrowded and overpriced Disney parks, I perceive at BG you get much more for your hard earned bucks...Of course get ready to walk (get your most comfortable pair of sneakers) and sweat since after all this is FL, but the experience for the whole family is unique and really one of those moments that live in the household memory forever!

For us FL residents I strongly recommend you to get the 'food pass'; you pay about $35 to $40 per person but you can eat limitless in most of the eateries at the park...And not only it means a free food with beverage and dessert:  if you are in a mode to have a few beers either at eateries or any of the myriad of kiosks throughout the park, on those you get 2 x 1...What else can you ask for? I feel a little sorry when see those tourists from South America spending $80.00 for a tray full of food when I walk besides with another and perhaps bigger food tray with two 16 oz beer cans or aluminum bottles and after seeing my food pass badge the cashiers announces: '$7.50'...You should see the expression in the faces of those poor tourists!

About the eateries or restaurants I specially recommend you the Zambia Smokehouse...The meat there is simply delicious and made to perfection!

With all honesty BG is really an entertainment park and if you visit Tampa make at least day and a half to get there...Despite how fast you walk, in a single day you do not cover the whole park...Also strongly suggests you to stay after dark for their fireworks and shows, both are great and really worth be seen.

Maybe the only drawback that if it is a thunderstorm nearby the park area, then attractions get into closed down mode...During our visit two years ago it happened once and although it reopened after just 1 hour, if you are in a tight time schedule might be a disadvantage...But I also consider the park must first and foremost seek the security and well being of its patrons so really have no objection to it...We spend that hour at the Serengeti Overlook, my daughter and BF eating some food, my half orange and yours truly sipping couple of beers each at its cozy and relaxing bar!

Make yourself a favor, visit Busch Gardens!!!!

Adult friendly indeed. Lots of cool roller coasters that help you lose your stomach. Shared lots of laughs with the very friendly giraffes. For $36 bucks you can go on a safari adventure and explore many endangered species. Short lines and not bombarded with impatient tourists. Busch Gardens was a breath of fresh after braving Walt Disney World. Also happy that Busch was open on Christmas day. Beer was very fresh. I did expect more beer stands around the park but can understand why there wasn't because Busch no longer owns it. Overall two late twenty-somethings had a blast!

Un excellent mix entre un parc d'attractions à sensation et un zoo.

Parcourez ce gigantesque parc grâce au téléphérique, en survolant girafes, singes et autres zèbres. Retrouvez-vous nez à nez avec des lamantins puis enchaînez avec des montagnes russes décoiffantes.

Que dire ...? Prévoir la journée pour bien en profiter!

I enjoy going to Busch Garden since they have many things to do here. Im personally not a huge fan of roller coasters but I love coming here to see the animals, coming to seasonal events and grab some churros.

Rides were fun...but they planned poorly...they have every restaurant shut down...and none of the employees know this.  They keep telling us such and such is still open...we rush over and they're closed.  It's almost like a big joke being played on the park's guests

Busch Gardens Tampa is amazing! We were there for two full days and utilized the Quick Queue on day two. Although the price is high (varies daily), it was worth it. We were able to ride Cheetah Hunt (our favorite coaster in the park) 10 times the second day. The Serengeti railway train is a MUST (a 40 minute trip all the way around). You gain fun facts from the funny tour guide and you get to see lots of animals without splurging for the safari. The park offers a diverse group of coasters that are high quality. Although we are coaster lovers, we had to check out Falcon's Fury. At over 300 ft tall, it is a must for those that love high thrills. Another thing to check out is the Cheetah Run that is over near the entrance of Cheetah Hunt. You get to see Cheetahs run across their habitat. It's quite the sight! Get there early so you can be up front by the fence. The park is filled with different types of animals all ages will enjoy. The theme is compatible to that of Disney. Lots of small details to look for. The food isn't overpriced and pretty good for theme park food. The Zagora Cafe in Morocco has a lot options, including vegetarian which is nice. The southwestern veggie wrap is very good. They offer healthy side options such as a piece of fruit or baby carrots. The staff is friendly and helpful all the way around. There's a free tram from the parking lot to the entrance. We would suggest booking a vacation package through the Busch Gardens site. We booked ours with the Hyatt hotel about a half mile from the park; definitely worth it. Can't wait to check out Busch Gardens Williamsburg!

Freak yeah! Busch Gardens is by far the best theme park and concept in the US. Don't get me wrong, it does not have the quantity like your Six Flags but definatly the quality. For those who haven't been there its a Six Flags mixed with the Zoo. There are animal exibits in between walking from attraction to attraction. The rides are awesome and intense. The price is no as bad as Disney parks but are more fun IMO. This location used to have a albino alligator in captivity that was probably the coolest thing ever!
Christmastown was disappointing. As well as the food options. Only one place to get cookies and milk come on. Dont go during the week. Wasted $200.

Average large theme park. Unfortunately, some of these places cannot handle large crowds during the holidays. I hate paying so much money to spend so much time in lines. I was going to give 4 stars, but 2 rides shut down for a period of time which means we wasted time standing in line or walking all the way to those rides. And we waited in line before the doors opened for a show and just missed getting in to see the show because the theater filled up. There weren't that many people ahead of us. 
We did get a great deal for tickets and meal plan. We are 2 adults and 2 children (although one is considered an adult at 11 years old). We all payed the adult with all day dining plan price - which through AAA was $99.99 per person. AAA does not charge tax or fees. All day dining at that price was worth it. Food is great for an amusement park. 
One other annoying thing...people who bring in their own food and make a mess eating while standing in line. A large group from an Eastern European country was eating cheetos and made a mess throughout the line - they left a trail. There needs to be better rules...maybe no eating in line. And the no cutting line rule needs to be enforced. 2 people shouldn't be in line for a 1/2 hour then the rest of their party show up and cut the line. So annoying! It was a fun day though and the kids had a great time. In the end, that's all that matters to me.

Amazing park! It is on the bigger side so if you come with people who cannot walk as much make sure you amke the necessary arrangements for them. However, they have teo ways in which you can move from one side of the park to the other without walking! The first one is ont heir air ride. The time I was here however the air ride stopped and we were stocked in the air for over 20 minutes. A totally scary experience, but at least we had a view of all their beautiful animals so that made it a lot better. They also have the train that goes around the park and stops in each area. Must go either with family or friends!
The best theme park for your money. You get animals, rides and free beer! It is the a great family place.

It was my first time at Busch gardens today. The only thing I knew about the park was that 1. It was owned by Seaworld and 2. There are often power outages. I was disappointed that parking was so expensive. 22 dollars for an uncovered lot? Cmon. Anyways we purchased the all day dine tickets on the internet so we paid 105 plus tax and got to eat and drink once every hour. I was highly underwhelmed by the food at Busch Gardens. The Zambia smokehouse brisket was like beef jerky. Very dry and cold. The chicken and the sausage were both okay but the chicken was dry. The carrot cake is okay, not great, but decent. The french fries were the best thing I had while there. 
If you have a wrist band it's BOGO beers, including craft beers! That was a huge plus in my book since it makes each beer about 4.50. I was a little bummed when I walked up to the entrance and 2 rides were listed as closed. As I walked through the park looking at the animals I realized none of the rides were operational. There was a power outage and the rides were closed for quite some time. When I was able to ride rollercoasters I was pleasantly surprised at how short the lines were. The park as a whole was relatively empty. I will say Montu, Cheetah Hunt, and the Shieka were my favorite 3 rides. Cobra's curse was boring and short. The inside waiting area was neat though. The Shieka kept breaking down throughout the day and I'm not sure why. I was also in line for the Montu 30 minutes before closing and they shut it down for "technical difficulties." It just seemed like the rides kept breaking and were inconsistent. The reason I gave it 4 stars is because I LOVED the animal exhibits. I was not expecting to see so many animals! I was able to see the animals closer than I have in any zoo! White tigers, hippos, kangaroos, etc. they were all great. I wanted to do the safari in the truck but it's an extra fee to do. :( I feel like that should have been included. Overall, I was surprised with Busch Gardens and would go back. I'm just glad the park was empty and we could walk right up to the coasters

We got the multi-park pass (unlimited visit for 14 days) to Busch Gardens, SeaWorld and Aquatica. It was a good deal. We ended up visited each park twice and enjoy every bit of it.

Busch Gardens has a lot of awesome rides. The crazy roller-coasters are the most fun in the park... and there are so many of them. So, plan in advance -- especially in peak season when the lines are line. The park also has a lot of animals. So, if you have a teenager and a pre-schooler, you'll still be fine.

Dinning in the park is pretty limited. Check the show schedule. They offer shows AT dinning area. I also love the turkey legs. They are classic! 

Though Busch Garden is a great amusement park, I think the single day ticket price is way too much. I believe they set it so high to encourage you to get multi-day and multi-park passes -- which are much more reasonable.

Took our boys here as a test run to big rides and just were overwhelmed with the amazing park! 

Next time we are getting annual passes

I always love walking around this park...I was sad that the skyride and half if he railroad was out of commission at the same time, so we did some real looking around this time...thank goodness! 
You MUST do the safari (19.00 per person) that will take you out and around by the gazelle , rhinos and finally the GIraffe!!! We hand fed them pets then and took tons of pics with them- it was awesome!! 
I love the bird area ( feed the beautiful lorries) and would recommend the kangaroo feeding as well! I just loved to pet these animals:)

This place is sinking fast. Been a pass member for a few years with Busch Gardens and Adventure Island and every time we go it's worse and worse. The food is still amazing but the staff seem to get more and more clueless. One person says one thing and another gives completely different info. VERY slow food lines, staff always seems dumbfounded and confused. Howl-o-Scream gets less and less scary every year, Christmastown this year was an epic fail. Most of the lights weren't even on! Especially in front of Sheikra, it was completely dark!! No organization whatsoever. Bathrooms are nasty now. We're so VERY disappointed. The bad turn this place has taken, it used to be so great. I think we're going to cancel our annual pass membership and go to Universal. So sad.

Very fun time was had by all here. I never had a desire to go to this Busch Gardens as I am a huge fan of the one in Williamsburg, but this place gets it right. From being able to feed the parrots and kangaroos to watching all sorts of amazing animals, this place is much more than a regular theme park. The kids wanted to go on all the rides, but the animals held their attention just as much. The rides were fun, but if that's all you want to do, there are other place in Florida for that. I would come back again. This place was a lot of fun.

We have a home in Florida that we vacation every year. This was our first trip to Busch Gardens. Glad we went it was awesome. We did the Sunset Safari and got to feed giraffes. There is lots to do in Florida. Go to Busch Gardens you will Not be disappointed. The park was nice and clean and far less crowded than Disney World. Good food also we all enjoyed it a lot.
I go to Busch Gardens weekly to watch the Real  Music series. The shows are excellent.

Came to bush gardens for Halloween weekend. It was SO busy we had to park in another theme parks parking lot 2 miles away! I know its the Halloween event but seriously? FINALLY we get to the park and get on line to buy tickets. ONE HOUR just to buy tickets. more than half the people on line couldn't read english,only Spanish. They're 8 kids per family couldn't understand English either. 80 dollars later...I stand on a 25 min line to get 3 beers for my friends and I. $25!!! For 3 beers? Anyway, at least we were in the park ready to have fun. To our surprise EVERY ride AND haunted house is a 3 hour wait we decide to go on falcon fury in fear that we wouldn't have time to ride anything else. We were the NEXT ones to have our turn "technical difficulties" is announced for the ride! BS! Now I'm mad and back on line for another round of $25 beers for just 3 beers. After 5 min of planning we decided on shikra it was mathimaticly the only ride at this point that we could go on before closing. We wait 2 hrs on line. Were next to go on and AGIAN "this ride is having technical difficulties" we wait additional 30 min and FINALLY when on our first and last ride of the whole 5 hour evening. In short, I spent $130 to go on 1 roller coaster in the course of 5 hrs....there's WAY to many people moving into Florida! This never happened from the time I was 5 to 13 years old. WTF happened?!

As a Tampa girl it's always a must to visit Busch Gardens at least once a year. Christmas in my opinion is always the best time to go!
