Christmas town is awesome if you have a little one the wait for Santa might be 45-90 min wait depending on the day but the experience is so worth it. They make you feel like you have your own private and special moment with Santa and Mrs. Clause and they don't rush you out like most places do. Also free cookies!!! There's so many activities for the kids and play lands and then of course free beer and roller coasters for adults. What's not to love. If your not a local I don't recommend staying in a hotel close by because the neighborhood is sketchy but you defiantly should stop by and check it out. Parking is $20 but that's standard at any theme park these days.
Great place to go with the kids. There is always something going on. Currently they have the Christmas town theme and is open till 10pm

Wow!  Busch Gardens sold me per the ticket:
Length of stay ticket with All Day Dining.
I stayed for 4 nights and paid over $1,200 through Busch Gardens Vacations for budget hotel Hampton Inn and Suites.  Looked like an ok hotel until 2nd day when dead German cockroach was in bathroom (not a palmetto bug).
The cockroach was the icing on the cake as that day Busch Gardens told me that my tickets "Length of stay ticket with All Day Dining" only had 1 day of dining!  The night before I had noticed the first card given to me (which you get when you turn in your voucher at zone A) said only one Day Dining. I went to the service desk.  I was told by the Busch service desk that every day I needed to come up for that days dining ticket.  I was told the kiosk people did no know the system you had to look at the voucher number to read it correctly, but that everyone knew about this at the customer service desk and not to worry I had dining for every day due to what I purchased.  
The next day, no one knew.  Not only that Busch Gardens customer service desk in the park now said Busch had nothing to do with the ticket or hotel as 3rd party sellers (hotels) offered packages on their website where I purchased it, which was Busch Gardens Vacations!!!!  
On the bottom of my receipt it said sold and serviced by Busch Gardens Vacations.  I showed the "supervisor" she said no that's not true you have to clear this up with the hotel.  You really can't make this stuff up.  
I was starting to feel like Chevy Chase in Wally World. 
I called the number on my ticket receipt, and googled Busch Gardens Customer service.  No resolution. Numerous emails.
 Seriously, if they are correct it seems the way they named this package was deliberate, unfair, and deceptive business practices.  Oh, the funniest thing I was told was that if the Dining included was for more than 1 day the ticket would have read "Length of stay ticket with All Days Dining". Not correct English.  Really????
The food is pretty good.  What they resorted to in order to sell it to me is awful. The park and hotel are in a really sketchy area.  Told by front desk in hotel not to go out unless we took transportation as it was not safe.  Wow!  I was sick of Disney, but it is just looking better and better.
UPDATE- Busch Gardens honored the length of stay all day dining.  They sent vouchers for the days I was owed mid-day on 12/25.  I am changing my stars from 1 to 4 as that was the only problem I encountered.  Roller Coasters and animal interactions are amazing.  
Food on all day dining is good.  Being able to grab a bottle of water anytime at no charge is great, BOGO snacks nice.
The best food is found on upper floor of the Serengeti overlook restaurant.  Absolutely delicious turkey dinner on Xmas, not part of all day dining, buffet style, no beverage included. $26.99 per person

This is a great theme park but you have to be careful when to come. Obviously, it's Florida and scattered thunderstorms are a given especially over the summer. They shut down rides until the storm passes for the safety of the people, which I appreciate. Unfortunately, if thunderstorms persist, they don't give you a voucher to come another day so choose wisely when to visit. The day I went, there were also quite a few full trash bins, and I get it, a theme park gets busy but after waiting almost an hour to get on a ride and then get off the ride to see the same full trash cans was kind of unpleasant. Other then that, it was a fun time! Rides are as advertised and gift shops are clean!

I've gone to Busch Gardens once a year for the past several years and I love it! The park is beautiful and well maintained. Staff is friendly. The prices are a lot less exorbitant than prices at Disney and the park and atmosphere is more laid back. You can walk around and enjoy the animals and exhibits or go crazy on the roller coasters if you're into the rides. 

There's a tram to take you from the parking lot to the park. There used to be free beer school and unlimited beer if you were smart to hit up a variety of the bartenders but I believe you now have to pay. Darn! At least now I'm not running to the bathroom every 10 minutes from all the free beer. :)

Fun park for adults and kids. A lot less crowded than Disney and overall more enjoyable in my opinion. Fun decorations around Christmastime, too!

A solid 4 stars as the park has a little something for everyone...  While not as famous or as glamorous as its counterparks ;-) Busch Gardens delivers a fun all around experience.  For the adventure seekers, there are plenty of roller coasters to choose from, the waits ranged from 10 to 45 min, depending on the time of day and I last went on a Sunday.  The earlier you get their, the shorter the wait times are for everything (A somewhat obvious point that it is often easier said than done).  The one disappointing thing was the train (Serengeti Railway) that runs through the park is closed for repair and won't reopen till 2016.  It was something we found out only once we got there, no signs at the ticket counter, but is listed as close on their website. Having been to Busch Gardens years ago, I did recall the Railway was a cool train ride.  In terms of value, if you're local to Tampa Bay or fairly close, it makes sense to buy the Fun Pass or an Annual Pass instead of 1-day admission.  They've added enough special events that it makes it worthwhile to go 2-4 times a year.

This is probably my favorite animal theme park in the world. My favorite ride there is probably the Cheetah Hunt, it is so fun and it is pretty long for a roller coaster. My second favorite is Shakira because the drop is mind blowing. I would recommend this park for kids because there is so many children attractions and fun water rides. As I said before this is my favorite theme park ever.

As amusement parks go, it's one of the best. But it's def showing it age. Great rides and Animals, But long lines.  Several rides had "technical difficulties " and after long waits, we had to move on. This happen 3 times. Not ok. I'm so not an amusement park guy but the teenage daughters wanted to go. Let's meet at the beach instead.

Busch gardens is always a great time for family and friends to enjoy the scenery, animals, and of course, roller coasters. It's a very typical theme park vibe with overpriced gifts and long lines. The staff are pretty good at keeping everyone happy. Unfortunately, when things start to go bad, i.e a couple rides shut down for maintenance, no seems to be able to give you a good reason as to why. This was a very frustrating thing as a guest. Other than that the rest of the park was great. They offer good areas for adults and children. I always seem to feel as though there is always a ride down due to some sort of maintenance. I would love for one time all the rides are working properly.

A fun place to hang out for a day or two.  I'm not really much of a coaster person, I'm more of a slower paced kind of rides guy, and they had these here too.  I had no desire to do the cheetah hunt, but my bride gave me "The Look" that said I'd better do it.  So, fair being fair, the skyride was next.  The animal attractions were pretty cool, but the train not working on the day we visited was not cool.

Favorite theme park around ! Nice staff, understandable wait times, good food! Always festive and they rock it!
Howl-o-scream is always fun and Christmas town is beautiful every year. If I didn't work so much I'd go there every week!!! Definitely something to do when you want to have fun and quality family time!

We've been here numerous times with our kids and they love it. Busch Gardens features some of the best roller coasters anywhere. As a parent, I appreciate the reasonably priced meal plans. The food in the Busch Garden restaurants is actually pretty darn good.

Have to say this place is still one of the best there parks in this part of the country.  I'm a roller coaster fanatic, and was happy they are still adding rides, including the new Cheetah Hunt coaster-- it's suprisingly fast and long track. Sheikra is nuts also!!  We went early in the morning and didn't have to wait at all really, we rode the good coasters over and over. Compared to Islands of Adventure in Orlando, the Busch Gardens Tampa coasters are most intense and more of them.  The food was a bit better at Busch Gardens as well, if you are going to be there all day get the all day food and drink pass to save money. The Quick Queue premium pass is worth it on busy days. I can't wait to go back!!

Park was clean but employees very slow, unfriendly and some downright rude. We attended the food and wine event. Drinks were way overpriced with hardly any actual alcohol. Food was mediocre at best. Animal attractions were good and our friends enjoyed the roller coasters. I definitely recommend eating right before or after. It would've been nice had they had more maps in the park.

I love, love, love Busch Gardens! I've been here at all different times of the year and Amaya have a fantastic time. If I lived close is but an annual pass, no doubt about it. However, we only travel to the area a few times a year. We usually get the fun card. Parking rates seem to keep creeping up, most recently up to $18, yikes! Our most recent visit was today, a Tuesday, and it was a ghost town. No lines, period, for anything! We rode Cheetah Hunt, our favorite ride over and over with no wait! All employees were super friendly, and the light crowds made for a great time and gave us the ability todo a lot in a short amount of time. I really also enjoyed all the Christmas decorations that were up, so pretty. We've been to the evening Christmas town event before and it is quite a sight to see everything all in lights. My only complaint/gripe is the food, is not that great and pretty pricey. We usually prefer snacks over meals, so we can try a bunch of things. We'll be back :)

A definite bang for your buck! The ticket and annual pass is a deal. They offer so many ways to make it affordable for a real family. The food band is worth it if you are going to be there all day, but it pays for it self after two meals. The rides are amazing. And the wait times aren't that bad. They keep the line queues clean. The offer a zoo /theme park all in one. Grew up coming to Busch Gardens since the 90s. They've made some changes, some good and bad. But it's always a place that you can count on to have fun. Try the spicy chicken wrap amazing!!! And Kumba will always be a favorite of mine.

We were there on Feb 25th and had a great day as we were leaving one of the Genteman who was cleaning up was doing a great job and I stopped and thanked him.  He looked suprised that someone noticed I remember his name tag was Charles.   The whole park looks well maintained. But we did have tickets that had meals included and on our last meal of the day my wife's worked and mine did not.  With the people piled up behind I paid after the manager said she could not do anything

Hi! I love Bush Gardens! My dad once was laying down on a bench with no shoes on and Oscar the Grouch came and tried to take his shoes. I did not get to see because I was on the roller coaster, Air Grover

Love the dining plan deal they have! However I tried their HRD WTR drink in the front of the park at one of their stands and was disappointed that it was not found throughout the park. It was aggravating that I could not find it in the back of the park and kept having to walk to front to get it. They have beer all around the park but don't offer the same selections everywhere.

By far the worst theme park in Florida. They make you pay over $100 to get in then pay $20 for parking . Once you are in you try to go on to the rides most are down , why technical difficulties . This happened to me twice in one week. Horrible horrible park

I have been an annual pass holder since I moved to Florida 5 years ago and have never left the park so disappointed and upset with my experience. I took my daughter to ride on the elephant rump and was told by Troy that my daughter would not be able to get on the ride if she did not actually walk on her own an enter the ride. My daughter refused to go on the floor and walk on her own (which she has been doing since she is 11 months and now is 19). I told him several times she can walk she is just being shy. And he continued telling me she needed to walk herself in. He was not at all understanding or friendly. I kindly told him 'I cant force her to walk" and he did not understand or allowed her to ride. I talked to the manager in the area and didnt allow me either. She has been on that ride over 10 times and never has walked inside the ride on her own. What if my daughter was dissabled or had developmental delays (which she does not have)? That means Busch Gardens will not allow dissabled children on that ride?   
I also recommend that employees who work in the children area (Sesame Street) at least have some kind of understanding of how children behave.

We love Busch Gardens, usually long lines, but after Labor Day before Thanksgiving it's not too bad.  If you have kids I recommend getting the fun card for themand one adult getting an annual pass.  Annual passes are less that 20 a month, you get 10% off of everything, special pass member offers (bring a friend for free during your birthmonth, buy one get one free food, and much more) and you get free parking (which is 20 dollars), so if you go once a month or more you save on parking alone.  Park has rides for all ages, pre-K and up.  My 6 year old is able to ride 5 roller coasters (cheetah hunt, sand serpent, scorpion, flying grover, and cobras curse).  Food isn't too bad, but you can always leave the park to eat and come back (I would recommend if you do to eat on fowler or fletcher, the restaurants on Busch Blvd are always being closed down by health inspectors).

By far my favorite theme park of any. Its half rides, half zoo. It makes any day here fun and exciting. 

The park has so may rides. The newest rides are cobras curse (fun but not the best, its a roller coaster that spins and goes backwards), cheetah hunt ( the best ride ever, super fast...like a cheetah!), and falcons fury (goes up, faces you down, and drops you- best thrill of your life). There are several others, definitely enough to keep you busy.

Then there is the animals. So fun to see elephants, play with kangaroos, and look at many more. The grounds are so large, a lot of walking is involved. 

Now, i have visited busch gardens more times than I can count. Most recently, though, they added metal detectors. Lets say that they haven't gotten the flow yet, as it took forever for the line for those with bags to make it thru and enter the park. And I mean a longggg time. That needs to be reevaluated. 

Bottom line, if in the Tampa bay area, and you have a full day to spare, you won't be disappointed.

I haven't been here in over 30 years. A lot has changed.  The animal area seems so much smaller. There are a lot more roller coasters. The Quick Queue was well worth the extra money.  My brother, son & I had minimal wait times at all of the coasters. 

My dad had a blast. He did find a rest & recharge station to plug his scooter in for a quick recharge. 

We were disappointed in the photo key. There were no park personnel out taking pictures in the park other than when you walk in. I say it is not worth the extra money. 

The map of the park is terrible. You can never figure out where you are or where you need to be (I read maps for a living) . The downloadable app for smart phones is just as bad. If you click on an item it should take you to a map that is understandable. How about using GPS mapping? 

Overall is is worth the trip if you like amusement parks.

Busch Gardens is always a great place to spend the day.  They really have some great entertainment. But the thing that really upset me was NO PEPSI PRODUCTS. They took away our free beer tears ago. Now PEPSI ? Whats next ????. The good news is you can bring your Pepsi and they will even give you a cup of ice.. How nice

was here today from 7:45am-6:30pm, and loved it! I would HIGHLY recommend getting a quick queue pass as well as an all day dining deal. Both of these paid themselves off within ONE ride/meal. 

We did get lost trying to find our way back to an elephant insider tour and unfortunatley missed the tour, but the park was generous enough to refund us our money. I also HIGHLY recommend the serengeti safari... a giraffe LICKED MY FACE!!! So cool. (Yes I cleaned up afterwards) and the Common Zebras were beautiful! 

Overall, I loved my first time at Busch Gardens and loved seeing all of the animals from the kangaroos, to the lions, and even the huge variety of birds :)
Great place and is age appropriate to all. It is super fun and the lines aren't that long if you go on a weekday. But I do think the map of the park can be a lot more simple.

Love coming here with my family and friends.  The best days to come are during the week, no lines and the ride attendants will let you ride multiple times if there is no line! Our 4 year old is able to ride The Scorpion and The Cobra's Curse rollercoasters, as well as the river rapids, the flume log and ubanga banga bumper cars .. She is 43 inches tall, the requirement for these rides is 42in and on couple of occassions we were told she wasn't tall enough and had to explain she has been on numerous times, on one occassion we even had to ask for a supervisor which was a little frustrating but she was able to get on and all was well. Our favorite place to eat is the Smokehouse located by Sheikra, I highly recommend getting the all day dining pass if you are planning to eat more than once during the day, this allows you to get food once every hour including dessert, unlimited drinks and my husband's favorite.. buy one get one free beers ($8 a beer), dipping dots/funnel cakes etc. We enjoy all of the shows the park puts on. I love the Opening Night Critters in Pantopia theatre and our daughter loves the kiddie show in Sesame street. The Dragonfire grill also has lovely shows all of the time. My absolute favorite rides are Montu and Sheikra, hubby loves Falcon's Fury (I am too chicken) and Cheetah Hunt, which is awesome! The little ones get in free up to 3 years old and there is plenty to do! The Sesame Safari of Fun has many kid attractions, as well as an awesome bounce house our daughter loves! If you are coming with little ones I definitely recommend you take a left in the beginning of the park and start out with Sesame Street where most of the kiddie attractions are. See you there!!

The first thing we did was sit on the Gwazi!  I had never been on a roller coaster before.  It was a horrible experience for me.  I felt my heart would stop and closed my eyes till the end.  Never rode a big roller coaster after that.  They have a lot of thrilling rides like Montu - you hear people screaming for their lives at every corner.  The smaller ones like cheetah chaser, 2 water rides and the trolley that passes over the zoo were fun.   I enjoyed the little safari and we got pretty close to the rear end of a rhino on that one.  Its a big area and they have lots of species of birds and animals.  Food and water is a tad expensive like at other amusement parks.

Lines are very long. It took an hour an a half just to get into the park itself then the first ride my daughter and I chose that line took 2 hours and then the ride went down. Went to get some lunch and waited in another line for over 30 minutes to get $10 chicken tenders that most dive restaurants would sell for less than $4. 

This place is okay I suppose, if you have loads of patience I suppose. You might need a week here just to ride all the rides once each.

I really enjoyed this park! We went for our first time as a group. I'm happy we bought annual Florida passes because we plan to come back again and also to use it at other parks. My experience coming to this park was as a complete novice. Parking was $25 and filled up quickly! They don't seem to have enough handicapped and/or preferred parking. Come early if you fit into either of these two categories. I like that they have a tram system to take you from the parking lot to the park, however, I had a large stroller and there was no space to put it on the tram without taking up space for other riders. So we walked about 15 minutes to the entrance. At the entrance, as a first timer with annual passes, we were made to wait in line at booth B. I estimate that we waited in line for at least 1.5 hours!!! And we got there around noon. The park opens at 10am. I suggest to go early if you're trying to redeem your printed online passes and free kiddy passes! 
After we got our passes we were able to quickly go through security! A plus that there is a metal detector! The guards also look through bags! Good!
Once in the park, it was a joy! The only thing I didn't like was that to exit the park once you're ready to go, the options of where to walk is extremely limited! There's a good supply of bathrooms and rides! 
I had a good latter half of my day there! I recommend.

Busch Gardens is a nice and fun theme park. They have lots of rides and fun roller coasters. They also have shows for the people who don't ride rides. Another thing that makes this park unique is the wildlife. They have all diffeent kinds of animals and shows that you can learn more about them. There are games and the food is good. Even though it ks a little pricey just for the day, it is still definitly somewhere you'd want to check out if you haven't been.

In my opinion, this park isn't worth the money. The park lost electricity in part of the park and we cut our day short. The concessions are a joke. Not enough options and the lines were ridiculous, even at non meal times. There were a few good roller coasters, but not many other rides unless you have little kids. And be prepared to pay $25 to park.

Compared to the Disney Disasters it was an excellent experience. Arrived early and got right into the park. The wait lines were reasonable for the most part and my 10 yr old grandkids had a great time.

11/11 - Here again.   After last incident BG gave us skip the line passes.   Only good for one line jump per ride (not quick que unlimited).   We used them yesterday and it was an ok day.   Today the kids were in line for Cobras Curse.   Estimated wait showing?  65 mins.   Actually time? 2 hours 5mins!!!   Yes my children spend half a day waiting to ride a ride !!!!    Why?  Lightening?   ZERO.   It was Busch Gardens favorite recording "Due to technical difficulties".   

Yesterday they removed the Platinum parking without notice.   That was a total nightmare trying to navigate two handicapped folks about a mile to get into the park.   I sent a message to guest relations...   (nobody cares.).   We will purchase quick que unlimited for the kids tomorrow ($150.00 extra) because without it the Park is a complete waste of time.   Unless you want to spend all day waiting in line.   





Completely awful!!!!   I can understand weather but holy sh!t...    every single ride "Down for technical difficulties...".  Omg....   we've been here two days and our children have got on 3 rides.    Between weather and "technical difficulties."   We paid $1500 PLUS HOTEL for me, my husband, and 3 children.    This park has gone down hill BIGTIME!   

Also our kids went to get on the SHEIKRA and they were in the seat and the ride shut down.   The tech workers are there working within a few minutes but it too ma few hours.   They tried to go back and they were told NO too small.  I've posted photos.   It's close but NO....   

I am headed to customer service to voice my complaints and I bet they don't do crap!

This was so disappointing. I brought my 11 and 9 year old daughters here for a kick off of summer break. We have been here since 10 am and 4/4 rides so far have been closed. We waited for 75 minutes on cheetah hunt just to get seated then, have the ride shut down. Even the gondolas shut down. We bought the "food bracelet" just to wait in more lines (BG maybe do a fast track line for the all you can eat). On are way to the Congo , and all the water rides are now shut down. So 300+ dollars, and we rode the bumper cars.  Bush  Gardens get it together.

The selection at the Food and Wine fest is very diverse, but something can be found to meet many tastes. 
There's a unique variety of wine and beer selection that was intriguing. A red Zinfandel, wow, but not to my liking. 
This 8 week new festival brought out many great music acts, like Gavin DeGraw, Collective Soul and Kenny Rogers. Today's performer is Aloe Blacc. Don't really know his music but found a couple of songs on YouTube today. Excited to see what kind office performance he'll give. 
Not too rowdy and definite a family friendly event despite the additional alcohols options.

I attended a networking event at the Gwazi Pavilion Tent hosted by Emerge and the Chamber of Commerce. It was a beautiful event space, I had no idea something like this was available at Busch Gardens. It felt a little circus themed because it is a tent, colorful lights go up the ceiling and the cocktail tables all lit up different colors, with some of them having colorful balls as centerpieces. They had multiple unique catering stations set up and served a signature cocktail in a cool light up cup. They had a sloth and performers come in throughout the event. You can do a lot with the space, I recommend checking it out for large events/receptions/parties. We also got free admission into the park after.

In my opinion, this park isn't worth the money. The park lost electricity in part of the park and we cut our day short. The concessions are a joke. Not enough options and the lines were ridiculous, even at non meal times. There were a few good roller coasters, but not many other rides unless you have little kids. And be prepared to pay $25 to park.  Updated to 3 stars after the park addressed my concerns.

Completely awful!!!!   I can understand weather but holy sh!t...    every single ride "Down for technical difficulties...".  Omg....   we've been here two days and our children have got on 3 rides.    Between weather and "technical difficulties."   We paid $1500 PLUS HOTEL for me, my husband, and 3 children.    This park has gone down hill BIGTIME!   

Also our kids went to get on the SHEIKRA and they were in the seat and the ride shut down.   The tech workers are there working within a few minutes but it too ma few hours.   They tried to go back and they were told NO too small.  I've posted photos.   It's close but NO....   

I am headed to customer service to voice my complaints and I bet they don't do crap!

Busch Gardens reached out to me and now they will not return my emails.   Wow ....   awesome customer service....

The park has only 4 good roller coasters. It's a good place to go with little kids but not teenagers. I think it is ridiculous that the park closes at six. The best time to go there would be early in the morning. Really hard to find a park map even when you ask for help.  Hate the time, but you can have fun.

This review is specifically for Joseph/Enrique. My cousins and my very close friend and I all went to Busch gardens Tampa bay today. It was so fun, the thrill was amazing, as were the animals. We rode falcons fury, many times. While we about to get off the attraction, Joseph/enrique (a worker) was walking by, and we asked him if we could stay on the ride again and go again, he says "nah I don't like you guys" then goes "nah nah I'm just joking of course you can go again!!." That was the so nice of him! I really believe he should get a raise or be promoted!

I grew up in Orlando and, oddly, Busch Gardens was the theme park with the most cache and that my friends and I loved.  Maybe it was because it was more of an adventure driving over to Tampa than to the other side of town or maybe it was because Orlando-Metro schoolkids went to every Orlando theme park on field trips all the time.  For me personally, I think it was the animals and rollercoasters. Long before Islands of Adventure or Animal Kindgom, Busch Gardens was THE place to go.  I celebrated a birthday here circa 1986, came over on day trips in high school, had an annual pass all through my college career in Sarasota, and have continued to love this park after settling in the Tampa area.  I think there are three or four main reasons Busch Gardens has withstood the test of time and why it has been a solid FIVE star experience for me for nearly 30 years.

#1 - The Animals - Busch Gardens Tampa is African themed and has an amazing collection of animals from around the world.  The animal exhibits are immersive and tucked into the Florida landscape making the park experience one of exploration and discovery for guests.  The park is laid out in winding paths and little nooks and around every corner there is a new exhibit or animal showcase.  I had a lovely day at the park with my (then 80-something) Grandfather where the only things we did were the animal exhibits and shows.  It was a full and fun day and we really enjoyed checking out all the exhibits.  One of my favorites has always been the "caves" - an area near Crown Colony with bats, snakes, and all sorts of awesome creepy crawlies.  I also really appreciate Busch Gardens commitment to education and conversation.  They had natural and large exhibit spaces long before that became the standard and the animal shows have always been very well done.

#2 - The Rides - While there are other parks with roller coasters now, Busch Gardens still has the claim to fame with the most varied and largest number of coasters in Florida.  Many may not remember it now, but Kumba was the first monster steel coaster in Florida, Montu was the first inverted, and SheiKra was the first with that thrilling death drop.  As time has gone on, Busch Gardens has phased out some of the more carnival-type rides (which makes me sad) and the amazing monorail (not so much a ride as a great way to see the Serengeti animals but still awesome).  But they still have the SkyWay buckets, the train, and a few other classics.  Timbuktu still has a number of cool, smaller rides like the Phoenix (the upside down ship) and cool, spinny things (the Sandstorm?).  

#3 - Great Deals for Locals - Busch Gardens has kept their pricing competitive against the big boys in Orlando, but more importantly, they have offered the absolute best deals for Florida Residents and locals of any of the parks for over 20 years.  With Annual Passes only $10-20 more than a 1 Day Admission, BG has kept me coming back again and again for special events like their concerts and amazing entertainment options.  (Can I mention how mad I am at myself that I never caught the Dance/Tango show before it departed for a still continuing run on Broadway?)  It seems like Disney, Universal and the rest draw so many tourists that they have not always been good about offering great deals to keep locals coming back throughout the year.  Sure, there are whole collections of parks up there, but I still don't have $400+ per person to blow on passes with tons of exclusions and blackout dates and no good options for free parking.  

#4  - Smart Park Design - Busch Gardens is a compact little gem but the best thing about the park design is that it is NOT a sea of endless concrete.  Florida only has 2 temperatures - hot and "OMG, I'm dying it's so hot".  Unlike any of the other parks I can think of, BG has always had trees, shaded spots, and the cooling help of water rides and misters.  It seems odd to wax poetic about the beauty of smart Florida landscaping, but BG does a great job of presenting a living, breathing, growing park experience with lovely flowering plants, trees, and native foliage.  I've found it to be the most pleasant of the parks when it comes to walking around all day.

Overall - BG is still my top pick of all the parks.  Good rides, wonderful animal exhibits and pretty good food for a theme park.  Word to the wise - Always eat at the Crown Colony Restaurant (not the cafeteria downstairs).  Sure, lunch for one will run you $16-20 with tip, but two words make it worth it - FREE REFILLS.  After a few times of sitting on the shady verandah overlooking the Serengeti exhibit, guzzling glass after glass of iced tea while giraffes wandered by - I was hooked.

Very bad experience. This goes out to anyone that has children with autism especially...they use the pathetic card where you have to get a "time" to come back. Anyone that has a child with autism understands that this is not helping whatsoever. Autistic children don't understand or tolerate waiting or crowds. We would get a time and return at given time only to turn us away because the ride was closed. This happened at least SIX TIMES. We arrived at the park at 10:00 amand by the end of the evening only rode 3 rides the entire day because they kept turning us away. We spent over $300 to ride THREE RIDES. Needless to say we will not be returning to Busch Gardens.

I've been here a few times but was severely disappointed during this trip. Many rides were shut down. I understand that it is slow season and there is maintenance to be done and new attractions to build, however, it would be nice to be made aware of this upon entering park. In addition to this, two different drink/food huts had items sold at a different price as advertised. When asked the reason for this deception I was told by one employees that the prices had gone up and it(the sign) hadn't been changed in forever. While all together I only had to pay a whopping 5 or so dollars more than shown, it's was the lack of consideration I found most annoying.

Beware of upgrading current passes. Busch Gardens will not offer proration of what you paid on your current pass when you upgrade. You essentially have to pay for both. Only buy an upgraded pass AFTER your current pass expired. Also, because of the nature of legal contracts, read the terms and conditions fully. You will also be charged a service fee for online and phone purchases. I only learned all this after changing our annual 3 park passes to Platinum passes.

Hands down this is one of my favorite parks.  The mix of a theme park and the  zoo makes this place awesome. This is definitely a family park with a fair amount of rides for old and young. The parks rides are not as modern as some of the popular parks but still a great place to have fun.  We were able to see most of the animals and ride the big attractions.  We did purchase the food card for a discount of purchases in advance.  The food was terrible and it was a complete waste of money. Unfortunately even in June the park didn't open until 10:00 am and closed at 6:00 pm.  Most of the restaurants didn't open until 11:00 am and closed at 5:00 pm.  We found it difficult to take advantage of the food, ride the rides and see the animals.  If you are considering food pass please consider the hours of the park.  Other than that we had a great time.

First time ever visiting this park, it wasn't to crowded. The all you can eat buffet was worth the $20. The reason for 3 stars, we had a group of guys cut in front of us to join some friends after we had already waited over 45mins. Other people reported it to staff and they said that they will call a supervisor. The group began harassing everyone they cut so another person went and complained again. Finally a supervisor Lexxie came we explained what happened, she went and talked to them. One female turned around and said your stupid to some ladies in front of us, some of the guys were even giving dirty looks to all of us behind them. Of course they said they were already there and made some excuse. She did nothing basically and said sorry. Why post signs about cutting when you do nothing.

During my only visit to Busch Gardens my family was in line for a rafting ride when someone pointed out approximately 20 ducklings swimming desperately around the ramp that brings the raft up to be loaded. The were being sucked in and then pushed back out by the current and water pump. After a very very lame and 20 second attempt to capture the ducks in a net for safety, they proceeded to run the ducks over with the next raft in order to keep the ride running. Since this was a family friendly ride children and adults alike were witness to this event and then saw the dead duckling bodies floating away. We immediately left after telling park customer service what had happened. I will never go back and will be sure to tell anyone who mentions Busch Gardens. For a park that claims to help animals its pathetic that this has happened. Even small non endangered animals should matter. Sickening.
Jan 2019- The entire Park had only 2 open rides because everything was down for maintenance. Don't waste your time coming from Orlando or anywhere further than local neighborhoods. Very disappointed

They need to do something so that you are not in line for an hour at the entrance of the park near holidays. It's due time for them to renovate a bunch of stuff too. It just simply cannot be that crowded. Unacceptable.

I'll say right out that it's hard for me to give a full review of this park as I'm six months pregnant and was not able to enjoy any of the rides (unless you count the train) so I can't say if the rides were good or the lines were long. I will say that I am as definitely bummed I couldn't ride anything cause they all looked great. 

I did get to see the ice skating show and the "critters inn" show and both were cute. I also enjoyed all the animals I got to see. 

The only other thing I did was eat. There's no food I would recommend as it was all your typical amusement park food and nothing was "good" although I didn't have anything that i would call bad. What I would definitely recommend, though, is the all you can eat pass which allows you one entree, a drink, and a side or a dessert once an hour. This is definitely the best way to go. It must have saved me $60 at least. You also get unlimited drinks.

What I would not recommend, though, is coming here while pregnant. I came to Florida with nine other people and most of them really wanted to go. Thankfully my husband and his sister don't like rides so they kept me company all day and we went and did the above mentioned. I would say if don't like rides or can't enjoy them - save your $100+ and go to a zoo or something. But if you're not in that group - it might be worth it.

Busch Gardens was awesome!! We rode on all roller coasters!! The best one was SheiKra & Montu!! We rode SheiKra twice.. Scary as hell but so much fun!! Can't wait for Cheetah, opening May 2011.. Will return..

We went for the food and wine festival.  There was a lot of good wine, but not enough food choices.  The festival was set up amongst the rides.  Most of the adult rides are roller coaster types.  The piped in music was awful.  There are some nice topiary, but 5-6 topiary displays are not a "Garden."  Lots of maneuvering among baby carriages and groups blocking the middle of the too-small walkways.  No Clydesdale horses any more!  Save your money and go to Islands of Adventure in Orlando, which is much more fun.

The Safari was an amazing experience. The tour guides were very knowledgeable and did a good job. Kyle, our driver, made sure we had every chance possible to feed the giraffes and we did!!!! Got some amazing pictures and made memories for life. My son had the time of his life and can't wait to go back. Thank you!!!

Hands down 1 of the best family vacations you will have. There is something for everyone to enjoy here. 

This was my 1st trip to Busch Gardens Tampa. Having visited the location in Williamsburg,  I decided this was the perfect plan to celebrate my daughter's 5th birthday.  We stayed nearby with Family just outside of Tampa so lodging costs were not a issue. The park is just 30 minutes from our family's home. Tampa can come off very comparable to some areas of Miami and East New York in  Brooklyn once you arrive. Busch Blvd has alot of fried chicken restaurants, Beauty supply stores and pawn shops. Don't let that discourage you. 

Once you arrive in the parking lot, I advise you to park in Area C or F for Flamingo. This will be a easier walk once entering and exiting the shuttle buses. The shuttle buses will bring you over to the main entrance of the park. If you're smart youl have purchased tickets by using your AAA Discount prior to arriving. You are greeted and asked to scan your ticket and be finger scanned into their system. There are no tacky wrist bracelets. Once you get into the park, I advise that you board the Serengeti Express Train for a full tour and easy access to all areas of the park. The park is African and Asian themed. 

There are areas if the park designated for children and the rest is for teens and adults. There are family rides such as the sky ride and sand serpent roller coaster. The Sesame Street Safari themed park features Sesame Live Theatre, Water areas for the small ones equipped with tipping buckets and sprinklers. No water rides. This is something Busch should consider. Bring on the water slides. I was disappointed that the rides were so limited for the younger crowd at Sesame Safari. My daughter enjoyed herself regardless. The Air Grover is a safe and fun roller coaster for kids under 7. The take photos of you while you ride. TIP: sit in front for a good shot. 

The rest of the park features beautiful landscape, wild animals and thrilling rides such as Cheetah Hunt, Cobra ' s Curse and my favorite Sheikra!!!!
A coaster that sends you upside down around and through water. Even onlookers get wet!!!!!!!!

The food here was very good. Be sure to buy a souvenir cup for free refills throughout the day and try the craft beer and fresh pretzels in Pantopia. From BBQ ribs freshly charred on wood fire to chicken salad. They have it all.

One of my favorite theme parks! This is the place to go if you're a roller coaster junkie like me. So many big rides and it's not crazy crowded like Disney World or Harry Potter World. Plus, there are animals in the park! A zoo and an amusement park all in one. What more could you ask for?

The roller coasters were fun. The animals were depressing. Giraffes seem to have comfortable space and the hippopotamus was the only active animal who was swimming. Kangaroos are about 15 or more in a pen not big enough for them to hop around. They were all laying around and seemed to be sedated with the exception of one who was interacting with a child that was feeding it. The fence was only about 3 1/2 to 4 feet high while this breed of kangaroo can jump as high as six feet. This makes no sense to me how they can have 15 
kangaroos, possibly more without any of them jumping over the fence.
recommended for family bonding activity, or group activity, don't take your date here if you don't want her to find out you have body odor.

I can't believe I am saying this but I find myself liking Busch Gardens Tampa Bay better than Disney World! Maybe it's because it's less crowded and they give 2 free beers to adults. My kids actually enjoyed it more too. No tantrums! Their Sesame Place area is so cute! It brought back some nostalgia for me because I grew up watching this show so to hear the soundtrack while we're coming on the kid's rides here was so touching to me.

Totally disappointed in how they treat annual pass holders who lost their pass. They let you go online and reprint your payment voucher, HOWEVER they do not forewarn you that you now have to go stand in the 1 hour and still waiting full service line. You want me to pay to come all year but you don't treat me like a member with benefits Customer service FAIL! Just tell me upfront that I will have to go through the crazy long wait first. Don't let me reprint my original pass and still sow I can go to the self service kiosk. Empower your staff who are assisting at the kiosk to make the appropriate adjustments. No just to saw OH WELL go get in the crazy long wait.
Love it here. If you enjoy roller coasters you will love this park. I recommend getting an annual pass. It is definitely worth the money
Tried to renew my annual pass over the phone. They had a wait time for over 200 minutes three days in a row. I like Busch Gardens but I ended up as a Disney pass holder.

I attended a networking event at the Gwazi Pavilion Tent hosted by Emerge and the Chamber of Commerce. It was a beautiful event space, I had no idea something like this was available at Busch Gardens. It felt a little circus themed because it is a tent, colorful lights go up the ceiling and the cocktail tables all lit up different colors, with some of them having colorful balls as centerpieces. They had multiple unique catering stations set up and served a signature cocktail in a cool light up cup. They had a sloth and performers come in throughout the event. You can do a lot with the space, I recommend checking it out for large events/receptions/parties. We also got free admission into the park after .

First visit to the park.  In this review I will provide you with Pros and Cons.  Cost was per person $100 and parking $25.00.. just for a visit to the park came to $225.00.   There is a trolley/train that takes you (free of charge) to the park from the parking lot.  This was great because the entrance to the park wasn't that close by.
We arrived as soon as the park opened which we are so glad we did. Once the crowd rolls in - long lines etc. Arriving early gave us time to explore the park. I loved the bird watching and all the charming landscape throughout the park.   Sheikra was the first ride. No purses even little ones- must put in a locker which was close by. The lockers are close to the rides but a big pain in the butt.   I get the reasoning but I purposely carried a small shoulder/sling bag which nothing would have came out of it on the ride but rules are rules.   Sheikra was a blast.. dive coaster.. loved it!! I recommend the front seat.   Since it was early there wasn't a wait for the ride which was great.  We then walked around and decided on the Sky Ride.. which are those cable cars that take you from one area of the park to another.   I am afraid of heights and it wasn't too bad I was able to ride it.  By the time we got off that ride - all the rides had long lines all ready and it wasn't even noon!!!  We decided to wait for Cobra's Curse.. the wait was only 60 minutes which was shorter than most. There were a lot of children in line so we were thinking the coaster might be more mild.  Its pretty neat though - when you get into your car - you are taken up by an elevator lift and then down little hill and the cars spin - you aren't facing forward. Then the cars go backwards.  It's a different type of ride - but was over in less than a minute.   The going backwards part made me sick to my stomach.

PROS:  I loved the shops within the park and enjoyed picking up some souvenir items.  The park is well taken care of and its enjoyable just to walk around.  I liked the fact that restrooms were all over the place.   The Trolley that pick you up at the parking lot is nice since you have to pay $25 to park at least you get something out of it. 

CONS:  When it came lunch time.. we couldn't find a place to eat that didn't have over an hour wait?  I would have settled for a soft pretzel at stand or something but there wasn't much offering food- a café and the main hall near the entrance to the park.  The lines are insanely long.   this really annoyed me. We had to leave early before we starved to death.   I gave up and we even waited a little bit at the café but the line didn't move!?  I could see the food in the distance but wasn't moving. Why on earth is there only a few places within the park to grab a bite to eat! ?? It was packed - and so crowded.   It was an expensive trip to the park and we didn't even get a chance to experience the food because the lines were crazy long even to eat.    What about a gyro stand or sell soft pretzels - something?  

Its great that maps of the park were provided to help you get around but they weren't entirely accurate.  We kept feeling like we were trapped.. and things didn't appear as they should of according to the map.   That grew old - and annoying real fast.  

Visiting this park made me miss my good old hometown amusement parks in PA...  you don't have to wait an hour to eat!

This is probably my worst trip ever, from beginning to the end, was given very hard time up front by ticket counter lady even though we had it pre booked it, couldn't find it, then supervisor was even worst that he had very rude attitude also threatened us that he makes sure we will not be able to enter park, where me and my husband were trying to explain him nicely that our other friends had Similar booking went to other counter , and they had no issues with . He was not helpful in any ways and his name was Edgar. He was extremely rude to us. It wasted our 2 hours. We drove 5 hours from ga, last night and had to drive back after park but apparently it was after 12 and still no resolution. After we went inside park and went to safari counter that lady took 2 seconds and was able to locate our booking. Kids were very upset (age8,9 and 13) that it took us longer to go inside and and not having enough time inside the park..

Okay so first of all this was our first time here traveling with s 14 year ild; 3 and 2 year old. It was about 90 degrees. Getting to the park we hit normal amount of traffic as we approached. Parking situation was a hot mess there's about 6 windows to pay for parking but it turns into 2 lanes of traffic with very little guidance. I have preferred parking they claimed there wasn't any but we walked by there and there were about four rows empty. We parked in the back where the first tram stop is parking like Disney but not a lot of guidance people were parking wherever. Asked the girl trying to guide traffic where the park was she said less than a mile from the parking but I could ride the team. Being that the tram is tiny and there were tons of people and we had a double stroller we elected to walk. The walk was ok not to bad there was some shade it was almost 11 am. Went through security and ticket scan quickly. Walked in then it's about another 10 min walk to the Sesame area which was our first stop. Stopped for our first refill of the day the soda machine was broken. This was the stand next to the ride which looks like little jets. The huele as very nice and we for icee. Walked to the Sesame Street area it's ok few kids rides with short waits but the rides are very old and ugly looking. Only a few kids are allowed on at the same time so it takes forever. The Sesame Street characters walked through the street and that was cool for the Kids. They rode all the rides and the bouncing thing which my two year old was to short for and he's 34 inches. We did all those rides and then we went to ride the train to see the animals. The train is not great it was very slow and there wasn't much to see. I would have rather walked and looked at the animals. The guy who narrates the train ride was not knowledgeable and not interesting. The animals were cool my kids enjoyed them. The food we did not have but we refilled a ton because of the what. All the machines were out of ice I stopped in four different locations no ice. The places all smelled rancid it was terrible. I would never eat there. If we go back I would only eat at one of the nicer restaurants. The staff also needs to be trained better there are many many people there that have no idea what's happening.

My husband is a huge roller coaster fanatic. I have a career that allows little time off and we spent months planning the best weekend for our "mini moon". We decided to leave Minnesota for Florida on a Thursday and go to Busch Gardens on the next day before heading back up to Orlando for the rest of the weekend to round out another park. My husband spent forever planning the perfect day in December that would have low wait times and be an overall great experience for us. WRONG. We showed up on Friday to be apologized to by every single worker we encountered because it was "Physics Day" AKA THOUSANDS of teenagers taking over the park. There was NO warning on the website as we planned our special day. Every ride we went on had smelly teenagers groping each other and making out during our waits in line. It was so disappointing. Even the restaurants were full of children.. it was like being in a high school cafeteria. We have been to many theme parks but I've never seen something like this. We finally bought the safari tickets for 30 minutes away from the teenagers and it was the best 30 minutes of our day. Thanks for the warning, Busch Gardens. The employees' multiple apologies spoke for themselves.

Took a girls trip to Tampa and had to save a day for Busch Gardens! Parking was easy and I greatly appreciated the trams taking you to the park. Of course you have to pay for parking which stinks but it feels like the norm now. We went on a Saturday and the lines and wait times for rides weren't unbearable as they can be at other parks. My only complaint is they definitely need to install more fans for those waiting in lines. Food and drinks are over priced too so try to be strategic.Their variety of roller-coasters truly makes the experience worthwhile. Can't wait to go back!

Came with my non-ride oriented family. It was OK. Part of a package, so no major loss, but would probably not do it again. We lapped the place in about three hours. Here's some random thoughts.

Busch gardens Tampa is squeezed into the middle of suburbia. Be aware that you will park in another block, due to the roads, and take a tram in. Allow for the time and be aware of the impact if you want to lunch away from the $10 fried meals. In the off season, one tram worked back and forth, so it took a while.

The park had a lot of great animal enclosures. The cheetah run was awesome. They really run! Most standard zoo fare is there. Did the rhino run which was pretty cheesy. Way too many scripted puns with little enthusiasm, way short, not much wildlife. They cut out parts some of the riders enjoyed a few years back.

The kids loved the rapids, but again nothing new there. Little maniacs also enjoyed putting in quarters to squirt the riders. However, they don't mark the jets to the buttons so watch someone first or plan to waste your first investment.

The advice here about the maze is really true. They make a significant effort that you don't easily find your way. Forget about even trying to find your way by map. The map will show one thoroughfare which is really a series of different paths. Go ahead and download a GPS Busch Gardens Guide. There's a free one that was amazing. The GPS enabled map was a god send. Even tracked ride times. Not really helpful to us, but maybe for you.

Really a let down from what we expected.  The roller coaster we were in line to ride broke down with no estimate for when it would be back in commission.  Many of the animal exhibits were not open. Also managed to see a cop take down a man who stole someone else's shoes.  

Went to have a fun day and ended up thinking, why is this place even open?  And considering the $100/day admission, it was not worth the price.  Just vastly disappointed.

Maybe it is because I am from the land of amusement parks (California), may be it's because Sea World ( the sister park to Bush Gardens) is better maintained.  I found the shows armature, the grounds tired and the park in need of some basic cleaning- also the food in the park was horrible (not that you go to an amusement park for the food...but you'd like it to be edible. The staff was not friendly & they appread annoyed if you asked them anything.   For the cost to get in, I'd drive to Orlando and pick any park there over his place
Perfect combination of animals and roller coasters. Went on a Monday and the lines for rides weren't bad at all.

Fantastic park with the best roller coasters ever. Just got an annual pass because of this! I would love to give 5 stars but the loading and unloading passengers system for some of the rides is pretty stupid. Otherwise park is clean, plenty to see for both kids and adults, and best value over Disney/Universal for the annual pass.

Great park!! I have been to the one in Williamsburg, Va (as I am from there originally), and this one is a lot better!!! Some rides are the same but the theme is more exciting here. The only drawback is the extreme heat during the summer. In the "cool zones", the water evaporated before the mist could even reach your head!!! But, the park can't control that so obviously I don't hold that against them!! Great rides, friendly staff, and just an overall good time!!
Busch Gardens is a gem!  Everyone within an hour or two of it should get passes.  Best theme park in Florida and an amazing deal for Florida Residents.
Fun place to go... the upscale restaurant on site... may need reservations on a busy Park day.

Spent 8 years in New Tampa, ten minutes from the park, so I bought the platinum family pass which includes free parking near the entrance to the park, and discounts on food, souvenirs, and special events like Howl-O-Scream.  Easily saved the extra cost in parking fees and time wasted waiting for the tram. 

I've done all the theme parks in Florida, but with the exception of The Wizarding World of Harry Potter, Busch Gardens is my favorite as a Florida resident. If you are willing to go on non-peak times, it's a quick walk to the front of the line for most rides, and the Halloween event is much more user friendly and affordable than the Universal Studios event which is way too crowded. 

The food, particularly the Zambia Smokehouse is very good, and you get a lot of it for the price--only Dollywood in Tennessee has better values. 

Love feeding the Kangaroos in the Australian section, and if you arrive in a slow day, you can get up close and personal with the various animals in Jamba Junction.

Very enjoyable experience at Busch Gardens.  All of the rides had less than 10 minute wait time for the majority of our day so there was really no need for the "quick queue" option on our tickets.  We opted for the online ticket purchase with an "all day dining" option that was around $15 more per ticket but it was well worth it.  If you eat one meal at the park while there, it pays for itself.  The kids had a great time at Sesame Street and thoroughly enjoyed the safari train ride viewing many of the park's animals.  Of all the theme parks we've been to over the years, I have to rate Busch gardens near the top on the overall experience.  The fellow patrons were not rude nor portrayed entitlement as we've seen elsewhere.  The employees seemed friendly and helpful, I'd venture to say they enjoy their jobs!  All in all, 5 star experience, hope to return again one day!

Known for their thrill rides and coasters, BG is much more than just another amusement park.  They have 250 different species of animals, many which are endangered, in a free range habitat area that alot of folks don't even bother going to see.  Living within a 20 min drive, I've been to this park many times over the years.  And I've enjoyed the shows, the themed events, Hollow scream, Christmas Town, the live shows etc, but I still love seeing all the African animals.  I think they have more animals than Lowry Park Zoo.  

I miss the old days when they were owned by Anheuser Busch and gave out free beer, enjoyed by many on a hot summer day.  I especially miss the Clydesdale horses, as that was always one of my favorite things to see in the park.  

My favorite ride in the park is the Cheetah Hunt coaster, a very smooth ride!  There are several water rides to cool your jets when the temps and humidity soar through the roof.  

They do allow water bottles so be sure to bring one.  The food is pretty standard fare, the animals seem well cared for and the humans are in abundance.  

There are many different options of tickets, if you are an out of towner and plan on visiting multiple sites, check out the City pass for some of the best deals out there.

We took at family vacation to Florida and spent 1.5 days at Busch Gardens. Overall, the experience was disorganized and many rides were not opened. 

Falcon Fury was supposed to open earlier this year & it has yet to open. The wooden roller coaster was closed both days we went to the park. 

When rides were open, the organization was lacking. Workers would let you through the entrance and this is where the organization ended. Riders went into whichever rows they felt like and people had to figure out how to manage riding with family members in different lines. If workers didn't allow so many people through at once, the system would work much better. 

My favorite ride was the Cheetah. It did not make one queasy but had quick bursts or speed with a few loops. Another exhilarating ride was the Sheikra. This ride takes you up, hangs you off the side, then drops you at 90 degrees!

My wife and I visited Busch Gardens today.  What can I say that hasn't been said before or will make ANY difference whatsoever with respect to how many people visit this park?

BUT...here's what I liked and didn't like, if anyone from management actually reads these reviews and GAS what I think (or what any reviewer thinks):

LIKED:
You can save $20/tkt if you buy online.
Frequent trams 
Opening Night Critters: AWESOME!
The shows are generally good
LOTS of animals to see (the cheetahs are my favorite)
Food is generally good
Shops have a good selection (I bought an awesome cheetah mug)
Bathrooms are cleaner than one would expect
Lines were short. Moved along at a steady pace
All employees were nice
Most things are easy to find

DISLIKED:
$18 to park.  NO NO NO NO NO. STOP IT.  It should either be FREE
to park or, at the MOST, $10. STOP BEING GREEDY.

Let people stay on the sky ride to get back to the area of the park they started the sky ride in, rather than forcing them to get off and stand in line to get back on.  We were in Pantopia and wanted to do the skyride just to do it and also to get some photos. We wanted to come right back to Pantopia for the critter show. NOPE. CANNOT DO IT. Must disembark near Egypt and stand in line to get back on to go back to Pantopia.  PLEASE STOP DOING THIS.  IT'S INCONVENIENT AND ANNOYING.

Congo River Rapids:  I was on this ride with 7 other people.  Only 3 people sitting together got soaked. The rest of us barely got wet. EVERYONE who rides this ride should get SOAKED.   LAME ride anyway.  Too calm, needs to be rougher.

The motown show is decent (the singing mostly) but needs to be improved. If you're going to have a bunch of people singing motown songs and dancing, add some scenery and lights and spectacle. That show needs a technical kick in the ass. Also, the asian guy on guitar is BORING. The other guy isn't much better.  They need to get into it more. You're not playing in the lounge at the Holiday Inn.


This is a good, fun park and I would recommend it to anyone.  But I think some improvements would be nice for everyone.

SUCKS!! Went 2x this week & they shut down EVERY ride w/any raindrop. Spent lots of $ on tix for 4 of us & never got to ride ANY ride! Today my family was in line for a coaster for over 3 hrs! Of course no refund. I know it's FL rainy season but sun was out, no rain, AND STILL no rides moving.
This place is fun  If u want to have a more fun time here get Game Cards,Preferred parking,Fun passes,in fact get the whole package it includes all the great stuff to have a superb time here

Second time here and absolutely aweful. Rides were fun and lines weren't too long. Maps were more confusing than helpful. The worst part was the -LARGE- groups of young kids from the local schools running around with -NO- supervision. The class of '19 should be embarrassed by their peers. I saw the same group(Yellow class of 19 shirts) trampling over people. Ran over older people and a person in a wheel chair. There was no need to run as fast as possible and push people out of the way to keep up. Cussing and inappropriate talk as loud as could be. Very, very bad experience with a child. Will not return. Try out Aquatica, Seaworld and Discovery Cove! Got them all as a package(including Bushe Gardens) and enjoyed them all. Went to Aquatica about 4 times now. Plan at least one more visit. Maybe this was just a bad day, or maybe the park should require school groups to be supervised. Not sure their policies but no employees ever stepped in to ask them to stop, either.

Why doesn't anyone in the park that works and is employed know anything about the park ??!!  I asked numerous workers about 5-7 happy hour advertised or the Thursday season pass holder got dog special ....train your people !!!!

One of Florida's lesser visited gems. Great park at decent admission prices and always a pleasure to visit. Just visited to attend a concert by Walk Off The Earth during the Food & Wine Festival and had a great time at both. The Concert venue is great once the sun goes down and there is plenty of up close general seating so there is really no need to pay for VIP seating.  The Food & Wine Festival is awesome and a great deal if you purchase the sampler lanyards.

Its quite interesting how this park evolved from beer promotional tool to a one of most the popular amusement park. We were here for 2 days and definitely needed the second day. During our visit toward the end of August I think they had just changed the hours of operation. Unlike Universal in Orlando they only opened from 10-6 even on weekends which was a bit of a bummer. Especially the weather at the time was always chaotic, the first day we visited maybe had torrent rain in the afternoon for couple of hours and most of the indoor shows we tried to get in were already filled given that this is primary an outdoors amusement park, they also seem to a bit slow in getting the rides back up once the rain stops.

However, they did have a 2 day admission for single day price around $80 online when I was booking my trip definitely helped offset the bad weathers and shorter hours. Below are the attractions we were able to visit in the 2 days here and of course spoils warning :)

-Rides 

Cheeta Hunt - By far the most popular ride while we were here, being that its closest roller coaster to the entrance and the longer ride time. This was the only ride where we had to wait more than 10-15 minutes. Definitely very fun and fast and does not drop very far making it more about speed than altitude. Unfortunately this ride was also the one with most problems. Twice while we're were waiting in line they had malfunctions and was not able to fix in short period of time. I would suggest visit first thing in the morning or before the park closes.

Sheikra - To be honest I was bit worried about the drop when I first saw the photos. Its definitely quite a nervous wreck that first time hanging by the ledge waiting for the drop. I would have to say first row does make quite a difference as you can see much more below you while waiting for that first drop. Much shorter ride time after the drop though but also shorter wait than the Cheeta Hunt. However this was the other ride we rode that encountered mechanical problems.

Falcon's Fury - We came to try this after Sheikra and at first I thought I was crazy to try such a high vertical drop. Again like Sheikra at the highest point it pauses for a moment and actually tilts the seat facing downward for you to see everything below! Quite an adrenaline rush indeed. The brake comes in approximately about 1/3 of the way toward the ground so its really only couple seconds of free fall if you're worried about the duration haha

Kumba - A bit rocky and bumpy ride compare to Cheeta Hunt, its located towards end of the park so much shorter lines. Compare to the flagship rides its a bit underwhelming but I think still fun

Scorpion - A much milder coaster compare to the other big boys, although it did go around 360 degree though I think this can be passed if you're stressed for time

Congo River Rapids - I'm not much fun for these water rides and this one wasn't much exception haha. Bit run of the mill raft ride with chances for people outside to spray you with some water. Glad this time it was sunny and my clothes dried quicker.

Seregenti Railway/Skyride - Both are great ways of getting awesome and scenic views of the large Serengenti open field plain that takes up 2/3 of the park. The train ride takes more time obviously but you get some nice photo opportunities. Definitely highly recommend to do both to help cutting down the walking time.

-Shows

Iceploration - My favourite indoor attraction and definitely a great way to rest your aching feet or avoid the rain. Very beautifully done stage and props with some animal actors included in the show! Even if you're not a fan of ice skating shows I think its worth it just to see the colorful and vivid arrays of costumes and arts.

Opening Night Critter - Its a very fun and cute trained animal show. In addition to the usual cats dogs and birds they even brought in a pony and kangaroo at one point. Perfect for kids and adults for some light-hearted humorous show.

Motor City Groove - We stopped by before leaving the park since the show time was right at 5:30. Quite talented singers and actually involves bigger crew than I thought with the band and dancers

In addition to the rides and shows the park also hosts a wide array of animal exhibits making this place a zoo and amusement park combined. I did notice the animals here definitely seem much more active compare to regular zoos. Plenty of chances to see them feed animals with guides answering questions. They also have a pretty big animal/vet center where you can actually see what goes during checkups.

The food here were pretty sub-par and the staff at the entrance does seem more strict about letting outside food as they check the bags more thoroughly compared to Universal but it could just be depending on the person. Despite some mechanical and weather setbacks overall the visit was great. With some proper preparations definitely can be a great memorable time here at Busch Gardens.

Fun theme park. The landscaping is beautiful, the roller coasters are large and in charge and the zoo life was spectacular to see. I was disappointed with the customer service of ride operators. Many were disgruntled and rude to us patrons. In the middle the kiddie log flume in Sesame Street Land the operators had a disagreement about their lunch break and who's would be covering it. Many other ride operators and food services workers were rude and what seemed displeased with their job. My daughter loves Elmo and whole cast did a wonderful job with the show/meet & greet. I am also disappointed at the traffic into the park. They need more bag check in kiosks and/or extra security to move guests more quickly into the park. Please remember to save yourself a little extra money, packing a few frozen water bottles. Fun theme park for those who can ride many rides, leave your newborns at home!!!

After reading a bunch of reviews about the park being run down, we disagree. We thought the park was very clean and well-kept. We took advantage of the later summer hours and so ate a couple of times and snacked. The all-day dining deal was well worth it. Bought one for each adult (family of 4) and we got the platters which had plenty of food for us and our 2 kids, who like to eat. We had a great time. The wait times were not bad for the rides. We got there early and closed it down. Did popular rides first and it was fine. Had a great time and we'll go back.

This was my first time coming to Busch Gardens as well as my 13 yr old son. We had a lot of fun. Plenty of shade and places to rest as well as shopping and dining to keep me occupied as I am not a big fan of roller coasters and more. Lines we not too long and my son and sister were able to most of what they wanted as far as rides go. I did go on the Congo Falls, the only type of rides I really don't mind doing. Yes, I got soaked. We spent most of the day here and only called it quits when my son go a little nauseated after too many rides. Parking is not too bad and they have trams that run from the park to the lots every ten minutes or so. Also, the park is not ridiculously huge but not small either. I was able to explore without getting tired or sore the next day... plus I got a lot of steps in! I scoped out some of the Food and Wine booths, that were not open (we were there on a Friday and F&W is Saturdays and Sundays only) and I was surprised by a lot of the offerings. (4 Ice Wines to get is double what is available at Epcot F&W.) The park is clean and there are a lot of warning signs that signify disruptive behavior isn't tolerated.
I love Busch gardens! It's very cheap and they have an awesome student discounted annual pass. The rides are great, lines are usually not that long and they have great shows. Just wish it was bigger

Had so much fun at this theme park. It's large and definitely need your comfy shoes. There is something for everyone in here. The food is just like any other theme park, expensive and just ok. 

I enjoyed The safari train watching the animals was fun.

The first time my family and I went to Busch Gardens. This is such an amazing park and with all day dining deal it was perfect. I would strongly recommend going to this park with your family and friends. The rides were incredible and the lines weren't even that long. I'm simply speechless.

My absolute fav theme park!! I love how laid back, and chill the park is compared to other parks here in FL. I don't recommend going on busy days, as you will wait in lines all day, but when you pick the day just right, you can avoid large crowds and quick wait times for rides without a quick queue pass. I definitely would recommend the All day dining pass! You will save lots of money on food this way, and get unlimited drinks all day, you can't beat that. Had a couple encounters with rude employees who didn't seem to care about the experience of guests (mostly at the food spots.) As a young adult with lots of energy and adrenaline to burn, this place is perfect to bring a group of friends and jump on and off roller coasters all day. For the cherry on top, to relax in between rides, it's really fun to experience the animals!
The family and I really enjoy spending time in the animal preserve. The girls get to feed many different animals

This place is probably the best amusement park I've ever been to. However, their pricing has become outrageous over the years and I didn't buy a ticket this year even though I really want to. Otherwise 5 stars.

Visited on 5/19/15.  Did not ride any of the roller coasters, but did notice that a few were not operating.  The Safari Train will not be operational until sometime in 2016, so the only way to see the animals in that area of the park is from the Sky Ride or take the Safari Adventure - an approximate 30 minute open truck ride costing $30/pp.  You do get to pet and feed a giraffe, if they approach the vehicle. (Pavlov's conditioned response...they associate the truck with food, so they show up). Didn't find the "guide" to be overwhelming knowledgeable; was rather boring. But the giraffe was beautiful.  The big cats were out and about.  Plenty of shady areas for cooling down. Concessions are ridiculously overpriced, but which parks aren't?

We got passes to go to Sea World, Aquatica, and Busch Gardens.   Adventure Island was supposed to be open and is closed.   This leg of our trip was a complete waste of time and money.  This is our least favorite park.   Had we known what Busch Gardens was like we would have skipped it and went to the beach instead.  Highly disappointed with how run down it is.  The rides are need to be updated and painted.   The food is awful and expensive.   The animal exhibits are fair but we have an amazing zoo in our town so others may feel differently.   If you are planning a trip my suggestion is to do Sea World, Aquatica, and Discovery Cove.   In my opinion it is a better use of time and money.   Busch Gardens should do everyone a favor and close down.
I go to this place 3 months ago and dont call my attention for me this place dont change since 1975 my last time is a lot of empty spaces  that nothing is call my attention.

My two favorite things are animals and amusement parks and this place has both! 

Busch Gardens participates in the "Waves of Honor" program which allows active duty military members to enter for free once a year and bring up to 3 family members free of charge.  Kudos to you, Busch Gardens, for supporting our troops!  So generous! 

Visited on 12/22/2017 and we got there about 30 minutes before the park opened.  If you have kids and a stroller I strongly recommend telling the people who take up the money for parking and they'll give you a special tag to put in your windshield and you can park right in front of the entrance.  (VIP status, yo!)  Parking was $20 and they take cash or cards.  

The park is pretty big and it's nice-ish.  It ain't no Disney but at least it's clean and has plenty of employees.  Prices are outlandish but that's to be expected.  There is money-gouging at every opportunity but that'll be no surprise to anybody.  

We had my little nugget with us so no roller coasters but there was plenty to do between seeing the animals and playing in the huge children's area.  Be sure to ride the train that goes through the animal park and the ski lift thingy cuz those were both awesome.  My kiddo loved walking through the bird habitat and feeding the parrots.  For $7 they'll give you a tiny cup of nectar and the birds go ape shit for it.  

My favorite thing in the park was the show "Opening Night Critters" which was indoors in a nice air conditioned theater.  The show itself was cheesy but they had about a hundred animals doing tricks and I almost lost my mind.  I found myself squealing with delight more than once.  Definitely do not miss this show if you love animals!  

All of the food I tried was very *meh* and incredibly overpriced.  If you are a bottomless pit like a camel like I am you wanna get the souvenir cup because the refills are just .99 cents.   We ate at the "Dragon Fire Grill" because it's like a big food court indoors and there's a ton of tables and a show playing while you eat.  We ate rotisserie chicken and watched a wonderful Christmas play and I loved it.  

It was definitely way cooler than I expected.

I grew up near the Orlando area, so for most of my life I was only familiar with Disney and Universal parks.
