That being said, if you are looking for more thrilling attractions, then Tampa is where to be. It is still very much a family-oriented theme park, but the roller coasters are unmatched in the state of Florida. My personal favorites are Kumba, Cheetah Hunt, and Cobra's Curse. If you are looking for more intense thrills, I would recommend Sheikra and Falcon's Fury.

My favorite part about the park however, has to be the animals. The park does not look that big from the outside but once you are inside those walls, there is way more space than expected for the animals. Of course it is not as good as the wild, but they seem content. I really enjoy walking around and viewing each exhibit. There is even an overlook near Cheetah Hunt where you can view many of them in wide open areas. 

I've been a few times since moving to Tampa which means I have been able to visit during their holiday/ special occasions. I highly recommend their food and wine festival during the spring time. We did not get the food passport which was a big mistake on our part. The food really adds up and with the passport you are able to keep track on how much you spend at a time. I have also been to their 
Howl-O-Scream event and their Christmas town event as well. If you like Halloween Horror nights at Universal, but do not like the long waits and expensive tickets, then I think Howl-O-Scream is a good alternative. It is cheaper and the lines are not as long (also you can ride the rides during and you have a better variety in my opinion). Their Christmas town is also a nice alternative to Christmas at Disney. Of course it is hard to compete with the House of Mouse, but I think Busch Gardens puts up a good fight. Also as a nice surprise, when we went to Christmas town it did rain and some rides closed every now and again but Busch Gardens has a policy where if the weather affects your visit you can go to customer service and get a free replacement ticket good for a year from the day you visited. 

All in all, if you live in the Tampa area or you are visiting, do not sleep on Busch Gardens. It just might be the alternative to the rather pricier Orlando parks you are looking for!

I haven't been here since I was a child and never at the one in Florida. The day started great no line  and we were actually able to get 50% off our tickets and stroller parking! Fourth if July weekend it was so hot but not extrememy busy. We had a large group and only got to get on 2 rides because of heat lightening! I can understand the delay and risk but I was expecting to get tickets to come back the next day for all the hassle. I would have only given them 3 stars but we happened to be there so long (10am - 4pm) my sister fainted!! Thank God within 3 min someone was there helping us. They were fast and nice and very attentive and I couldn't have been more thankful. It never rained just extremely hot but I'm hoping when we return we will be able to ride all the rides with no weather set backs.

The roller coasters were amazing. As was the process to retrieve our annual pass purchased online. 

BUT.... My three star review comes from the absolutely terrible customer service. The customer service is terrible to the point where I actually regret buying an annual pass. 

First, when we took our dogs to the kennel... there was no one at the front desk. Which is okay, but what wasn't was the fact that there was a worker sitting inside the dog kennel waiting area on the phone. The worker never even asked if we needed help. 

Second, when ordering food and drink refills. Workers would not know answers to questions about the menu. Workers chatting with friends would blatantly ignore customers, etc. 

If you want to fix Busch Gardens, fixing the customer service is a must. We went to Disney yesterday, and the difference in the customer service is appalling. Busch Gardens has enormous potential and amazing rides, but rude workers will kill a good time, every time.

A great deal to get the year pass in the beginning of the year when its the regular ticket price. A nice location and venue to just pop over for an afternoon taking a half day at work or something. Go over on a hot afternoon and hit the water rides. :)

A very fun filled family theme park. Been going for years. My favorite ride is the phoenix....idc how many new rides they introduce. The cheetah chase is amazing as well. A lot of great memories here. I am so happy to say that my daughter will be visiting for the first time soon.

We ordered tickets through Groupon so we went to the ticketing counter to ask the staff how to use our vouchers. We stood in line and not once, not twice, not three times, but FOUR times we stepped up for our turn to a window after the last customer stepped away and they turned their sign around and said they were closed and to go to another window. They were very rude and would just simply point to their sign instead of helping us. Once we got in to the park it was very hard to find our way around. They only have maps at the front entrance so don't forget to grab one on the way in. The signs were very vague and we had a hard time finding the things we wanted to do. Stood in line for rides and they would get shut down due to technical issues. The roller coasters were average, the ones at SeaWorld were better. Definitely not worth the money we paid for tickets. Parking is also $25 FYI. We will not be returning here

Great place, always something interesting going on. They sometimes have free beer at the area next to the flamingos and there will be always something interesting to do. I used to go to see the fireworks when I was here as a kid. I will note, usually newer rides have a longer wait time but you can get on Kumba and Montu very quickly since they've been around for awhile. Cheetah hunt and the Serpent ride will take a bit longer. The wooden roller coaster is gone sadly but I think they're replacing it with something new so that's nice. Overall good experience, good to go with family and kids.

Been to Thai park few times now. Every time we come you can see even more how old it is. Nasty restaurants. We all know there are people that are paying a all day you can eat. So this made food bad. And even the restaurants that don't have that still really bad. The trays to pick up you food are one of the most disgusting thing I have ever seen in a restaurant. Dirty and wet all 5 times I needed one. Doing the whole day between buying waters. Beer. Nasty funnel cake. Ice cream. T-shit and other thing no one of more than 12 encounters with employees was nice. No one from the staff had any education. None of them wanted to be there. Not even a hi after spending all this money. In general a very dirty park. And really bad staff. And nasty food. I know 10000 better way to spend my money. This is my family last time in the place after more than 15 years coming here.

Busch Gardens Tampa was an awesome experience! From the food, to the animals and roller coasters to the customer service....it was a great day!

When me and my party arrived to the park it was storming. I was surprised at the number of people that were at the park. We didn't have to pay the $22, for parking which started our day off nicely. 

I would highly recommend purchasing the meal plan with your ticket as it is worth the extra money! You can eat a full meal every hour if you like. Plus water is free and snacks are buy one get one free, which included most everything even beer. 

We started off with a meal upon arrival since it was still raining. We took advantage of the rain and hit up all the animal exhibits the first few hours. Then once it stopped raining and there was no lightning for a certain period of time we were able to start riding the roller coasters. 

I had no idea Busch Gardens had such awesome roller coasters. We road them all, and two of the best coasters we rode again after dark. We saw a spectacular fireworks display around 9:30 PM. And we stopped by a snack bar on the way out and got our last free water and I purchased some caramel corn at buy one get one free.

The shuttle was nice too so you didn't have to waste your energy walking from the parking lot to the park. When the park closed the shuttles were coming every 1 to 2 minutes which was great! We even received a free ticket for another day within a year due to the inclement weather. What an awesome deal!

Thank you Busch Gardens for making my first experience at your amusement park GREAT!

Good time to be here in Tampa for this park. During the spring is the best time to go. Hardly any lines and low crowds. I would highly recommend this park to anyone that is going to be vacation here in the Tampa bay area. Family friendly park.

The security process is absolutely ridiculous. Forced to wait in sweltering temperatures for 20-30 minutes. They need to use fans to circulate air and get more security gates!
This day has only gotten worse. I was in line on two different rides and they shut each one down for "technical issues" when I was literally the next in line to ride after waits of 20-40 minutes!
I'd give it negative stars if I could.

Great place to take the kids. Especially if you like animals, safaris, and roller coasters. Purchase the fast pass to help avoid the long waiting lines. I also recommend purchasing the dining ticket which comes with one entree, a side dish, and fountain drink once every hour, totally worth it! Especially the all day complimentary water that comes with it. The downfall: the park closed at 7pm!! but I more so wish we knew the dining halls and restaurants throughout the park starting to close at 5pm. We went the last week of May so I'm not sure if that had anything to do with it but in case not, plan accordingly.

Great Park for all ages!  Lots of thrill rides and animals, pus Sesame Street characters, River rapids, flume.  Buy 1 food wristband, you can get water al the time and food every hour.  Great deal, especially if you share.
I tried to steal a drink and the cashier caught me and made me get in line to pay. Once I bought it she gave me a bag of chips for the inconvenience

This is an amazing park and the best in Florida with some of the biggest and fastest roller coasters around i been coming here sense i was a kid and always love to come here and ride the roller coaster plus this park is owned by Anheuser-Bush the makers of Budweiser and other beer's you want to ride some good roller coasters and scream allot this is the place, i recommended it to anyone.

I'm told that, according to the Travel Channel, the ShieKra is the #1 roller coaster in the country.  I must say that IT...WAS...AWESOME!!!  Pretty scary to look at, with the 90 degree drop I almost wussed out, but after some name calling by my supportive friend, I had to give it a shot!

The rest of the park is almost like a zoo...lots and lots of animals (turtles...YAY!!!) to look at and learn about.  You also have the opportunity to look at the famous Budweiser Clydesdales and Sprint, the Budweiser donkey from the commercials.  

The other couple roller coasters that I went on were really fun, as well.  They rode very smoothly, which is always a plus in my book.  You also have a chance (which I missed) to sample beer...for free...and become and Anheiser Busch Brewmaster.  I was really looking forward to this, but the timing was all off.  And we had a really small child with our group.  It makes me sad.

Food is expensive and not great, so be prepared to sacrifice an arm, leg, and some other valued body part perhaps.  Or, snack throughout the day so you don't have to go for the full meal.

I'd visit again, even if only for the free beer!

We went with a group of 10 people yesterday and had an amazing time . The rides are the best , started with their icon sheikra which is always a treat . Then komba which is a fun rollercoaster followed by cheetah hunt which is like 4 rollercoasters combined in one . Falcon fairy is a super scary ride when you are looking at it but when you get in and feel the drop it's much easier . Mantu has been my favorite ride for years and no matter what you do we always get dizzy . Love the park , the prices and the staff .

If you mix an amusement park, botanical garden and a zoo together you get something that looks similar to Busch Gardens.  Many opportunities for fun but also for complaints.  We think they do a great job overall.  

Highlights, Tips and Observations:

There are several shows in the park.  We liked Turn It Up, an ice skating show teamed with pop music.  Great performances but also doubles as a much-needed respite from the sun and heat during summer.  There were four shows offered the day we visited.

There was a nice variety of animals and they looked happy and content.

The rides are spaced out throughout the park.  Expect a walk from one to another.  They're mostly geared toward the adventurous crowd that are at least 48" tall and without health concerns.  You WILL get wet and/or soaked on water rides.  Renting a locker or bringing a dry bag for phones is a good plan.  We didn't find the stand-in dryers they offer for $5 as you exit to be terribly effective.

 The train ride moves around the entire park.  If you take it all the way around, it lasts about 35 minutes.  Yes, there are times when the ride is more interesting than others but it moves you through the park and is a great way to see much without exhausting yourself.  Also, staff members have been trained to wave as the train passes.  Littles that enjoy waving will have a blast.

Serengeti Overlook is a good option for food.  If you need to eat, this is our recommendation.  I've written a separate review for their page.

Despite the landscaping and gardens that are carefully maintained, much of the park remains in full sun.  They mitigate this as they can with misting tunnels and misting individuals (that is, people who walk around and mist guests).  Having said that, wearing a hat and sunscreen is recommended.

Busch Gardens AND the parking lots are HUGE.  Paying for VIP Parking is a no-brainer (for us).  It gets you MUCH closer to the park.  Otherwise, your feet might feel like they're *done* before you get to the entrance gate.

Busch Gardens is part of Tampa's CityPass.  If you can commit to visiting several attractions in a 9 day period, this is a great value.

Final Assessment:  Great choice for the entire family.  There's something here for everyone.  We're happy with our decision to visit and expect to return at some point in the future. 4 Stars.
We had an awesome time here!  My kids had a blast.  It rained for a little while and we were able to check out the animals while the rides were shut down.  It was much better than Six Flags!

Being a Tampa native with annual passes, BG has been a great place for our family to spend time at. Parking is decent and with trams it doesn't really natter where you park.  Having an annual pass does help so you don't pay for parking. Entry is not bad since they've streamlined the metal detector/ bag check and ticket entry areas. There are things to do for every age group.  Sesame Street for the little ones,  roller coasters for the tweens, shows for all ages,  animal exhibits,  animal safaris,  and more.  Food is like every other theme park...so so and a bit expensive; but I get it, they gave to make money.  When the weather is nice(not boiling hot) this is a great place to hang out. By the way,  2 free beers on a visit is a plus!

I´ve been to this park ever since I was 2 years old, and it´s AMAZING! Really great for family´s. It has amazing coasters and attractions, you can also pet kangaroos, ride on a truck and feed giraffes, go through an animal vet, and buy cool souvenirs. You won´t regret buying tickets, it's AMAZING HERE!

The annual pass is a great deal if you're local.  The park is perfect for the roller coaster thrill seekers and the younger kiddos.  Definitely world class roller coasters that are maintained well.  You never hear any stories or humans being ejected mid loop.  Covered and cooled areas for those who sweat profusely (me).  The only reason I didn't give a 5 star is because I have an unreasonable expectation that there would be smoked turkey leg/nacho stands every 100 yards.  We come here several times throughout the year.

Fun park but was not aware that the back of the park opens at 1030 and the rides there don't start until 11.  Wasn't too happy that the security person said I had a lot of sh_t in my backpack. My backpack was small but my kids stuffed their phones in there with sunglasses and glasses. Whatever---very rude! He should have kept comments like that to himself. Other than that the food was pretty good at the smokehouse and the rides weren't too long a wait if u have the quick queue. Cheetah was the best ride and we still managed to find an adult sized shirt for 16 dollars.  Just watch for sales.  They ran out quickly of the 3 for 34 adult shirts which I only saw in one of the stores. I would give a half star more since my kids 11 and 16 are having a blast!

I love the idea of combining a zoo and a theme park.  

They surely have a lot of roller coasters and they look all thrilling.  On the other hand, they lack options for non roller coaster riders, other than watching animals.  While I love roller coasters, I often get a motion sickness from rides with loops and a lot of turns.  I like straight rides with a lot of speed.   So to me, this theme park is a little too much and I would not dare trying to conquer all the rides.  And to be honest, the rides are very similar to each other and it gets boring after a while.  

While I appreciate that I get to go on rides waiting for very little time, sometimes I feel this place is too empty and looks like it is going out of business.  They seriously lack options of dining.  

They have a couple of  package deals with other theme parks combined.  Busch Gardens is definitely one of a few tourist spots in Tampa and if you like roller coasters, you should check it out once.

Was on vacation did the vacation package at the holiday in express with the BuschGardens tickets. Waited an hour and a half to get my quick queue. Call BuschGardens Vacations because they couldn't find me Quick Queue. Got home and called them about the bad experience I had. They said sorry. Nothing we can do. Very bad company. Don't ever do it. Worst experience ever. Don't do Vacation Packages. Hotel experience was also bad. Stay away.

If I could I would give them NEGATIVE stars.  This place has the WORST customer service!!  They refuse to comply with Federal law for persons of disabilities.   They are VERY rude.  You are better off to visit Orlando theme parks.  They care about their customers.  They actually would love to have you come back again, and treat you with respect.  If things go wrong in the Orlando theme parks; there's a high chance they will offer you free tickets to come back.  Tampa Busch Gardens management is like a Six Flags.  They are more of local park than a park for international visitors.  Here in Orlando, all our water parks heat their water in their pools / rivers / rides to 84 F; in Tampa they do not heat their water at their water park.  Orlando cares about you as a customer to return.  Busch Garden's Tampa could care less about you as a customer.  It's unbelievable that I had to get the Tampa police involved to resolve this  matter pertaining to ADA Federal Law.
Long lines and short rides for a lot of money. Cedar Point is waaay better. Food is poor and high cost. Parking was a nightmare. The whole experience doesn't hold a candle to Disney.

I would say the best time to go is M-F if you want to be able to get on all the rides without waiting 1-2 hours for a ride unless you get the fast passes. Getting the silver yearly lass is worth the $$ for sure :) cobra curse is definitely a fun little ride to get on. The atmosphere is nice but the only downside is that the bathrooms aren't in the best shape haha but what can you do

We went here on our staycation. Our kids are 12 and 9 they were able to ride all rollercoasters no problem. We got a quick queue so we were able to get on rides fast without having to wait which was nice because it was a little hot out. But I must say by far I was very happy that being a full figured woman I was able to fit on all the rides. That is the main reason this place gets high stars. 
Food was pricy as most parks are
Bathroom were clean think because we went on a weekday so not many people at park
But if your in Tampa and you like coasters this is a good find. 
If your an animal lover dont go see kangaroos they looked very sad and not well taken care of. 
But the other animals seem pretty good.

Best place for roller coasters and seeing safari animals and being close to my house benefits us in a lot of different ways.
Halloween events are the best

love it here and all the festivities throughout the year. The rides are so fun and when the heat starts to get to you go see the ice show! (It's not as good as the old show) but it'll cool you off! I love having passes and coming just for a few hours sometimes. On busy days the lines can get long and hot so if it's your first visit to Florida I recommend you are sure to drink lots and lots of water, and bring a portable fan! I cannot not emphasize drinking water enough lol there's stuff for all ages here!

It was a great experience. The reason I gave it four stars is due some areas that require improvements. Requires restrooms away from the theme areas. Once you approach each section everyone is going to the same restroom making it busy and not clean after 50 people have used it. 

Requires additional eating restaurants/sitting areas. 

The rides were awesome and the children area is for every age which was great. The animals were awesome for everyone to see. I will come back and tell others to visit.

All the rides were down for maintenance when we walked up to them. The only one we were able to get on was the Kumba. After hours of walking around to see now "down for maintenance" signs we finally gave up and went to customer services. When we got through THAT line we were given a flat "We called and all the rides are open" and we were given an email address to get a refund. A total waste of a day, and a complete waste of $100/head. Don't waste your money or time at Douche Gardens.

You know, for an amusement park in the middle of a city block Busch Gardens isn't half bad!

Easy to get to, you can spend part or all day here and really get a chance to experience a lot.  I'm a huge roller coaster fan, so a park accessible and fun like this is great to have in Tampa.

I've found Sundays to be a great day to get on rides without crazy waits.  Perhaps it's football season, but I managed 6 coasters in 3 hours without really trying. 

All day food deal is great at $40, and this gets you a meal an hour all day at select restaurants.

Season passes are pretty inexpensive next to Disney, and the coasters are far more intense!  Plus, animal safari!

Went for my sons bday. It was a wonderful day. The only downside iis if you go in summer, there are a lot of thunderstorms, thus, they shut all rides down due to lighting. They monitor the weather like crazy. Our day was washed out unfortunately but still enjoyable. The park is beautifully landscaped and kept clean. Food was decent as well. Our favorite exhibit was the gorillas. They come right up to the window. We will go again but not in thunderstorm season!

I honestly think they need more staff.  The fact that they cheap out and make employees work several different rides at the same time is ridiculous.  One employee had to lock and unlock the entrance and exit 30x just to fill some rides.  Quite irresponsible on the Busch gardens management.  Having to wait 30 mins in a line that is 10 kids is honestly dumb.  I think the management need to quit filling their pockets and fork up some money for more staff....

A wonderful place to visit!  It's an amusement park and zoo all in one!!

A great place for all ages.  Doesn't matter if you like roller coasters or not, there is more then enough other things to enjoy.  A great children's section, great shows, and wonderful rides!  I can't over sell this park!

Wow! My family and I loved Busch Gardens. The combination of rides and animal attractions means you never get bored walking around. The rollercoasters were all fun, especially the Cheetah, which uses magnets to shoot you down the track super-fast. The kangaroo exhibit was adorable (who knew that kangaroos had soft fuzzy noses?) and the other animal exhibits, like the tigers and elephants let you see the animals clearly and looked well-maintained, clean, and interesting for the animals. We bought a package from AAA that included 1 meal for $69.99 and ate BBQ at the Zambia Smokehouse. The food was better than the average amusement park stuff, although if you wanted anything other than the 1 included entree, the prices got steep quickly.  We didn't even have time to ride the train or do the Safari excursion, so I can definitely imagine going back.

Over 40 years I have been going to Busch Gardens Tampa Bay. 
   Always something new and exciting. Best theme park food in Florida. Always fresh and tasty. 
  The rides are always new, well kept and ready to please !! The Best !!
Very busy day, but got in quickly as we purchased our tickets online. All day meal deal is so worth it!

Park is very difficult to navigate at first. Lines are ridiculously long and underestimated. Signs/staff will say 30-60 minutes and you end up waiting 90 minutes - 2 hours for a ride. Plenty of empty seats at times on rides. Should have an option for single riders.

I waited an hour and a half for a "30 minute wait" at the scorpion ride, and when my group was about to walk into the carts, they announced a "technical difficulty" and told us we couldn't wait. Ridiculous.

If I were to choose between Disney and this place, you would know the answer. 

It was nice to be in the train to see the animals and then get off one stop and walk around. I remember trying to pet a horse, but I haven't seen one that up close. It was a nice looking one! If you hate the hay smell, you'd probably skip this part.

I was kind of scared of roller coasters.. it was all in my head till I got on those rides. My fave was Kumba. My legs felt so free, and it was good to experience the rush through my body.

I didn't like Gwazi at all.. pretty rocky ride -- my neck and back started hurting. So did Ralph's.

I am totally agreeing on drinking lots of water. If you buy a big cup with Busch Gardens, you can get free re-fills, even the next time you go there. If someone gives you a hard time about refilling it, go to the next one. We did and had to tell the person about the last person. She said that wasn't supposed to happen to us, but it did.

I would definitely come back here again... and get there early next time!

A zoo + roller coasters + drinks = a good time.

My friends and I got fun passes/annual passes so we could come for their food and wine festival.  We usually first grab a beer, go ride Montu, grab hard liquor (like a pina colada or margarita) wait in line and finish our drinks before getting on Cheetah hunt, and then grab more drinks and walk around the park.  It is a fantastic plan that leads to good times.

There are two places in the park that serve liquor.  One is the building across from cheetah hunt.  The other is a tiki hut looking stand that I can never remember where it is, but we always stumble upon it.

I love the food and wine festival, because I can try a ton of little plates and sample a lot of little drinks.  Their sangria is pretty good.

My favorite ride is Falcon's Fury, but I heard I'm crazy.  Other favorites are cheetah hunt and montu.  If you live in Tampa, it is definitely worth getting passes.

Went to bg with kids tonight.  Bronze members can't get in.  No communication prior.  Was told to check site prior to coming to the park even though we have a membership



Then the park replies on yelp that I should check the website ( which I stated earlier) or my yearly pass(. which contains no actual dates) 


Once again. I paid for an annual pass.  If you have announced blackout dates since my passes were purchased how have you communicated them to your customers other than a website that I would not visit because I have already bought passes? This isn't entirely the customers responsibility to seek out this information.   Once again piss poor on Busch gardens part and I will gladly hit as many forums as possible with this in addition to requesting a year refund via corporate office.  


Staff also told me it was blocked because of a concert.  No reason not to be able to let me kids ride rides in the rest of the park. Not a surprise that the reputation is what it is.

Visited Busch Gardens Tampa about 12 years ago and LOVED it. I couldn't wait to bring my son when we decided to go to Florida. What a huge disappointment..it was $400+ for admission and safari tickets for 3 of us and another $25 to park. Half the exhibits were closed due to inclement weather or out Foraging. We did love the safari and Gabe the tour guide was awesome. A lot of the other attractions are extra as well and if u don't purchase them ahead of time, you won't have the opportunity to go on them since they sell out fast. The day could easily cost you hundreds though of you do book the extras. The Clydesdale horses are gone since Seaworld took over. Such a disappointment. Go to Gaterworld..much cheaper and a lot more fun!! Would give one star but Gabe and the safari pushed it up to two.

Thanks for the veterans free tickets. Although free in June is a little hot. Especially for Veterans who have breathing difficulties.  Or walking problems.  Have to give a shout out to Haley. Can't remember what store but when she saw her store was out of sloths she called around until she found a sloth pin for us. So thanks Busch Garden and Haley.

Today was my first time going to Busch Gardens. We had reservations to the special event of LUNCH with Elmo and Friends. I was told on the phone it would be inside but be warned it is in an outdoor pavilion. The employee I spoke to was wrong about the set up of the facility. In addition it is self seating so therefore the tables were confusing. For example we were table 11 but there was another family that was also considered "table 11". Therefore it was a bit chaotic when different groups were meeting the characters. Personally I think each family should be assigned a number instead. 

There was an outdoor cheer competition happening directly next to our pavilion. Their music was off the charts loud to the point you couldn't hear the person sitting across from you. Therefore the Sesame Street staff did the "logical" thing and tried to blast their music louder than the cheerleaders music. With 2 completely different songs playing at full blast it was absolutely horrible. 

The food: The quality of the food was lacking despite my picture not showing the lack of flavor. It honestly tasted comparable to an elementary school's cafeteria. Someone in my group had a roll that was still clearly frozen. There was mashed potatoes, macaroni n cheese, rolls, veggies, chicken strips, pulled pork, salad, cupcakes, and fruit. I tried almost everywhere and was very disappointed. 

Characters: First off there is no show during this lunch. I was misinformed over the phone about the entertainment involved during lunch. The characters dance for about 30 seconds. Don't get me wrong it is cute. However I wouldn't pay money just for a few spins. The characters were supposed to walk to one table at a time. However the staff wasn't facilitating enough as people kept approaching the characters, ruining the flow of meet n greets. Our table for completely skipped over by a character and I eventually had to go approach him since they were leaving soon. 

Photo: The photographer lady wasn't very friendly at all. I wasn't thrilled with the quality of the photos taken. However 1 of them turned out alright out of about 5. 

Favorite character: The count was the best character there for sure. He was fair on the amount of time he spent with each family and I felt he actually invested time with my experience with him. I would've liked to have been able to meet the Cookie Monster or grouch as well. However there was no guaranteed characters except for Elmo. 

The cheerleading music interrupted the entire meal and it was honestly miserable. The characters were cute but not $20 a person kind of cute. 

I went to guest services and they tried to work out some accommodations due to our poor experience. However I was not satisfied with how things were being handled. I ended up calling Busch garden customer service who attempted to tell me there was nothing left they could do. However I eventually was able to speak with Busch Garden corporate who took my complaints serious. We were able to work out something that I considered to be fair and respectful. The corporate employee I spoke to was kind, empathetic, and made sure things were made right. 

Whoever scheduled a cheer competition next to Elmo's special event lunch clearly didn't think through the logistics of sound. The food however does need help, especially for how expensive it was. 

I was very disappointed on my experience at Busch Gardens. However clearly corporate does care about customer satisfaction and is willing to take appropriate actions. 

It should not have taken 1 guest service trip to speak to a supervisor, being put on hold several times with customer service for a good 30+ minutes, before FINALLY getting someone who could help me out. 

So for now Sea World would be my go to place out of the two pairs. Busch Gardens has some growing to do with customer service and with their food.

Great tourist spot but pricey ($130.00 per adult).  Hubby and I went for vacation.  

PROS:   Parking lot shuttle, lots to see (animals, shows, rides, restaurants, souvenir shops, educational tours, safari adventures and more). 

CONS:  Price and snobby ticket window staff (just plain rude, cold and nasty... the supervisor was sitting at a desk right behind my ticket agent and said nothing to correct or mediate her rudeness.  We said nothing... just bought the tickets and walked in). Horrible way to start our adventure here.

RECOMMENDATIONS:  
... Wear comfortable clothing and supportive walking shoes (LOTTTS of walking). 

...Bring water (bottle).  If you have kids eat before coming. There are several fast foodies in the area.

...Study the grounds map (handed out free) then schedule your show tours (times) before starting your adventures!!!!

...Ride the roller coasters (especially the Cheetah Hunt).

Recommended!

Great park! Something for the whole family. Great kids play area. Sesame Street  for younger kids. Tremendous thrill rides! Good food. Clean park. Shik-ra is one of the best coasters ever. They decorate the park beautifully during the holidays. One of our favorite times to go!

Get here early!  If you do, most of the rides will have very friendly wait times.   So while the rides may be short in length, it is pretty easy to go on several of them.

Pro tip: If you come here with a party and plan on spending a while here, get the all day dining pass.  BUT, only get it for half the number of people in your party.

What it is is that you can get an Entree, Side, and Drink, once per hour.  Some places like the smoke house will give you huge portions!  Get something like the sampler plate.  Its entirely too much food for once person.  And since you can get something once per hour, highly doubt anybody will be hungry.

My friend and I went here today. We spent six hours in the park and were only able to ride three rides. Every ride had over an hour wait. When I rode Sheikra, the operations were only running at 11 cars an hour, based on the monitor in the dispatch station. Other guests were frequently abusing the quick queue system. Several times I saw entire families enter the regular line and then climb under the rails to enter the quick queue line after passing by the attendant who was checking passes. Of the three rides that I did go on (Sheikra, Kumba, and Montu) there were consistently empty seats despite there being 40+ minute waits. In fact, most dispatched trains had 3-4 empty seats, but there were no single rider lines throughout the park.
On a more positive note, the animal exhibits were very clean and spacious. The park as a whole was lovely. There were lots of shady areas and everything was clean and well kept. It was a very large park but pretty easy to navigate. Much like Busch Gardens in Williamsburg, the park is essentially just a big loop. 
I have to say, though, that my visit overall was extremely disappointing. I traveled all the way from Connecticut to go to Busch gardens. Admission to this park was extremely expensive, and at the end of the day, I spent a lot of time and money to go to this park, which I was really looking forward to for months and had an awful time. My friend and I had planned to stay for the fireworks, but ended up leaving three hours early because we had such a terrible time. After spending so much money and traveling so many miles, it was an extremely disheartening experience.

We've never been and was really looking forward to Busch Gardens. We used a City Pass which was the main attraction, for us, of all the others. We left kinda disappointed. My son has a disability and could only ride a few rides-not that there was many! It was either the few kiddie rides which he's too big for or the rollercoasters (that wasn't even an option, lol) I know it's not a new park but dang nothing seemed to be working! Rides were down, one of the restaurants was not cooking hot foods just offering sandwiches. Also, the signs kept you (us) walking in circles. There are maps located all over but you still had to maneuver through diff areas to get where you wanted to go. I def got my 10,000 steps in The best part was the train ride up close with the wildlife!
Its one ofmy favorite places to go on the weekend. We go almost every weekend and stay all day. Our daughter loves bush gardens too

On Christmas Day, we took a four-year old girl to Busch Gardens to give her something fun to do and try to accomplish something important in her life.

First, we were impressed Busch Gardens waived all parking fees for the day as a holiday gift. This was not announced, just a very nice gesture for guests. We took two cars, so we saved $50 right there, and think about all the money Busch Gardens gave up for the entire day based on a pretty full lot.

Because we were letting a four-year old girl drag us around, we adults did not do the larger, thrill rides on this visit. 

She stopped us at almost every smaller attraction and was clearly happy with all of the rides for children, whether she rode with one other random child or was able to ride with her mother.

Therefore, we spent time in the Sesame Street section of the park as well as going to visit Rudolph the Red-Nosed Reindeer (She's a big fan) and friends for pictures. I was slightly disappointed Hermey the Elf was not there offerering dental "check-ups" and photos, especially since the American Dental Association gave him a dental degree for the show's 50th anniversary in 2014. Nope. Not making that up. Do your own Google search and see for yourself. 

She also loves animals, so the big train out of Nairobi station that travels through the open area of giraffes, hippos, zebras and rhinos was fun for her as well. It is a Christmas Carol train after 5pm and those carolers do not let up.(She did not like the huge ostrich at all!)

Playing a choose your Christmas gift themed game with a guaranteed prize for just $6 and buying her a Christmas light headband for only $5 also showed us that the park was not trying to overprice little things that enhanced her experience. 

The biggest move was visiting Santa's House to see The Big Guy himself. Especially on Christmas Day after he clearly put in a long night traveling around the world delivering toys.

Not only was it the highlight of her Christmas, but all of us adults were extremely impressed with the details of the rather intimate experience.

For her first time seeing and meeting Santa, she did not deal with the usual mall chaos. She got Santa all to herself in peace and quiet, escorted by a Santa's helper through a magic mirror after a meet and greet with Mrs. Claus, who welcomed her as she entered the front door by ringing a cool doorbell. (The house looked perfect for the occasion and they only let in a few groups at a time)

Ours was a truly authentic Santa and the room he sits in (Obviously, there are multiple rooms to keep things moving a bit) was lavishly decorated and spacious. There's clearly no rush and it is very quiet and intimate for the child to interact and take pics with Santa.

Even after we all said thank you to Santa, the Santa's helper escorted us down another hallway where Christmas cookies were handed to us before we left the house. Nice finishing touch. Tasty cookies too.

None of us would have ever thought having her meet Santa for the first time in her life would be this good on this day in a large theme park. 

She was really happy and obviously will talk about it and remember this for quite awhile.

Our sincere thanks to Busch Gardens for making a four-year old girl's Christmas experience very special.

The young lady terrianna was not very nice I apologized for leaving the beer cooler open and she blew me off and said whatever. I'm a guest and that wasn't very respectful. Work with a smile not an attitude. Other than that the park is absolutely great

When you look at the distances between Disneyworld, Universal, & Busch, the latter appears to be the kid that doesn't get picked in gym class. However, I can draw at least 5 comparisons to change your mind about that:

1. It took me 9 minutes to clear general security at TPA airport...I let my Trusted Traveler membership lapse (no fast lane for me‍). It would've taken over an hour to clear security in MCO. 

2. Park tickets on any given day at WDW & Universal are $100pp. No sales. Take it or leave it because they don't need your stinking money. Busch Gardens, on the other hand, has sales. We got 60% off our tickets.  

3. FOOD! Oh my gosh, the food. We must've eaten 5 times in 1 day. On the dining plan, we could eat every hour, on the hour. An entree with a side or dessert. And the sodas were included to refill all day long without a limit. WDW & Universal have dining plans but even if you buy a full package, WDW starts at approx $100pp/day, and Universal $64pp/day, and there are dining limits. 

OUR DINING AND TICKETS FOR 1 DAY AT BUSCH FOR 3 PEOPLE WAS $267!

4. WDW & Universal have character spots, but let's agree that these are grown adults in stuffed animal costumes and the exchanges are a little creepy for them and us. Busch Gardens has amazing shows with extremely talented people! We saw the Turn it Up! ice show and Critters Inn. Critters Inn features rescue animals turned into superstars. Someone saw the good in them! I might've cried a little during that one. There's several other shows but these are the ones we saw and they were outstanding. 

5. The zoo animals. Oh my gosh, we've been to San Diego & Houston's zoos and we saw more animals close up at Busch Gardens. And that was without paying extra for the interactive encounters. 

Okay so kind of #6, but only if you're a roller coaster thrills kind of person. I'm more of an amusement rider, meaning I like the the easy rides that entertain you along the way. This is where I prefer the other 2 parks. I can ride 2 of the stomach thumper 'thrill' coasters and that's it. Getting older sucks. BUT, that's when I walked over to the drink station, got myself an ice cold ginger ale and enjoyed the park views while my family got their insides pressurized & shaken up. It was incredibly gratifying watching grownups get off that ride looking woozy. It was a good thing I stopped early.

At the other 2 parks, you can ride or watch a couple shows. But the seating for non-riders is incredibly limited throughout those parks, so that explains all the annoying scooters. At Busch, if you don't feel like walking, there's the train and sky ride. If you don't want to ride the coasters, go for a walk through the gardens and be greeted by a lorikeet bird that says peekaboo with the cutest intonation. 

I'm not saying that WDW & Universal are bad..we're definitely going this year, but they're not the only ones that can help make the memories. If you don't rent a car, Tampa is only a 1 hour Uber ride from Orlando. That's the minimum waiting time for a ride at Disney. But 1 day of tickets & food at Disney will easily buy you 3 days of the same at Busch. We stayed at the Hampton Inn across the street from the park. 

After reading some of the negative reviews, I suspect those people might either be employees from competing parks or people trying to complain for free tickets. We visited on a Tuesday and had a wonderful time.
Came here 9/25/19, had s nice time.  I am a Annual Passholder.  My only complaint is that they need to update their shows.

We did the Serengeti Safari yesterday & it was amazing. It was $39 but totally worth it. You check in around 15 minutes before your scheduled tour (have to book at least 24hrs in advance) - There were 18 of us on our tour & you stand on the back of the truck. It was around 90° yesterday so it was really hot, but feeding the giraffes made it worth it. 

It is a 30 minute tour & the truck makes a couple of stops to see a few different animals but to be honest, that part wasn't very exciting bc you can see them at any zoo. The last part of the tour we were able to feed the giraffes. The tour guide gave us each a piece of lettuce & the giraffes came right up to the truck. There is a photographer on board who takes pictures you can purchase but we just used our phones. I would definitely recommend this as it was a really cool experience. I'd rate it a 10/10 just for the giraffe interaction

Today was the first day of attending the park after buying an annual pass. I am now sorry I bought the pass. So far, out of 4 rides we have been waiting in line for, 3 of the rides have shut down due to technical difficulties. When you only have a few hours to ride, and you wait for 30 minutes only for them to close the ride becomes extremely frustrating.

4 stars for the whole experience-

I've been coming to Busch Gardens since the early '80s and a lot has changed. I won't drag out this review and go through all of the changes but I really like the park now. Granted, I feel it was at its prime just a few years ago but I'm starting to warm to the new Pantopia changes. (Personally, I liked it best when the new Dragon Fire Grille was the German Festhaus and there was the whole Egypt and German influence) Anyway, the park is really large and I think it would be tough to do it all in one day so I recommend getting a seasonal pass - pays for itself in two trips. A couple of tips:

1. Purchase the All Day Dining wristband. $30 but a seasonal pass gets you a discount on the band so it makes it close to ~$25. The bands get you all of the food you want to eat and BOGO drinks. 
2. Alcohol prices are different between the Dragon Fire Grille and the Colony House (weird, right?). Stick to the house if you want the lowest price.
3. Bring your patience if you visit during Hollowscream.
4. Enter the park and follow the path to the right and work the park in a big circle.
5. The sky ride is notorious for not being open except for windy days - figure that out.
6. Upgrade your ribs for $3(with wristband) to the baby back. They'll most likely fall off the bone.
7. ONLY get the ribs at the smokehouse - not at the Dragon Fire Grille. They're always chewy at the DFG.
8. Lastly, disregard the parking attendants if your arriving after 10am. Just drive up to the first lots as people will have left the park and you'll get a great spot near the walkway or trams.

We brought our grandchildren here ages 5&6. They had so much fun in Sesame Street. We stayed there during most of the visit. There were so many rides and activities that they loved. They treehouse was a big hit with our granddaughter. It was great to sit and watch them enjoy themselves. I was very impressed with all the ride attendants. Very friendly and safety conscious at each ride. If I lived in Tampa I would definitely be a season pass holder. We'll definitely be back

OH MY GOSH! I have been going here since I was a little kid. There is something for everyone here. Definitely a place to go with your friends or family. Their Hallowscream event is awesome too! I know I'll be going back soon because it's just so much fun! Definitely would recommend to a friend.

Imagine (for you Chicagoans) Lincoln Park Zoo with roller coasters and you have Busch Gardens.  Better than Santa's Village, worse than Six Flags.  Since there's not much in Tampa entertainment wise, I give Busch a rather lukewarm 'Thumbs Up'.

I love this place.  It's expensive, but the animals are in very nice habitats.  Rides are decent, not great, but fun.  It's kind of like a zoo plus, the animals are really the main attraction, rides are just extra.

I have been enjoying Busch Gardens since the early 60's...when it was mainly just a brewery tour with bird show.  In my college years living nearby, buddies and I used to enter through the bird cages and get some free beer in the hospitality area...and then the beer was still brewed there. Then after the Serengheti Plains with more animals and rides were added, we took our kids there and it was a major thrill, but now quite equaling Disney for them. Adults appreciated the nature/animals emphasis more than cartoon characters and relentless promotion of Disney products.   
More recently we have not visited after kids have grown...and prices have sky-rocketed.  Nice you can get an all-year pass but not if you only want  to go once for old times sake.  So overall it is tops in memories and great as a Tampa tourist draw but not so much for repeat visits.
Always have an amazing time with my friends. Friendly staff. Best rides around! Always get my yearly pass!

One of my favorite theme parks to go to.  They have many great coasters.  If you need a breather between rides, they have animals here too. This place is well maintained.  Of you love animals and coasters, THIS IS THE PLACE FOR YOU!

I loved the zoo. This place was built more for walking around and site seeing. There are some roller coasters. I hate roller coasters that go upside down....there's only one that doesn't. However it was great over all.

Cool place! We used to have annual passes but moved out of state for a few years. Now we are back and the rates are a bit steeper now than used to be! Otherwise would give it 5 stars. Might have to get a couple of daily passes and stop by and see what has changed. They used to add new rides/coasters frequently so I am sure there are plenty of new things to check out!

So many great things to see and do here. It's a little expensive but the annual passes make it much more affordable. There is to much to do in just one day anyways. I love all the animals and the rides and even the shows. The staff is always very friendly and helpful. I can't wait to go during the holidays to see all the Christmas decorations.

This theme park makes all other zoos and theme parks look bad. Not only is this the best park in Florida, it beats six flags too. She has come a long way from the Busch Gardens of my childhood and even further still from my parents childhood. While I miss the free beer that was discontinued with the change of ownership, I love what this park has grown into.  
The rides beat any Disney or Universal ride hands down, no competition. With a great variety of roller coasters, water rides and the Serengeti train, there is something for everyone and all ages. Although it doesn't spike your adrenaline like some of the roller coasters here, the train is a must! Where else in Florida can you ride a train between zebras, giraffe, buffalo etc. Although be prepared for delays because this train breaks for animals :)
The animals here, are in heaven. They have so much room and Busch Gardens prides themselves on giving the animals things to do. Don't be surprised if you see a lion playing with a ball or a gorilla opening gifts on his birthday. The Serengeti is huge, the zebras here don't even know they aren't in the wild. This is also the only place I know of where you can come face to face with a tiger or climb a ladder into a spy glass right in the middle of the enclosure. I highly recommend visiting the tigers in the morning when its not hot and they are feeling frisky! They tend to pounce on the glass and show you their teeth. Don't be ashamed to use your children for bait, because tigers apparently will come closer for bite sized kiddos. In the afternoons and in the heat, they get lazy and may not be quite as exciting.
Lots of dinning options, with anything you can think of. I love the Zambia smoke house and the Colony dinning room with family style all you can eat dinning. They also have a cafeteria show room where you can catch a show with your meal. Unlike Disney, No reservations required.
There are several impressive shows in the park that even adults will love but there is also a sesame street play land where you can catch a dancing Elmo.
Everyone in the family will find something they love about this park.

Visited Busch Gardens on Monday 3/25 on Spring Break. We have 3 boys (2, 6, and 8). The youngest liked the Sesame Street area and train ride. The older kids enjoyed the roller coasters. We had all day dine pass and enjoyed lunch. The first restaurant we went to was closed with broken water pipe. Park was crowded but kids enjoyed rides and animals. Went to Sesame Street show and the Turn it Up ice show. Boys thought the women in show were pretty and got a picture after the show. Everyone was nice and friendly. Overall had a fun day with the family!  Park was spread out so be sure to wear good shoes for walking and stroller for young kids. We got three day passes with all day dinning and also went to Sea World - Good Deal!

In 1976 I went to Busch Gardens Williamsburg with my family that was fun.. this was more fun!
We had a great time here the park was very clean the staff was friendly.
It was a Friday morning when we got there, so the lines were at a minimum we got thru the whole park and the girls were able to ride all the roller coasters  i think 8 in all.  The favorites were SheiKra, Cheetah Hunt, and Falcon's Fury and we still had time to get something to eat! we ate at the pretzel and beer place we had pretzel dogs and bacon pretzels too yum BACON!!
The combo of animals and rides is well done  with over ten different themed areas within the park, and more than a dozen animal attraction spots. the tigers and birds were my favorite. the gator pond was cool, you can really see how big those guys are!
Cool flamingo area too great photo op.

I've always been a fan of Busch Gardens and am very thankful that Tampa has a theme park along with a water park as well. We used to have an annual pass but didn't use it as often as we should have so we only go during Howl-O-Scream or a random day. It's an awesome place for a theme park and is very big in comparison to other parks. For days where we don't feel like dealing with Universal/Disney World traffic or lines, we go to Busch Gardens for our alternative and I must say that I've never been disappointed with Busch Gardens. They also have animal safaris and a lot of things to do there. It's always a grand time every time. If you are going during busy peak days and hours such as spring break, summer, Howl O Scream, I would highly recommend the fast pass because if not, you will not be having any fun waiting in those extreme lines.

Very nice park & well designed but today they dropped the ball.  The power went out around 3pm, I get it things happen so we waited around 2 hours & decided to leave. At the exit their was an Team member with a "may I help" flag.  He said don't go everything will be up in running very soon, he even gave us 4 fast passes.  Okay, sure we'll wait a bit, we'll another 2 hours go by & still no rides running.  Quite an expensive day to be cut so short. 

Great customer service they contacted us & gave us 4 tickets to come back to experience the park & they don't expire for 2 years.  Thanks Busch Gardens we look forward to coming back

This gotta be the funnest, tightest place in the universe. Their roller coasters & rides are superior. Plenty of food to eat. Not to mention all the African wildlife that's around the park. Very versatile amusement park. - @MrGrim2daReapa

This is the second year that I've had the Fun Pass for Florida residents (Cost just under $100) and it is totally worth the price! I've gone here at least 7 times this year and have normally piled into a car with an 'annual passholder' who gets free parking. Since parking costs $18 otherwise, this is a great setup and I will eternally thank my friend for it!

The coasters at BG are fanstastic (I recommend Cheetah Hunt, Montu, Kumba & Sheikra). And I must say that Falcon's Fury is much better than expected. Soooo smooth and offers beautiful views of Tampa. Not as scary as it appears. All rides have cubbies to hold your small bags, sunglasses and shoes. If you have a backback, you may be asked to lock your bag away at a locker to pick up later. The park is very shady with many trees and you probably wont have to worry about burning in the Florida sunshine. 

There are several locations for beer/liquor if you like to drink and ride coasters. Our first stop is normally the Crown Colony Cafe next to Cheetah Hunt which is a great place to get craft brews or mixed cocktails. Another great spot is the pretzel place right by Falcon's Fury.  Water fountains are also located at all bathroom locations throughout the park. Such a great place to visit!

HAD A BLAST

I loved taking photos of the animals and saw Peter Noone with Herman's Hermits Music Show.  

It was a cold day and the crowds were light!

Amazing day!

So this is the trip that every parent looks forward to for their child. A trip to Busch Gardens Tampa Bay. My daughter and her class went there for the Halloween festivities. While she was there,  she purchased a bottle of water for $3 at the Tigris kiosk souvenir shop. She handed her $20 to pay for a $3 water and was given $7 back. I'm not saying my daughter's a genius but she knows that she should be getting back $17. There was a very long line and she was  hurrying so that she wouldn't hold people up. When she walked outside and looked down at her change she noticed that $10 was missing and that she had only gotten back $7. This also happened to her friend at the same kiosk with the same cashier. It appears there is a cashier at that kiosk who feels that it's okay to steal money from children because the children won't speak up or notice. I am so unhappy and disappointed about it, not just because a place like Busch Gardens shouldn't have that happening, but also because it left her $3 short of the breakfast money she needed for the next morning. I think it's really despicable when adults take advantage of children. If had only happened to my daughter than I would say it's possible it was a mistake, but she's 14 and she knows some math and it also happened to her friend who is also 14 and also knows some math. So that leads me to use my math and say one plus one equals foul on Busch Gardens Tampa and the cashier at the Tigris kiosk who was working there last night on September 27th 2019. Know that our family will not set foot there again. I really hope that someone from Busch Gardens Tampa will look into this and see what their employees are doing.

Busch Gardens is best theme park in Florida, and not just because it's here in Tampa, but because over the years they've done what other attractions around the state did not--adapt.

In the 50s and 60s, Florida was a sleepy state that relied on tourism for capital.  With the sweet allure of beautiful sunsets, white sandy beaches and great attractions like Sunken Gardens, Weeki Wachee and Cypress Gardens, the hope was to turn visitors into residents.  

Built on a piece of land that previously served as Tampa's temporary international airport (Henderson Field), was Busch Gardens, and it was far from the theme park we know today.  It was basically a park with some benches and trees, and if one was interested, a brewery tour was available.  That was about it.

Then came Disney.

Walt Disney quietly purchased a ton of acreage outside of Orlando in a sleepy town no one had ever heard of called Kissimmee, and someone over at Busch Gardens started planning for the future.  In the years to come, rivers were dredged and straightened, natural watersheds were ruined, interstate highways were built and mom & pop roadside attractions on Florida's forgotten state roads began shutting their doors.  

But not Busch Gardens.

My first visit was shortly after my family was first stationed at MacDill AFB in 1978.  I can remember waiting in line for 30 minutes to ride the Mamba and the Gravatron.  And as I got older, rides like The Python and Scorpion were considered scary and insane.  As time when on, and as roller coasters became more advanced, Busch Gardens made the neccessary adaptations to keep up with customer demands.  Their foresight and ability to remain competitive with the larger parks in Orange County is, to me, why Busch Gardens is the #1 theme park in the state.
This is summer nights it's 10 pm and most of the restaurants are closed along with the bars this is not good....get with it Busch Gardens

I loved the atmosphere here!

I had a great time visiting the park during Christmas time! I thought that the park was extremely clean and the lines were not bad at all. I really love the fact that I can enjoy viewing wildlife here as well as enjoying the thrill of riding roller-coasters. I was not dissatisfied at all with the rides that they have here. My favorite ride here would definitely be the Cheetah Hunt. The park definitely gave great park shows as well! 

I definitely will be buying an annual pass when I move back to Tampa.

Hey not a bad park at all!! Lines aren't too long, lots of cool rides, zoo nice touch for when rides shut down down for storms and such. Lots of shade, cooling sprayers, places to sit and get refreshment. I'm not a ride person- family is- so the side amenities matter to me. It's clean, well maintained, staff is helpful and friendly. Lots of good people watching. Food-- avoid the all you can eat deal unless you eat like a pig and care not for quality. Clearly cuisine from a can- edible but just so.  Nicer food around but don't honor the feed bag deal!!
Fun place to hangout. Love all the rides and the new additions to the park. Great place to bring the family. Love this place

Given that I cut my roller coaster teeth at THE best park, Cedar Point, I was less than blown away by the rides offered.  However we did have a nice family day here. Plus they offer an amazing $12 deal where you can dine all day at specific restaurants throughout the park. I know you're thinking " I bet the food was garbage and there is only one participating restaurant" and you would be wrong! There were plenty of places to choose from, the food was actually very good, and the portions were plentiful. I don't know how they make money off this deal, but it was worth every dime.  My teenage son who will consume as much food as he can get his hands on, ate pizza, ribs, 2 bacon cheeseburgers, fries, watermelon, Oreo cupcake dessert, plus I can't even recall how many bottles of water he consumed! As much as I love Cedar Point, I would have spent well over $100 to feed this kid and I only spent $12. The kids had a good time, I left with money in my pocket, and Sheikra is a pretty cool ride for the coaster enthusiast!

Beautifully decorated for Christmas and LOVED the safari tour !!!! The tour was an additional $50 but worth it !! The tourist was super informative and was willing to answer any questions anyone had about any of the animals . We got to feed the giraffes and take selfies w them!!

After missing several years of fun passes due to family circumstances, I bought one day passes for my visiting family from out of state and fun passes for myself and my other half. Needless to say, I did not keep up with the changes in the past few years and arrived to find many of my favorites no longer in existence!  Gone are the sit down restaurants with full and tasty meal choices and replaced by fast food for the most part, with the exception of one open only on weekends.Gone are the variety shows that used to keep us so entertained and replaced with a more quick variety of entertainment.  Gone are the rides if you're not into roller coasters such as Tidal Wave and Rhino Rally which were favorites of mine. This park is no longer for seniors (my mom and now deceased dad used to have annual passes every year and loved going). The only part for small kids is Sesame Street Safari of Fun. My four year old grandson did not enjoy any of the rest of the park at all. This park has turned into a roller coaster park with fast food options and appears to be marketed for the 16-35 crowd. Won't waste my money on another fun pass next year! This is no longer the theme park I used to love!

If you're looking for fun in the sun, in the Tampa Bay area. Busch garden is definitely the place to go. Busch gardens have so much to offer. For the individuals that enjoy roller coasters, there are several to choose from. There's a huge area designated for children, the Sesame Street characters was a huge success. For the little ones in my group, lots of interaction with the characters. Although I didn't have the chance to experience the safari tour, it's definitely something on my to-do list.  Bush garden has plans that are affordable for everyone. My family purchased the silver packet, which includes multiple parks as well as discounts. We also purchased the meal pass, which allows you to eat at various restaurants throughout the park.  Drinks are free all day.  Individuals have the option of skipping the long lines with priority access.

10/18/2018
So far it's been a really nice day! Parking was a snap with plenty of parking. The wait for security was almost a walk through and the lines for the rides maybe 5-10 minute waits!
I personally believe they need a few more less petrifying rides but their rides are fun. I myself am terrified of some of the heights and turns but overall good rides.

Went for the first time in 6 yrs. Bought the Quick Queue Passes. 3 of the coasters we tried to ride were ' temporarily down for technical problems'. Seems during peak tourist season you should be able to keep your rides running. Ridiculous.
I love Busch Gardens most favorite places to go to . I'm a roller coaster junkie . And the best part  I can spend all day at this place

Busch Gardens is the coaster champion of Florida.  The park is tiny compared to the other guys but the somehow manage to shoehorn in an exceptionally great collection of coasters.  Steel Gwazi looks like it will be pure insanity when it opens.

Downside?  The park is bloody confusing to walk around.  Endless paths seem to go nowhere.

Updating my review completely as Busch gardens representatives have reached out numerous times and we came to a solution. I appreciate you reaching out to a long time customer. My brother will hopefully allow my nephew to come with me on the 12th but if not I will be going myself to enjoy the 20th anniversary of howl o scream. Thank you for the opportunity to do so this year as next year we will not even be able to afford any type of pass.

This was my first visit to Busch Gardens.  Nothing can compare to a Disney park, but this one is pretty close.  I visited with my daughter and her boyfriend, and our mission was to ride all of the roller coasters. February is a great time to go as there are very few lines and hardly more than a 10 minute wait.  The first roller coaster we rode was the wooden roller coaster Gwazi.  It was literally the best wooden roller coaster I have ever been on, it is fast and rickety!  We also rode Montu, Kumba, Cheetah Hunt and Sheikra.  Because there are no lines, we rode in the front seat and back seat of most of them. The park is huge and involves a LOT of walking.  The animal habitats are some of the best I have seen.  The tiger exhibit has a box you can climb up into, and the tiger is sitting on top!  That was so fantastic!! We turned our ticket in at the end of the day for a free one, but we were so exhausted by the end of the week (and all the other parks) that we just couldn't do the hour drive again.  This park gets a 4 compared to a Disney park because the employees are unfriendly and act as if they do not wish to be there, and the park is nowhere near as clean or well maintained as a Disney park.  But the roller coasters are excellent!

Was a season ticket holder for many years until just recently when they decided to cancel the two-year membership they used to offer.  No one from the park has ever reached out to ask why I (and my fiance) both decided to cancel after all these years.  The remaining one-year season program is just not cheap enough for someone who was averaging about once a month visits.

The park itself is great, especially if you enjoy amusement park rides.  They are generally changing things around every couple years to keep things fresh, which is one of the reasons why I choose the higher four star rating.

They offer concerts throughout the year that are included with your admission.  Unfortunately they recently expanded the 'paid' area for these concerts making it more difficult to get a good seat.  You often have to get there hours before the concert and bake in the sun before it starts.  They also have these annoying light towers that block a large portion of the free seats from good views on both sides of the stage. Why can't these be moved out since they are no longer used for the summer Cirque Due Soleil shows that are no longer offered.

The park has several other fun things to do like the animal areas, ice skating shows, singing and dancing shows and a Sesame Street kids area that even has a little-kids roller coaster (Air Grover) that is actually pretty fun even for adults.  Also a new roller coaster is opening in a couple months...

Overall a great park that would get us back as customers if they brought back the two-year membership AND cared why we didn't renew in the first place.

Bush Gardens is  a zoo with rollercoaster its for animal lovers and thrill seekers like my daughter. There rides are mostly death defying rollercoaster. There were a few rides that were relaxing for myself like the water Rapids, a train that takes you from one end of the park to the next while encountering animals, the sky ride, cobra curse and Sand Serpent. They had a indoor ice skating performance. And many animals like Lion, monkey, penguin, elephant, cheetahs, alligators and much more. What I didn't like about the park is your not allowed to bring food or drinks.

Hey, not a bad place to chill for a day in Tampa.  No where near as colorful and big as Disneyworld, but its a good (and cheaper) alternative.   Check-in gates should be shaded because the lines can be long and the sun can be brutal.  We give Busch Gardens a little hug, not a big juicy hug.  Verdict: 3 stars.

Going to Busch Gardens really wasn't a priority for this trip.  The only other time I've been to Tampa was on a day trip to go to Busch Gardens back in 2000 so I didn't feel the urge to return. My ever-so-charming host and Tampa native lives literally next door to Busch Gardens.  After breakfast at Waffle House, it was 9:30am on Sunday morning and I didn't want to kill time until noon when stores opened up in Hyde Park.  Since Busch Gardens was open, we figured we should spend at least part of our day there.  It was great that we could just walk 4 blocks to the park entrance.

Tickets are $65 but they're like a season pass.  I get free entry no matter how many times I return between now and the rest of the year.  It's a nice added-value in case I do return to Tampa this year.

I love rollercoasters and Busch Gardens has some of the best.  The SheiKra features a 90 degree, 200 foot drop.  The car stops right on the curve for 10 seconds so you're looking straight down and then you plummet.  This is one of the best rollercoasters ever.

I loved riding the Montu back in 2000 and got to go twice this time.  You get to go really fast in inverted loops and your feet get to dangle.  The Gwazi is an intertwined, double wooden rollercoaster - shaky as hell but that's part of the fun.  The Kumba has a few long drops and a huge 360 degree spiral.  The adrenaline was pumping after going on all these rides.

My favorite water ride here is the Congo River Rapids.  You're on a 12 person circular raft and you're hit by water cannons, huge rapids and go under a waterfall.  It's bumpy and you'll get drenched.

I really only wanted to go on the thrill rides but I was convinced to go on the Rhino Rally.  It's set up as a safari ride in a land rover and we drive around looking at the different animals.  In the middle there are some theatrics where we've steered of course and then we're floating in a river.  It's cute and a good option for families.

The park was busy but there didn't seem to be much of a wait for many of the rides.  Maybe 15-20 minutes at most.  It also helps when you can navigate the park with ease when your host knows Busch Gardens like the back of his hand.

I couldn't leave the park without having me some Dippin' Dots.  I do love those Dippin' Dots.

Super super super! Se vi piacciono i parchi divertimento, è quello che fa per voi! Curato nei minimi dettagli, davvero. E bellissimo anche per la presenza di animali stupendi, per quando si vuole rifiatare qualche minuto :D
Saw The Diamonds performance today at Stanleyville theater. Their music was great. They sang songs from the 50s. Performers also played brass instruments.
My daughter and I love Busch Gardens. I got us annual pass. We try to go once a month.

I don't know how some people dislike Busch Gardens, i read some of their complain most of them are about the wait time or just not enough things to do simply because they don't do ride. I mean come on do some research before you go? If one ever been to Disney and universal studios, the waited time in Busch garden is actually less most the time,  don't just expect an empty park when you only paid 100$. I like Busch garden I'm their gold pass member,every time I go I see a company trying very hard to improve and compete with other theme park,they almost put out a new ride every year how much more can people asking for? Keep up the good work Busch garden,you got the best roller coaster in Florida.

Second time here with annual pass, this time it was a bit cooler out and a weekday so not as crowded. Just wanted to walk around and look at animals no rides. Seemed that there was no shutdown due to rain this time. They of course had the skyride closed again and some other ride.

Didnt know they dont give you free beer anymore since busch sold the park.

$22 to park way too much money. 

I took some pics of the kangoroos, they looked so depressed in their fenced in small area, barely enough room to hop around just lied docile on ground was sad. They also had a lot of them in that small fenced in area. Animals just looked so sad and I am not a big animal fan.

I remember coming here years ago and how much fun I had. After today, I'm infuriated with how poorly run it is. The layout of the park is great and the rides are fun. I love how the animals are everywhere and always near you. However, the workers were rude, every ride line was insanely long, and 2 of the rides I waited in line for an hour for shut down because of technical difficulties. I purchased the all day dining pass and the food wasn't even good. The chicken fingers tasted like rubber and the pulled pork sandwich Tasted old. I will NEVER come here again. Waste of money. Busch gardens better shape up.

3 killer coasters! We got free entry with our discovery cove pass, so the price was right. Sheikra is the craziest coaster I've ever ridden with a true 90 degree drop; get on the front row!! The animal exhibits were surprisingly pretty neat also, which made for nice walks between the coasters.

Any parks that honors it's service men and women by giving free admission to them and up to three dependent ID cardholders will ALWAYS get my full support in return. I just wish I had gotten to this park prior to 2009 when they had the free beer and brewery tours I've heard so much about. But no worries; this park is still top notch. 

I appreciated all of the animal encounters that you can do without having to pay extra. One of the staff with the elephants was super generous; since he saw us there earlier in the day, when we came back later in the evening, he let us feed one of them, and gave us more demonstrations. He showed us what to do to get her to shake her head and a couple of other movements!  It was all of our highs for the day!!!  I highly encourage asking tons of questions about these beautiful creatures. The staff loves their animals and appreciates your curiosity.  I also appreciated their use of "we ask the animals to do..." They no longer demand the animals to perform any tasks; they use only positive encouragement/reinforcement. 

You also have to stop by and see the kangaroos. Feed them and pet them!  I had no clue they were so soft. 

We will be back!

We went on Thursday. Easy parking, easy on to the tram, five minute waits for rides, great rides, friendly staff, nice animal habitats, and food prices that aren't too crazy. Wow, I'm not used to this! For someone who is used to the struggle of going to So Cal amusement parks, this is amazing. To top it off, this is like an upscale Knott's Berry Farm, mixed with a touch of Six Flags and a pinch of Wild Animal Park. It is so worth the entrance fee! The downside is that I'm no longer going to be motivated to go to Knott's or Six Flags. Florida 4ever!

I have always loved Busch Gardens, and have been coming here for 40 something years. I enjoy both locations (Tampa and Williamsburg) immensely. You may find a bad review here or there, but I would chalk that up to a patron having an issue versus something that would occur often. Take those with a grain of salt.  Of course, this being a theme park, the food prices are outrageous, but the quality is very high, and I am not aware of any exceptions to this pricing scheme anywhere in the country at any park. There is nothing there food-wise that disappoints. As a matter of fact there was nothing disappointing in the entire visit.  The only thing I can complain about is a minor thing which is a pet peeve of mine. The website does not have the correct amount showing for parking.  Theme park that has an annual budget of hundreds of millions of dollars (not an exaggeration) art to be able to have correct parking fee information on the website. I don't think I'm being nitpicky about that. Parking was $25 and the website clearly stated $18 when I checked in the morning before we left the house.
