The majority of the animal enclosures are really nice and the animals seem content and healthy.  We have thoroughly enjoyed watching the babies of many of the animals grow up.  

We are not big on rides, but have done a few of the coasters and Cheetah Hunt is a favorite.   The train to view the animals is not one of our favorites as it seems to break down often and doesn't add all that much to the animal encounter.  Take all the walks, they are more enjoyable.

Many of the shows are good, and the music sessions in the early part of the year are great,  but get your seats early as the theatre fills up quickly.   We love Christmas in the park as the decorations are beautiful and Christmas Town gets us in the holiday spirit.

Food is hit or miss.  We have tried many of the places and food isn't consistent, and is expensive.

There is something off about this place. It is not the location being in the middle of no where. It is not the general lack of guest service they have. It is not even the lack of safety I fell when I am on their attractions. For me, everything feels so forced and old. What I mean by old, like not fresher up for so many years. 

I visited this location maybe seven or so years ago. My partner at the time and I walked around the whole park. Which when we were there that time, everything was closed due to "inclement weather." Which was not to be seen all day. 

When we visited, everything looked the same. Literally the same. While I appreciate how much it can cost to update and change attractions and lands within a theme park, an effort must be placed. Unfortunately, there does not seem to be a need on their end to do so.

We went yesterday 4/7/2021 and friends we were with had platinum passes. We were supposed to get 50% off our tickets. After 30 mins of discussions and denying the discount even though was told day before that guests would get 50% off they continued to deny it. Eventually they did give us the discount but took forever. At the same time others behind us overheard our situation and became concerned about their guests getting the discount and were on the phones. 
once in park-most food places were closed. So when we needed food everyone flocked to same few places. We stood in line for 2.5 hours for cold chicken fingers and hard waffle fries. The girl running thr stand near the Tigris roller coaster who was cooking the chicken fingers and waffle fries snack bar was the absolute slowest human being on earth. She did not try to hustle knowing there was a line and how long people were standing there. She continued to look at her phone and slooooowly get food. My toddler was losing his ever loving mind with hunger bc we can't bring snacks in- but not small snack bars with small lines existed there in the park That I could go to to help with his hangry self! At this point we had gone in ONE ride. It took over an hour to get on. EVERYTHING TOOk OVER AN HOUR TO GO ON. UNLESS YOU SPENT THE EXTRA $100/person fast pass- but we even noticed people were still waiting long time to get on rides. Basically- barely got on any rides bc of long lines and time- long lines for food which made it not worth the trip. Half of the events were closed and cafes. Waited almost 2 hours to ride train bc they had to skip every other row for social distancing- it's outside and we all had masks on?!? Not necessary. Our trip to Busch Gardens in a nutshell Will be remembered as the day we waited in line not the rides. NOT WORTH THE MONEY! Go to Aquatica! It was awesome.

They claim they are at half capacity for guest entry, so we reserved our day, but when we got there it took and hour and half to just get through the lines for temperature checks. Then once we were able to get to the gate entry they were letting everyone in, even those without reservations! It took us and hour and 45 minutes waiting in line for food. They had 3 of their restaurants closed, and none of the small drink vendors throughout the park were open. There's was no social distancing at all in the park, but the kids rides seats were being cut in half for social distancing, but not the adult rides. . The ride wait times were 2 hours to 2 1/2 hours long. They were are charging $129 for fast passes and they are only $19 after the new year. Basically they are letting everyone in, but haven't employed the staff to keep up. It was an extremely poor experience for this theme park. I heard several guest complaining about the same issues we had as well.

Place was fun as a pass holder we would go all the time. However the company's policy to discriminate against disabled people is appalling. They denied access to the park due to my disability. No accommodation at all. All they did was freeze our passes until they change their policy. Outrageous especially because when I bought the passes that wasn't their policy. Everyone thinking masks and social distancing helps, if it did this would be over by now. It's out there like the flu, oh wait that disappeared. Not everyone can wear a mask. Not everyone should be forced to. They don't make you safe. There's no guarantee.

Ok so first of all I have to say some people put such a BS for reviews so much negative crazy reviews, when my husband got tickets I start reading and actually I didn't want to go . But since we got it let's go see & let me tell you we had a blast we spend all day there with 2 kids age 11 & 4 and they both had blast , stuff super nice friendly and informative , hand sanitizers everywhere if you wNt you can have mask or not , lines to rides where going super fast you can find something for everyone and trust me it's crazy amount of smiles all day . As far as food let me tell you I LOVE FOOD & I tried almost everything very tasty delicious & fresh we were very happy , only thing is lines are long but one person waited the others enjoy something in between and time went by quickly .
AnywAy who ever wrote those ridicules negative review that I read had to be in different park I'm serious .
One advice make sure you have some change of clothes few rides can get you wet 
Definitely will be back next year .
Thank you Bush Garden employees for making it such a pleasant visit .

I've been a pass holder off and on for 15 years, more recently mostly "off". I decided to become a pass holder again this year, and after a handful of visits, I miss the park we used to visit when it was owned by Anheuser-Busch. I miss what I feel was overall, a more customer service oriented environment. What happened?? 

Yes, there are more roller coasters and I love them. But they've closed down and scaled back on many of the areas and attractions that made the park unique. 

I'm sure the annoyances I've experienced recently are unique to my personal circumstances, but I waited so many years for the time when my son would finally enjoy coasters, and it's finally here! We enjoy going to the park together with minimal personal items, and closing the storage cubes at all the coaster exits "for the safety of the guests" is just a load of crap. They've been there since the beginning of time, and no one has ever stolen my drink cup, flip flops, or sunglasses (if you want to leave your purse/valuables in an insecure cube, you're an idiot). Today, we could not step in line with a refill cup because the cubes were closed. We were also told that we couldn't wait together and take turns riding while the other held the stupid cup at the exit, that we'd have to get back in line a second time. Or, we could rent a locker ($2 each area, $8.00 all day...this makes buying the stupid refill cup completely pointless if you have to pay $8 a day to store it in a locker!)

I told my son to go ahead and ride alone while I waited at the exit. While waiting there, I watched every coaster (10-12) pull away with *never less than 4 open seats each time. My son patiently waited in line for 40+ minutes to ride alone with an empty seat next to him. So my next question is why hasn't Busch Gardens caught on to "single rider lines" yet??? 

I wouldn't mind a few changes so much if we were at least given some advance warning. As a pass holder, I get emails regularly...you think they could  have mentioned this at some point, somewhere before we got into the park. 

Despite having to enforce stupid policies, I find the staff (*most of them) to be very polite and friendly. The food is hit or miss. I usually wait to grab something after we leave, but I had a $10 credit that had to be used so we got chicken tenders, waffle fries, and chocolate cake. I thought the chicken tenders were fantastic at Howl O'Scream, but must have been really hungry because today nothing tasted very good.

Despite my dissatisfaction, I have an entire year to go, so I will make my adjustments as needed, get my fill and (more than) money's worth, and look into Universal passes next year!

Went today to Busch gardens, horrible experience. Complete chaos from the get go. Waited in line 1 hour 45 minutes to get in with no social distancing. We were practically shoulder to shoulder in crowds. We tried to stay further back from people ahead of us, but because everyone was waiting so long, people were pushing through. My kids rode one roller coaster and process took 2.5 hours. Had meal voucher so went to eat after the one ride. it took 2 hours on the food line. The place was overcrowded, even with reservation process. I can't believe how overcrowded with covid. We left after eating, which we only ate because of food voucher and we were starved at that point being there for 5 hours and getting on only one ride.  It was the biggest disappointment for myself and kids. I can't believe they allow this during covid. Have been to all Disney parks, and universal. This was worst experience I've ever had. We had 2 park tickets and planned on Seaworld, but will be forfeiting our tickets after this experience.

Visited Food and wine festival and what a  joke! None of the booths opened on time - supervisors walking around not attending guests. Help did not know what they were doing. Joke and a waste of my day! Very disappointed to see Busch Garde

Worst park we've ever been too. Park is laid out like a maze and they don't give you a map. Paid full price and so much of the place was closed, from rides, to restaurants and exhibits. Whole family was throughly disappointed!

Spent part of an afternoon at the park, I do realize that there could be staffing shortages but the experience at the park was horrible. The lines for food were ridiculous and in most cases most of the food was sold out. The lines for the rides  were reasonable but at least 5 of the major rides attractions and shows were closed. Half of the drink and snack stands were closed. Once again I understand that Covid has some effect on normal operations, but when one asked to pay full price for tickets (120$), you have expectations that you can have a reasonable enjoyable experience. We left the park after 3 hours which was not  planned.

Always come here once a year so I can get in for free and every time it's different.
I always come during a weekday and during the school year so it's not super packed. 
Love everything about Busch Gardens and I'll always come here when I'm in Tampa every year.

Nice park but doesn't compare to Disney's Magic Kingdom or Epcot so if you're debating on which park to visit, visit one of the Disney parks as the prices are comparable. Positive is that lines are shorter here as there's less people. I enjoyed the roller coasters and seeing the various animals like lions, tigers, hyenas, orangutans, gorillas, crocodiles and more. Food is below average compared to Disney. Standard parking is $20.

Busch Gardens is a unique amusement park, essentially a Six Flags and a zoo put together. This hodge podge at times seems a bit strange, but I enjoyed the variety - and hopefully the diversity of attractions means there's something for everyone in your party!

Many of the roller coasters are a bit short and may have long waits. If you're going during a busy season, a fast pass will likely be a wise investment. Though I came in December, so it was pretty empty. The animal attractions are pretty cool, with some of my favorites being the kangaroos, the interactive bird houses, and the big cats. You can also take the train through the large plains to see more animals that aren't as easy to see from the pathways.

Pricing can be pretty steep - as much as $100 per person or more! But if you get the Tampa Bay City Pass, that can make it more affordable (as long as you also want to do other bay attractions). Also, while the park itself is nice, the area it's in is a bit run down, so be aware of that if you're booking lodging or finding parking (it's best to pay for the park parking, even if it's pretty steep). Overall a fun experience if you're a fan of thrill rides and wild animals.

My boyfriend and I just purchased platinum annual passes a few days ago and have gone twice now. We appreciate the free preferred parking that comes with our platinum passes. We are from Georgia and have season passes to Six Flags which we've been going to all summer... and let me just say, Busch Gardens blows Six Flags out of the water. Busch Gardens is SO clean, the staff has been nothing but immensely friendly, the rides have LOTS of variety, the wait times aren't too terrible, all prices are reasonable, and there are plenty signs and maps located throughout the park to help us figure out where we are.

The ONLY warning I give to you inquisitive potential park-goers is this:

There are lots of wasps (mainly in the summer) and you very well may get stung by one. I got stung by one DURING the Cheetah Hunt ride on my back. I am pretty sure that the wasp somehow got behind my back right before the coaster took off, and then when the ride took off, I leaned back and got stung. I thought that the ride had somehow electrocuted me at first because it hurt so badly. Then I quickly remembered seeing the wasps all over the park and realized I had been stung. The first aid employee was able to give me Benadryl and some sting cream that helped. Another park employee told me that Busch Gardens sometimes closes the park just to spray for wasps so I know they are at least trying to get it under control. (So I'm not mad!!!) I still plan on going and can't wait to ride Cheetah Hunt again! Haha.

Great park. We went on Xmas eve eve and it was quite crowded but everyone maintained decent social distancing. The people of Florida are very cool. Not scared mice like Californians. Covid can hang while we enjoy ourselves safely. I'm a huge fan of Busch gardens. Way better than Disney.

If I could give my review a title, it would be 'LOL' because this place is a joke. 

My girlfriend and I have been here twice and have had an awful time both times. Before the pandemic, it was raining the entire time we were there and pretty much every single ride was closed. What kind of theme park doesn't have one or two indoor attractions available to do when it rains? Busch Gardens, I guess. Anyway, they gave us a rain pass so we could come back another time.

We came back this weekend and greatly regretted it. 

Social distancing is not being enforced by park employees AT ALL and many guests were walking around the park with their masks off. The park was not clean, as one of my friends said when they went to the restroom that there was actual crap all over the walls. The ride wait times were severely under-estimated, meaning you would get in line expecting an hour-long wait only for the wait to be over two and a half hours long, which is stupid. 

The lack of maintenance for the rides here is ridiculous. The worst part of the day was when we got in line for Sheikra and waited over two and a half hours only for the ride to "break down" and for everyone to have to leave the line when the park closed. "Break down", my butt! Very obvious that the employees just wanted to go home. Do they only have like one maintenance guy handling all of the rides here? I've never operated an actual theme park, but I've played enough rollercoaster tycoon to understand why that doesn't work.

My friends and I were here for over eight hours and only got to ride one ride. We had actually gone for my friend's birthday and she was super upset because she didn't even get to have a good time. 

After the park closed, my girlfriend and I went to guest relations to tell them about our poor experience to see if there was anything they could do. We ended up speaking with that department's manager named Mike. I do not understand how he got promoted to his position with such poor customer service skills. He did not listen to our concerns. We told him that we would like reimbursement for our parking and our food, then he started going off about how he couldn't reimburse out park ticket. We weren't ASKING for our park ticket to be reimbursed! Learn to listen to people! Then he starts saying that he can't reimburse our parking or our food because we don't have the receipts for them. Who keeps the receipts for those things? No one does! He then starts saying that if he were to give us the money for those things without a receipt, it would look like he was stealing from the company. Ridiculous! I work in customer service and would never say something to a customer to insinuate that they are trying to make me do something illegal. 

He then suggests that we go back to our car to get the receipt for our parking and come back in to get reimbursed. What?! He expects me to go all the way back to my car to get a receipt only to not be able to get back into the park because firstly, the park is closed, and second, I don't even have a ticket anymore because the front gate employee took my rain pass when I came in???!!! Make it make sense, sir! 

The absolute worst part was when Mike threatened to call security on my girlfriend because she had the audacity to use a curse word when describing how awful our experience was. She basically said another version of, "I've had a crappy experience today," and he threatened to call security on her for "cursing at him." What a joke! You don't threaten to call security on people for relaying to you how poor their experience was! THAT IS YOUR JOB! YOU WORK IN GUEST RELATIONS! If she had been swearing AT HIM and calling him curse words, I would have understood the need to call security, but it was very obvious that he just didn't want to help us. The icing on the cake was that the only resolution he could provide to us was another rain pass when we had already asserted multiple times that we didn't want to come back! Why would we want to come back when we've already had two terrible experiences here? 

The cherry on top of this crappy cake is that he then recommended that we send Busch Gardens an email with our receipts to request the reimbursement through that means. We asked what the guarantee was that we would be reimbursed if we send them and he says, "there isn't any." Again, LOL! So I'm supposed to waste my time tracking down receipts and sending them to Busch Gardens so they can 'maybe' do something to help me? Again, what a freaking joke! 

Busch Gardens is a crappy theme park, before and during pandemic. The coasters are fun, but that doesn't mean anything when everything else about the park sucks so bad to the point where you hardly even get to experience them. DO NOT waste your money here! If you are looking for a theme park in Florida that is operating properly during pandemic and is actually fun, go to Universal Studios instead.

Gold pass holder.  Went today. Most of the shops were open.  All of the rides were open with a few exceptions, the sky ride and the water rides were not open.   Pretty good experience overall.  Park was not crowded at all.

This trip was a huge disappointment. As pass members, we love this park but with the current restrictions we really haven't ventured anywhere. Decided to try the park with reservations, hoping for a relaxed family experience. Boy, were we shocked to see the crowds.  There was TOO MANY people and very few rides, shows, or stores operational.  Not even the tram takes you to the entrance. Your dropped off down the road to begin the day of walking to nowhere.

The crowds were too heavy with some areas bottlenecking. Yes, employees are walking around with signs that say social distancing, but we had to remind folks to back up. The masks are on the whole time, which is okay if everyone kept their mask on, which they don't. We did see security telling folks to put their mask on and over their nose, as we walked among the crowds.

But the major blow was that all the shows were closed up, plenty of the rides were too. So what ended up happening in the rides that were open, you were looking at 90+ minutes wait. There was nowhere to go, with this many people and so many activities and shows not available. Plus, I hated not having a map, none are being given to guests, to help guide us along and better inform us of what was available. Just to spend the day walking around, to find that rides are closed or have extremely long crowded waits is not acceptable.

Paid for preferred parking for our family member's vehicle and when we got there they inform us that the lot was full. Then we had to stand in the customer service line for over an hour to be given a refund with Busch money. It takes them 30 to 60 days to issue you a credit card refund. That's awful, especially when it only took them a second to charge it!

Yes, seeing the one elephant was cute. Taking a one-way train ride after a 40 minute wait to see the other animals running free was cool too. But walking by and not spotting any of the lions, cheetahs, or monkeys was disappointing. Even the penguin tank had maybe 10 in there.  

Busch could do better and they had in the past. This was a mistake and glad we had passes, for we have hope it can only get better.  Feel sorry for all those families that paid the extreme one day ticket per person to have nothing at the end of the day, except perhaps a picture with a mask on by a lighted tree.

Absolute poop show!!! Do not ever go. This situation is actually unsafe. No food, no staff. There are so many restaurants, rides and other features closed down. 90 minute plus wait for any food, rides, or attractions. I can't believe I dropped nearly $500 just to get my family in the door. And good luck finding anything. The signage is terrible. Whoever is in charge here should be ashamed of themselves.

I really really enjoyed busch gardens! It's one of new favorite theme parks. I saw they have the Christmas light town so I figured so that, explore what animals they have and get on some rides. You do have to make reservations before you go but they still let you in if you don't. I guess it's luck. The day I went it was ridiculously packed! I probably waited in line between75-120 minutes between each ride, only got on three of them! I didn't like that. Another thing is you have to use lockers and you have to pay for them. Every other theme park I have gone to, they have cubby and you leave your stuff there until you get back. Not sure if it's a new thing with Covid. So you pay $2 for first hour then $1 for each consecutive hour or $8 for the day. Anyways so park is huge they have lots of animals and rides. Parking if free is you have silver or up passes. I got a season pass so I will be back

Very few restaurants open, more than half of rides were not operating, and sanitation was spotty. We took the train with two year old twins and they were operating at one way trip to the next station. We had rented a stroller from the park and were told because it doesn't collapse we would have to leave it there, and that we could do a round trip, and to just stay on the train. The next station would not allow that and only due to us pitching a fit and the fact.that they still had room were we able to take it back. I recommended in the future to have one station call ahead and tell them what was going on to which I was told, yes you should do that. I will not be back.

I visited the weekend before Christmas. The crowds weren't too bad until late when we went through Christmas town. Masks were being enforced at the entrance but there was absolutely no distancing in the lines (I only went to the kids area).  Many kids attractions were closed but the worse part was NONE of the kids rides were wiped or sanitized in any way. I was beyond pissed. Bathrooms weren't very clean either. For the price I expected more. The only highlight was the train ride (after 20 min wait) they did wipe down the train and we were able to see animals up close. Save your money if you're only interested in the kids area and go to Disney or maybe try after covid.

Have you ever heard the saying of someone who can't find their own ass in the dark with two hands?  Welcome to Busch Gardens Tampa Bay.  Wait times grossly inaccurate.  For example Cheetah hunt Reported 60 minutes when we went in at 10:30 am half hour after opening.   Actual time was over 3 hours.  No stoppages during that time either.  Tell me they isn't gross under reporting.  Would've liked to have chosen to not go on the ride.  Wasted half a day on one ride.  I would've actually bought an express pass if I had known how long the lines were really going to be. Then at other rides they don't have wait times posted at all.  No staff at the front of the line either, so it's just a crap shoot.  Not sure if that's better than the gross underestimates.  I suppose it is because my expectations are set.   

Get an express pass.  I saw the same kid go in more than half a dozen times before I even reached half way point waiting in line.

Don't waste your money. Tampa has so much to offer don't waste your time and money here. Went for a day and left after only 2 hours. There were only 2 rides open despite it being one of their busiest days of the year. Of those 2 we tried to ride one, and subsequently were asked to leave the line. They closed that one too!  We left after that. BTW...they only listed 2 rides closed at the entrance. Absolute misrepresentation!

We picked Tuesday to go since we heard it's the least busiest day. 

We purchased tickets in advance for three. We had some discounts but still we paid little less than $350 for 3 including $25 parking charge. 
We spent about $55 for lunch. It was a lunch for 3. If you have hungry family, maybe paying $30 pass for each person might be a better option. 

We got in line before 10am and we walked into the park little after 10am. Our first ride we got on was a bumper car ride. So many rides were temporarily closed. It was little disappointing. By late afternoon some of the temporarily closed rides opened up but some never did. At first we felt like we wanted a refund but because it wasn't so busy, kids were able to go on the favorite rides multiple times. 

We stayed at the park until 5pm. It was a perfect fun day for 7 year old.

This started as an exciting trip to Busch Gardens in Tampa. I'm not from Florida but I have traveled the world and have visited many  theme parks. 
Today, 23 November 2021, my husband, son, mother-in-law and niece started at Busch Gardens around 2 pm and we bought the express pass ($69.00 each) to skip all of the ride lines because it's my husband and My vacation before we both start our next military duty station. We started off in the Emporium and bought super cute refillable cups. As we walked the entire park, we found that all of the rides were "temporarily closed" except the ride Mantu, to our knowledge. All of the refillable stations were closed and the one we did find had a long line and didn't open until 4 pm. The three disrespectful girls that were working at this beverage stand next to the swan garden sculpture and Iron Gwazi (which didn't open until March 2022) have no customer service skills. My husband approached the stand and asked if they refilled the water cups there and with attitude one of the girls shoot her head no. He shook it off and went back into the line with my mother-in-law. Finally it's there turn, they approach the counter once more my mother-in-law asks "What products do you have?" The girl behind the counter, with attitude says water. So, my mother-in-law asks if they have sprite and the girl just said "water". My mother-in-law said," Y'all don't have anything else?" She shook her head saying no. We have water. My husband walks back up and says "ma, they have coke, I'm looking right at it." The girls response was, "well if you knew that then why'd you even ask?" My husband told her his mother was asking and she wasn't telling her.  I understand there was a long line (as these girls who were working this station kept saying in front of all of the customers) but they literally just opened the stand and already complaining for everyone to see. As Military, it's hard to believe that there are such unprofessional and disrespectful people out there when literally all they have to do is go to work, put on a smile for a couple hours and sell prepackaged beverages. Other than this, the park was beautiful and there were plenty of photo opportunities. We got our caricature drawn around 7 pm and the lovely artist did an amazing job, I can't wait to hang it up in our house,Thank you for that experience. She was so kind and very professional. We made the most out of our trip so it still turned out amazing but it only takes one bad experience to ruin a good time and that's unfortunate. I hope y'all find this helpful so you aren't disappointed. Have a great trip!

Tampa bay bush gardens is such an excellent and exiting park to visit! It is family fun for all and staff is superb! The rides as exhilarating, the food and sweets are exquisite! 

There is a large variety of animals to see up close and personal! Really enjoy visiting Bush Gardens!

This has been an all around terrible experience. There is absolutely no social distancing whatsoever. Not enough staff and security presences. Never did I see the "task force that is leading the Coronavirus preparedness and response activity" that Busch Gardens claims they've hired. I absolutely did not feel safe while I was there. The ride attendants ALL were rude and spoke with a dry and unfriendly tone. People are walking around with no face covering or not wearing them correctly. There is very few employees walking around enforcing and monitoring the guest. We found 2 securities and 1 employee standing all together but not correcting the offenders. Guest walked directly in front of them eating and drinking while waking and they wouldn't say anything. I watched guest be allowed in to the park with no face covering and later handed a mask on a ride. I couldn't take it anymore so I decided to go to guest service and asked for a refund. After expressing to the supervisor my feelings and concerns and even provided her with dozens of pictures of people walking with no face covering she wouldn't refund me my ticket. Her response was "if I didn't feel safe than I should have not entered the park." I expressed to her that obviously if I would've seen before hand what I saw threw out my two hours at the park I would have not wasted my time and especially my money.  I don't think I should be the one to have to stay out of the park when I am the one following the rules. The CDC and our governor need to step in and take action against Busch Gardens for the lack of responsibility and the over excessive capacity in the park.

Very poorly run. No staff found walking the grounds to enforce rules, such as non smoking. People smoking and vaping in unauthorized areas. Many shows not open. Several
Rides not operating ie sky ride and train. This park was a disappointment.

We were having a great time until we bought shirts.  I was charged correctly, he wasn't.  He was charged 10.00 too much.  He didn't realize until we left the store.  We went back and the cashier said she couldn't do anything, and she'd have to wait until the one supervisor came to take care of it.  That's right, only one supervisor in the park supposedly.  After waiting 30 minutes we were told she is on her way.  Park is closing, my back is hurting and we are waiting for a supervisor for a 10.00 credit.  Are you kidding me.  This level of customer service is what makes me a disney fan.  Never will I be back.  Are you telling me god forbid someone gets hurt there is only one supervisor in the whole park. Ridiculous.  She is finally here.  She tried to refund it and now  it rings for the right amount when she tries to refund it.  We told her to not ring as a refund and it came up 32.00.  He finally got his full refund.  RIP off artists.

Cobra's Curse...more like Kumba's Curse. Over ten years ago I went to Howlscream at Busch Gardens and someone threw up while on the front row of Kumba and it caused a 30 minute clean up delay. I had yet to witness a delay at Busch Gardens over the years until today. My friends and I decided to wait a little longer to be front row on Kumba and lone behold, as we were about to get on the rollercoaster next, a girl threw up in the front row. What was more disturbing was how the team cleaned it up. They used a spray hose to spray it down with water which caused it all go to the floor where you exit the ride. They ran the rollercoaster cars twice to dry it off and then sprayed it clean. It took about 30 minutes and seemed like the crew was figuring it out as they went. It's concerning that they did not have gloves nor did they wash their hands after. Working healthcare myself, Busch Gardens should provide their staff with PPE for moments like this.
Other than "Kumba's curse", the Skyride, Cheetah Hunt was closed in the morning, and Kobra's Curse was closed. Being a Florida resident, visiting parks in the winter months seems like off season is the worst time to visit which is why the Christmas Town happens. I was also disappointed that the safari ride seems to be only something guests pay for now as an extra excursion.

So 1) I haven't been here in close to 20ish years, 2) we are Disney people and I know you can't compare things to Disney but this place was a disappointment.
Went on a Saturday - tickets were $90ish to get in but came with a free meal (will get to that in a second) and because the rollercoasters had well into the 2-3 time frames to ride, we spent another $99 a person for the unlimited fast passes.
The park was fairly dirty - garbage on the ground, and dirty eating tables. 
The ride lines were long but I think the fast pass was worth it in this case. Just really expensive.

Most of the restaurants were closed so we had to look forever to find a restaurant we could use the free meal at, and because it was the only one open it was like a 30-40min wait.
The servers were the LEAST FRIENDLY people I have ever encountered. I get it, you'r job isn't the most pleasurable but the girl didn't smile, didn't say thing, and barely made eye contact. Check out wasn't any better.
Came out to a super dirty table to eat our food at, and the food was incredibly subpar. How do you mess up chicken fingers and fries????

Overall wouldn't go back. It's not the experience it use to be. Save your money.
Great place for our vacation! Please take the time to plan your day(s) it will make it worth it.

This is the worst run park in our country. Rides break, rides are closed, under staffed, undertrained, and when an issue occurs like a broken ride with a child on it, no one knows what to do and children are lost. like mine was for an hour. I called their risk management and corporate numbers and never received a call back... go to Disney or Universal!

I hadn't been to Busch Gardens, Tampa in years and went today with friends on a Monday--BIG waste of time and money!  Most of the rides were closed, shows closed, concessions closed but you can bet all the souvenir shops were open. Even the 1 train ride was cut short due to repairs.  So you spend your day eating expensive food/snacks and walking miles to find open exhibits.  We did get in to see their Christmas Holiday ice show which was fabulous and professional.  Other than that it was a big disappointment.  The grounds were nice but not as upscale as Disney such as the holiday poinsettias were not real nor was any of the garland.  It just looked old and worn out.

We are pass holders. Christmas town is definitely a must do for the food, best Santa and Santa picture in the area if you have kids, great food samples you can purchase, and shows. If you are local and can make it, try and go in a rainy day, that's when we get the least crowds:) plenty to do wether you like coasters, seeing animals, or have little ones that need to get their energy out.

Way better than the crowded and overdone magic kingdom.

We drove here twice from orlando in a week (an hour or so drive) as this was better than disney and sea world.

Not much of a wait for anything (a bit more on Sunday as compared to the weekday).  You can bring in food/etc, which saves on money.  Buy the plastic small spray bottles ahead of time and fill with water - target sells them for $1 each, which is way better than the 2 for $20 deal they have in the park!

Busch Gardens in Tampa is the best!! Our experience here started off right! Entrance into the park is $20 and my brother asks if there was a military discount. The employee collecting the money says, " No, but I appreciate your service so go right ahead!" I thought that was really nice considering they didn't have to do that! We went on a school day so the lines were not long at all which made the experience fantastic. My brothers and sister and I are rollercoaster lovers so we definitely made it a point to go on all the rides two or three times. I appreciate the length of all of the rides. Usually the rides at amusement parks are super short after the initial plunge or whatever the special feature of the ride is but the rides here make waiting for them not so bad. Trust me, as soon as you think you were done you were plunging into another series of twists and turns and we loved every minute of it. The rides are awesome and puts the Busch Gardens in Williamsburg, VA to shame, even though I would still go there if that was my only choice, lol. 
They do have a zoo of some sort and animal exhibits which are not my thing at all. i always think the animals look sad.
All in all I am definitely looking forward to returning to ride the rides! We had reservations at a restaurant for later so we actually didn't eat or drink anything at the park but they have a lot of different options available.
(The admission price is a little ridic, but the rides are amazing so............)

Expect long wait times at all the rides especially cheetah hunt (for good reason). Don't even try to come during the holiday season unless you want to wait 2 hours per ride. Do come during the off season to enjoy all your rides for waiting under an hour or even 30 minutes. Tons of shows throughout the year and ton of food. You will probably have to come to the park via tram (free) or by walking.

This was our first visit as a pass holder and I was left feeling like why do people love this park so much??   Several rides and most restaurants were closed.  I get it during the off season, but this was a holiday week and it was super packed.  No social distancing was going on other than everyone wearing masks.  Lines were everywhere, hell even to grab some popcorn was 20+mins.  The rides - you can forget it.  The average was over 100 minutes.  The shortest at 1 hour.  They off quick queue but that's if you want to pay $120!!   Today the line was put to the parking lot and we decided to just turn around and leave. We did get to see some of the animals on the trip but overall this trip was a disaster.

As a season pass holder I always have a great time at bush gardens , their parks are always clean and well
Maintained they offer great deals for pass members the staff is always friendly , I enjoy the fact that you can see animals as well as ride the rides ! One complaint is they don't have expectant mother parking . But I wanted to
Compliment their "christmas town" experience , I can't say enough how beautiful the light displays were and how great the shows were and how magical the scenery was ! I've been a pass holder four years and never attended boy was I missing out ! Will now make it a Christmas tradition !
Understaffed in every area .terrible behavior by the patrons.and fairly dirty.would not recommend unless it was to an enemy.

What a great park! They really keep everything clean and sanitary and obide by the COVID masks and rules. I found that the guests were following the rules. The park is 95% out doors, which made it easy to social distance and stay away from people.

They have a lot of cool and unique animals you don't see in every zoo like the Hyenas, elephants, hippos, lots of flamingos... really neat. The roller coasters are not my thing, but my wife road a few and said they were fun and exhilarating. The grill in the middle of the park was decent food: I had chicken fingers and fries, wife had cheese pizza and cheese sticks, and we also tried the pretzels from the pretzel place nearby. The cinnamon sugar pretZel and regular salted were just as good as an auntie Annie's or any other pretzel spot. Overall, a good and fun day. Wait times were short (could be because a Tuesday). Would
Highly recommend!

on my vacation to Orlando, we decided to take a day and head on over to Tampa to check out Busch Gardens. We were surprised to find that the area surrounding the park was rundown and ghetto. There was no where to stop and grab a bite before hand. That didn't ruin the overall experience but I would suggest eating before you go or pack a good amount of snacks if you don't want to pay theme park prices. 

We went with a toddler and this was her favorite place that we visited. She loves the splash area and also the kiddie rides. The only thing that I didn't enjoy was the attitudes of the employees, the majority of the attitudes we the we don't care/I don't want to be here. The park itself is old and rundown. 

The coolest thing was the Animal Care Center. If you make your way to Busch Gardens I would definitely suggest making your way to this area. Jungala was my favorite area inside the park, because I love tigers. All in all it was a good day because my niece had a great time, I am just not sure I would make it a priority. I would give it another shot.

What a dissapointment. Paid for 2 annual gold passes and everytime we come so many rides are closed. The sun is out and it is 4:30pm and the safari train ride is closed again. Didnt realize it until the 3rd employee I stopped after going to each train station at the park finally told me it is closed today. No sign out front, online, nothing. Save your money and just pay for 1 day. It isnt worth what they are charging when rides and food kiasks are closed.

I have been an annual pass holder least 6 years and have mostly enjoyed going to Busch Gardens.   I don't ride many of the rides, unless we bring family along, but I love the animal aspect.   The events such as Mardi Gras, Food and Wine and Christmas town are always fun events.

I understand that COVID has had a major impact on many businesses, and Busch Gardens has suffered also, but for the price you pay, it just isn't worth it anymore.    Many of the rides are still closed, and in the afternoons the animals are often inside.   I usually go early just so I can see the animals.

I went for the October annual pass holders perk of animal encounters and was extremely disappointed.   Three animals...a turtle, an armadillo and a porcupine.    None of these are ones which you can have an encounter.   Two of the three handlers were very informative, but the last just stood there.   I had expected so much more.

They have removed almost all of the hand sanitizing stations which were located everywhere throughout the Park.   The last I heard, COVID is still a problem in our world and people need to take precautions so it doesn't keep spreading.   

We are opting for Zoo tickets next year and likely won't be returning to Busch Gardens.

Busch Gardens is one of those Tampa Bay staples that every local should be going to at least every other year or so. This theme park is more than just rides: they're a venue which hosts all kinds of events (food and wine festival), they're a zoo, and they're a garden. There's also alot of education they provide about the animals and plants they host. Now I do have one disclaimer which is that I didn't go on any rides or roller coasters besides the train and the carousel, but this is a testimony that there-s something for everyone, whether you're a thrill-seeker, adrenaline junky, or just wanna get away from everything. Perfect place to go for holidays and special events. I myself come every year for their Howl-O-Scream event ALMOST every year but one. This is my second time coming out to their Christmas Town where everything is decked out for the holidays. We spent seven hours at the park, and in those seven hours we did alot that was not roller coasters or rides. We went on the train and saw the animals: antelope, giraffes, rhinos, and zebras wandering and roaming freely. Then we went on the other exhibitions and saw the chimps and even had a chance to go underneath a tiger in his enclosure. We had a chance to pet baby kangaroos and be surrounded by birds. The food here is good, but menu is limited and pretty pricey. I highly recommend the smoked chicken, which was large, fall off the bone, and full of smoke flavor. It really hits the spot on a warm day with sone coleslaw and waffle fries.

If you plan to visit Tampa, I HIGHLY recommend getting the city pass. For roughly $120 per person you get admission to five main attractions, one of them being Busch Gardens. My boyfriend and I knew we made an excellent choice getting the city pass when we arrived at BG and saw that general admission was $95. And parking is $17. Yeah, it's expensive but the park needs to be maintained somehow. I think it's worth paying that much to go to Bush Gardens. It's like a zoo and amusement combined together. It's huge and it has an African theme. My boyfriend and I had a blast here. The lines were short and the longest we waited in line was 20 minutes. I really had fun feeding the kangaroos and birds. Food is expensive, so we got one entree and split it. Busch Gardens isn't just for kids- it's for everybody! There is a lot to see and do. It's too bad BG closes early!

Wow oh wow. What a terrible place all around. I have never in my life been to a park that was more disorganized, horrendous and all around bad. This park deserves negative stars and I honestly can't comprehend how it has so many positive reviews in the first place. The wait to get into the parking lot  alone takes HOURS because the entrance they've created is just plain stupid and created a ridiculous traffic jam. We ended up parking elsewhere and walking in to save time. 
Once your finally in, good luck trying to find any rollercoaster, let alone ones that are actually open. They have so many signs that lead you to absolutely nowhere because apparently following the arrows is the wrong thing to do when trying to find anything. We looked and walked for half an hour trying to find any rollercoaster entrance or even an employee to help but there were none to be seen anywhere. I'm not one to write negative reviews but I've been to dozens of parks in my life and this is easily the worst with no competition. I wish I had more words to describe how bad the experience has been but I'll leave it at this: I created a Yelp and wrote this whole ass review while waiting in line for the first ride we have been able to find all day and we still have an hour to go (supposedly) on wait time. -100/10 do better.

Went today with some friend to spend our afternoon doing something fun. Today was the first time riding Tigris and cheetah hunt and I can say that both rides are for people looking for that high but can not do larger coasters that have to many loops or goes to high. The first thing that gets your blood moving with both rides is the acceleration using magnets to get both rides upwards speeds of 45 for Tigris and 65  MPH for cheetah hunt.

One highlight for each ride that makes them both so unique is that cheetah hunt towards the end, zig zags like how cheetahs would run after their prey and with Tigris having multiple twists through out the ride to give you that "big coaster loop" feel. 

The wait time for cheetah hunt as of today was only at 5 minutes since they have two coaster cars verses the 20 minutes you can expect for Tigris with it only having one coaster car. Both rides regardless of wait times are both worth the wait. 

10/10 perfect for a fun family night out weather you are a local or a vacationer.

This is a great place to come and visit. The rides are pretty good, I'm sure you'll find at least a couple that you'll really like.  But beyond the rides there are some great events here. For Halloween they have howloscream , for Christmas they have Christmas town, and they also have BBB(bands, brew, and BBQ). Lots of fun to be had here at all times of the year. 
I you have some time to spare that you should try some of the tours. There are cool safari tours and  If you're around during howloscream than you can go on one of the guided tours. It's a lot of fun and you get to skip in front of the line for the mazes. I come back here all the time. Fun place. Always something new.

Over Priced. Over Crowded. Don't fall for the "all you can eat option" that states your family can eat at one of 6 restaurants every hour, or every 90 minutes.  It would take you that long in any food line, especially since they closed like 1/3 of snack bars, and other eateries. So good options are extremely limited. They of course say nothing up front that they are running the park this way. 

If you have any hopes of riding more than one coaster and eating more than one meal, get ready to spend half of your time in lines. 

Waste of time, money, and energy.  I'd have much rather spent that type of money on an all day boat rental with ski/tubing equipment.

I had an annual pass to Universal Studios and Islands of Adventure for the past year. My girlfriend got us both annual passes to Busch Gardens for our anniversary. Let's just put it this way.... I canceled my pass to Universal the next week.

This park is tons of fun. It has some family elements, but if you love roller coasters like me you can ride them here all day long! I will be coming back regularly whenever we have time for a weekend trip up to Tampa!

Busch Gardens is a big shocker for the unexpected. I had a idea that the park was big but not till my trip here did I really get a personal up close encounter of the rides and the animals. I came here on mlk day and what a day to pick to come. The park was empty I was a little nervous on it being packed with kids not having school. I got there around 11am and stayed till around 6:30pm being the park was about to close at 7pm. 

As far as my actual first impression goes I loved how the park offers so many different ride choices. I want with some close friends who know the park well so I was able to be shown the best features of the park. I rode all the major rides being about 9 coasters my favorite being the cheetah hunt. The lines for rides I was impressed because the park was not busy and I only waited about 20 to 35 minuets per a ride. My longest wait was around a hour being the ride had some technical issues. Me and my group did check out some of the animals but we spent more time on the rides so I can't say much on that aspect. 

Now as far as cost goes I don't think it's worth it not even close. If your a Florida resident you can go all year just by paying a 1 time fee of around $100 bucks. But for a normal family of 4 just to come for 1 day your looking at over $400 dollars not including on the high cost of food and drinks. But yes high cost of food and drinks are expected for a amusement park but that upfront cost of the ticket is brutal. I understand your getting rides and animals in one but I think a more understandable price would be around 59.99 for a one ticket for a non Florida resident. 

Overall I can't imagine what a hot summer day would be like here and how crowded it gets. I would return to Busch Gardens again in the future but I wish they took there pricing into consideration for out of state residents.

This is one of the best amusement parks ever.  

Mostly because it is home to my favorite rollercoaster: SheiKra

I love rollercoasters, (the bigger the better), and I have a sister that won't go near them.  Busch Gardens is a great place for the both of us.  It doesn't disappoint.  

The wildlife is really well "displayed", if you will.  Habitats look nicely maintained.  

Speaking of well-maintained, their bathrooms are also pretty clean, which is a major plus for places like these.


If you are in the Tampa area, definitely hit up busch gardens.



Oh yea, and I didn't even mention the FREE BEER.  It's owned by busch, what else would you expect?  (go to the hospitality center)

My husband and I recently moved to the Tampa area and were not that excited to check out Busch Gardens since neither of us like to ride roller coasters, but we ended up loving it.  They have some great shows and nearly a third of the park is animal exhibits.  One of our favorite things to do at Busch Gardens is to get on the train that takes you throughout the park because you have a really great view of the animals in the safari area.  We were also pleasantly surprised by the price of food at Busch Gardens.  We ate lunch at an all you can eat pasta and pizza buffet and it was only $9 a person.  I would highly recommend visiting this park!

This review is based on my most recent experience at the park. When we got to the park, at the 2nd entrance (once you've paid and entered with your ticket) there is a sign that lists all the rollercoasters that are not not in service for the day. There was 4 listed. REALLY? Four... not counting Gazi. There are only 9 in total and technically 5 were not working?!?! 

Now, I 100% get there are probably major reasons for them to be down that include safety but that just seems insane to me that they would still charge full price for less than half of the rollercoasters which is the only reason we were there and why most people are. Yes, it may not bother some but that is just crazy. It is not a cheap place to go, especially per person. 

On a plus note, I did enjoy seeing all the lights and decorations that were out for Christmas. They were beautiful.

It was my first time going to Bush Gardens and I must say it was rally cool. From the roller-coasters to the attractions with the various "wildlife" every thing was great. The restaurants and food and drink stations were very good and might I say one of the best out of all of the parks I've ever been to: This includes Universal, Cedar Point, Six Flags etc. The drive from Jacksonville wasn't bad, we even made a weekend of it. We had a great time and we'll come back.

I have not been to Busch Gardens in years but I recently went and had a great time.  I think this place is special because it is not as packed as the Orlando theme parks but you can still have a lot of fun here.  They do a lot of things right here.  If you have a double seated stroller with more than 1 little kid, you can park closer to the front entrance.  They have stroller parking for family members, which is great.  If you do not park in the stroller area they have open air shuttles that will transport you to and from the parking lot.  

They have a very nice train that stops by the different 4 stops every 15 minutes.  If you stay on the train and do the full loop it takes about 45 to 1 hour. The train is awesome and the conductors do a great job in telling you about animal's and rides that you are passing by.  

The entrance plaza is nice and they offer all day dining so if you have a big family I would highly recommend this for the day that you are there.  You can also get a drink cup and have refills for .99 cents all year. 

They have plenty of coasters, water rides, and kids rides.  They have a very large kids play area where you can have a lot of fun.  If your kid has sensory issues they have a sensory park which is great for kids to play on.  

Through out the year they have a lot of other events going on from Halloween to Christmas!! Also they serve AB Beer and hard alcohol here at this park and you can enjoy a drink or two here as well.  

I highly recommend Busch Gardens!!!

If you don't get tickets for this attraction on a deal... You might want to reconsider going. They are currently suffering from a lack of employees....as are a lot of different establishments but some of the basics are just completely ignored. Animal attractions are great for young children. The thrill rides are spot on except for some of the ridiculous wait times. Of course you can pay an up charge to cut the line just like all other attractions. I always love a place the charges $30 just to park. As long as you don't set the bar too high, you will probably have an acceptable experience.

Don't know why this place has bad reviews. 

Everything was super fast for us... parking, tram, getting in etc. we showed up as the park opened because I read the bad reviews about waiting and we didn't need to. I was stressing for nothing.

If you don't want to wait in line, get the quick queues. You're in and out of a ride in a few minutes. If you don't, there were still people who walked on the ride and off the same exact time as us and we had the quick queues. 

If you go early, there's very few there! We went as soon as it opened up and everyone pretty much walked in the rides.. the later you go, the more people. 

The rides and stores open up throughout the day. If you make it a day trip, you'll see it come alive. 

There are a few attractions closed but I spent a full day there and was very satisfied. The food and drinks are expensive but there's also a McDonald's like across the street.. eat a quick meal before coming in. Then buy some snacks or a meal before you leave. 

The shows are awesome. The animals were cool to see and we enjoyed the rides!

Bring bug spray !

We traveled all the way from Texas with children and grandchildren to share wonderful memories with them. We grew up going to Busch gardens and so did our children. We were so disappointed! It was very expensive and not a single ride, the bird show didn't exist. The sky ride is gone even though online and on map it still exists. The sky ride was always the height of the day for all. So memorable!  The train was not running. A lot of the animal could be viewed. Paid for the food plan but were great full that we only bought 4. The food was awful, cold and nasty. We understand you could not control weather but it seemed to not make sense. The games and such could run but not the merry go round. Stood inline to see if we could get a refund because we were so disappointed, but after row hours left. Grand children were crying, disappointed and miserable!  This park in no uncertain terms has gone straight down hill. Read the bad reviews online but refused to believe but now we do and will spread word.  I bought seven tickets and my daughter bought three more. My son bought eight. What a waste of money!

We haven't been to Busch Gardens since a Hawl-O-Scream visit several years ago and were looking forward to attending the park during their annual Christmas Town Event (Nov 12 thru Jan 2). As I mentioned in my recent review of SeaWorld Orlando, on Black Friday 2021, we purchased our SeaWorld & Busch Gardens Tampa two park pass (for two) totaling $131.98, definitely a great deal!

SeaWorld is the parent company to Busch Gardens, so my 3-complaints from my SeaWorld review remain. (1) $30 parking is expensive, why not include this into the cost of the ticket? (2) Food and drink prices can be excessive, $10.99 for a beer, $4.70 for bottled water, $6 for a cookie WTF? (3) once again, no paper map. Guests must use a QR code to download a map or take a photo at the entrance, then continuously use your phone to navigate the park, this is beyond frustrating. Do yourself a favor and download the map from their website and print a copy or two to take with you.

Busch Gardens has a good variety of rides to choose from, and they are all a blast. Unfortunately, on this occasion, Skyride, Congo River Rapids, Cheetah Hunt, and Kumba were closed for repair. In addition, Falcon's Fury closed early, Montu closed down due to heavy rainfall (of course, as were we next in line), and the Iron Gwazi does not open until March 2022. As you can see, we didn't have the best run with roller coasters on this visit, but we still had fun on Tigris, Cobra's Curse, Sheikra, and the Stanley Falls Flume.

I enjoyed that Busch Gardens has a balanced selection of rides, animal encounters, and activities to choose from. There is a lot to do here for anyone, and you can easily spend an entire day exploring. We came for the whole Christmas experience, and it was beautiful, but some of the Festive Shows, such as the 'Christmas on Ice,' were not offered because we came on a Tuesday.

We were not too impressed with the food at Busch Gardens, but if you can wait until Christmas Town opens at dark (6 pm) you have an opportunity to try some of the better food the park has to offer by purchasing one of the two food and beverage sampler packages available. The 8-option is $44.99 & the 12-option is $64.99. Just know that if you order a beer, it is served in what looks to be about 8oz cup, yet the food looks better than many other options we viewed/sampled throughout the day.

My two cents on the Nairobi Train Station's Serengeti Express: Ride the train during the day when you can actually see the animals. We went at nighttime thinking we would see a magnificent light show, but all you see is pitch black darkness until you get back. The best part of the whole ride was when everyone started howling like wolves once inside the tunnel.

Something to note: Elmo's Christmas Wish is the same storyline as the one at SeaWorld and is performed outside in the Sesame Street section of the park. The show is adorable, and the kids seem to love it. You can sit very close to the stage, and the characters will do a photo op with kids/adults after the show. There is also a large playground/jungle gym nearby for kids to play while waiting for the show to start. Nancy and I got in there and had so much fun!

Once again, some minor issues here, just like SeaWorld, but nothing I would consider a deal-breaker, especially since we got such a fantastic deal on our tickets. If you have never been to Busch Gardens or if you are looking for something fun to do in Tampa, I highly recommend a visit here; however, look around for deals online through Groupon or AAA.com.

The park is incredible; beautiful landscaping, incredible sights, and an awesome collection of rides and shows. 

I went on a busy Wednesday in the middle of December, and the park was decently busy. However, the first issue with this place isn't even in the park itself, but rather the parking lot. I've visited some prestigious parks, such as Six Flags Great America, Cedar Point, and the parks of Disney World. Something all of these parks have in common is that they have mastered getting people into and out of the parking lot. Busch Gardens Tampa Bay, sadly, has a terrible setup, and the line to get into the park moves atrociously slow, and, if the line gets long enough, it can slow down traffic. This was my first of many major complaints.

We walked into the park and visited Cheetah Hunt, an awesome launched roller coaster with incredible sights. The line got pretty long, but it was nothing o complain about. We then stopped by an eatery across the path called Oasis Pizza. The pizza was alright, but what wasn't was the hour wait to even order food. Food service is NOT this park's strength. While the employees are awesome, their speed is not. 

We then took the train to Stanleyville, rode some attractions there and at the Congo area, and then visited Pantopia. The first thing we did here was the acclaimed Falcon's Fury, which was an awesome ride. However, this is where my biggest complaint comes in.

Only two members of my group wished to ride. As we were approaching the front of the line, a ride operator asked for a group of two. We immediately began walking to the front. A man in front of us then raised his hand and started to get his daughter from outside to join him. The other member of my group said that this was not fair, and that she had never entered the line, which everyone in front of us agreed with. The man then began to shove them, in front of small children, his daughter, and his wife, and scream that he had every right to bring her on the ride. The ride operator then "explained" that if it was just one person, he couldn't do anything. This was then followed by many people in line protesting by asking if they could bring just one person in line. I do not wish to express anger to the ride operator, nor the man's daughter. However, I am very disturbed that the man thought that he could get away with it and at whoever in charge decided this was okay. 

We then continued to ride attractions until we visited Cobra's Curse. This is a fun attraction that had a decent looking queue line. However, the way the skip-the-line queue was being operated led to the stand-by line not moving for 20 minutes at one time.

I do not seek a refund or anything of the sort.

I only seek for a reform of policies and rules in order for future guests to enjoy their time.

I hoped that I'd be impressed and would want to visit again, but after this experience, I have no desire to return any time in the near future.

This was my first time coming here. I've been to several amusement parks but this one was so drab and outdated. The pathways were grimy and landscape was over growing. I waited in line for their wild mouse "Sand Serpent" roller coaster for 1 hour. Kids were seen cutting through lines, hanging from handrails, falling into others in line, etc and there was no one around to correct this. For twice the price of a reputable amusement park (I.e Cedar Point), I feel awfully jipped. Their main ride, Cheetah Hunt was also down when I was here.

I don't even know what to say.
My family purchased a 3-park pass and decided to check out Busch Gardens on the 2nd day. This is the park that my husband has been waiting to go to forever... and I was so happy to be able to take him.

So getting there wasn't bad and the parking wasn't the greatest - since we had to park on the other side of the park where you have to take a tram to get to the entrance of the park - but we made the best of it.

We get thru security and showing our tickets to get in and we thought that the adventure was going to begin... like at Sea World... but low-and-behold, we were so surprised to find that you have to walk so much before you even see anything! What?!? 

We see a ride coming up and notice that it's not running... come to find out that it's not even finished yet! Ugh! 

More walking it is...

So we come upon some areas that have some beautiful flowers and topiary... loved it. But no more... we had to walk even more to find an area with the kangaroo and further down, some birds. 

Where the heck are the rides in this joint?!?! 
Found Sesame Street area found... our daughter got in one ride there and we walked out. 

More walking and we finally find some rides but at this point - almost an hour in and we hadn't found a concession stand to get anything to drink and mind you, it's like 90° while walking! There were about 5/6 concession stands and restaurants that we passed that were just closed.

So we had to stop to get a drink at the first concession stand we found that when we got in line, only one of the registers were being used and the line was super long!
We finally got our drinks and snacks, ate them and decided to jump into the line of the first water ride we see. Score!

No score...
After waiting over an hour and a half, the employees come over the PA system to tell us that the ride was shutting down because it was broken but we were more than welcome to stand in line until it was fixed! What?!?! Why would I continue staying in line for a ride that was completely shut down?!

So we get out of line and were just disappointed with the whole experience. There were barely employees around to help with answering questions, which was very strange to see.

The layout of the park was so strange... I don't know how to explain it but it wasn't easy to read the maps that they have in order to get around.

So we decided to leave the park - and thank goodness we did when we did because a storm came ripping thru the park - and we got to the area where you get on the tram and come to find out that the park had stopped the running of the tram because of the storm that was coming. And they weren't going to start them up again for 45 minutes! What?!?! You bring your patrons from across another parking area that isn't close by on your tram and now we have to walk to the other side - thru a long tunnel and cars whizzing by and falling branches from palm trees, no less! Busch Gardens... do you not care about the safety of your patrons!!!???

So... that's the end of our adventure at Busch Gardens. I felt that it was a waste of time and money... even though the hubby says he'll give it another try one day - maybe never for me.

I liked Busch Gardens when visited. It offers a variety of attractions, animal attractions, and good food. It was bust, but still a fun visit. We took the train ride across the Serengeti and enjoyed the scenery. If you are with a season pass holder then you can get tickets for 50% off. It was definitely worth the $50 we paid with friends. We tried the all you can eat option and enjoyed grabbing water as we traveled the roller coasters. The food options are plenty and they were good. I enjoyed the ribs and chicken salad options. 

Busch Gardens is definitely an all day adventure.
Packed and minimal food options with hour long lines! Fast pass expensive but worth it. Otherwise you'd spend two hours waiting for a roller coaster.

I love Busch Gardens. I really enjoyed my time here with my kids, since it was off season the waits were not long at all and their military deal is just amazing. So I got their military deal, then the meal deal, but not the fast pass because if I was not military the ticket $90, meal $34 and weekend fast pass $65 would of been over 200 a person and this isn't universal or Disney you know. Don't get me wrong I do really like this place, that's just really really expensive. 

The rides were pretty fun. I've been to like 20 amusement parks and their rides are in top 6. The staff was friendly and helpful and worked with me well when my kid didn't want to ride the coaster and let me hang out while my other kid rode. 

They could really improve by adding more things in their line than just the line game. The newer rides have started to take advantage of this, but the older rides is straight line game and the log drop is so narrow lines that I had to stand and walk sideways the whole time. 

Gotta appreciate the charging stations, cell phone charging cells and free WiFi. That's always a bonus. 

I would always come back here if in the area.

-  my husband took a job writing an article about all the Busch garden brand parks in Florida so we went to the water park., Discovery Cove, Busch Gardens and much more.  We. We're lucky as we were given free passes for Skip the lines and we were thankful!  If you are a lover of coasters like we are-- well we recommend this pass!   Skipping lines made for an amazing experience.  

We never have enough time to see everything and already have plans to bring our young child back as it's a short ish drive for us...... my favorite of the parks was Discovery Cove, the. Busch Gardens, Seaworld then the water park.... 
Love travel!

I am sad to say that there probably will not be a Busch Gardens in the near future.  Took the kids. Everything was shut down. It genuinely looked abandoned. Almost no concessions open (the ones that were open were gross and still absurdly priced). Skeleton staff.  Many rides shutdown. Some of the big coasters were open but only large children and adults can ride them.  They apparently aren't even printing maps of the park anymore. Honestly, it borders on fraud to allow people to buy tickets without telling them they are simply buying an expensive ticket for an open-air walk.  It's just a cruddy partial zoo now.

I love this amusement park. I loved it as a kid, and I love bringing my baby girl now. Great mix of attractions for the young and young at heart - animals in the safari including white tigers, orangutans, and elephants, lovely gardens, a Sesame Street section with all the characters, good shows, wide selection of food and drinks (including beer and wine), and my personal favorite, super fun coasters. The Cheetah Hunt is my favorite, and all six are awesome. Come on an off day to avoid the lines. We came on Thanksgiving and didn't have to wait in line for anything.

So this was a decent experience. My first comment would be if you do not like roller coasters or thrill parks, then you probably won't get the most out of this park. If you love animals you will get a lot out of it. If you are expecting good food, there is only really one place I would recommend.  There is a barbecue smokehouse at the back of the park that is fantastic, but all the other food and snacks that we had with their unlimited dining program was frankly horrific. I had one of the worst pulled pork sandwiches of my life that tasted like salty rubber and even the funnel cake that I had tasted like Burnt dough and old cooking oil. They kept advertising that there would be Rudolph the red nose reindeer and related character meet and greets, which never happened and was very disappointing to me. Their Christmas village was basically pretty lights, some decent singers/performers, and the rest was just a glorified flea market/shopping mall. It was a pretty basic experience but I enjoyed The time with my family there which I guess is what really matters :-)

If I could give this park zero stars I would. We waited longer on line to get food (hour and a half) just to get half cooked yellow chicken. I am expecting to get salmonella poisoning at this point. Only a quarter of the food places are even open, what is the point? Lines are atrocious, workers are rude, but at least the sodas are okay-for 6 dollars. DO NOT WASTE YOUR MONEY OR TIME- GO TO DISNEY, WALT IS WAITING!

I love Busch Gardens!! I would compare it to Disney world in that it is maintained super well with great cleanliness and very friendly and happy workers all over the park! The rides are more intense than Disney world and in my opinion, more fun. There is so much to do; Busch gardens is also a safari and it has animal exhibits all around the park that even go along with the rides! For example, next to the ride "cheetah hunt" is a real cheetah enclosure! They even have a kids camp so kids can stay in Busch gardens after hours and sleep there for a night. I  wouldn't recommend going with someone who does not love roller coasters because many of them are thrill rides. Even so, they all ride smoothly and feel safe while you're on them. 
My only complaint would be that while I was there, some of the rides had to be stopped for a couple hours and made the waits very very long.

Buying tickets in the park was absolutely horrible Keisha was not nice wouldn't answer our questions just uhh huh or no no and said we had to have I'd to get in instead of just asking for our licenses to put our info on the passes very rude buy your tix online

Fun family trip (hadn't travelled since 2018 for a family trip) and my older teens loved the rides, my husband and I loved the animal areas and gorgeous landscaped areas and shaded walkways with so much to see! Once 4 pm hit a tremendous influx of people seemed to be entering, guessing for the Christmas Town foods for purchase and the related festivities? 
       Plenty to stay busy with, lots of walking (wear your best comfy walking shoes)! Food prices are up everywhere and amusement park food and beverage prices are always high. We opted for the all day dining wristbands which was $44 per person, but once we saw water priced at about $4/bottle and all food prices hefty we knew the bands were the way to go since staying til close. There are certain eateries the meal bands work at so investigate that via the Busch Gardens app. 
      We'd all 4 say only eat at the Smokehouse place if getting pulled pork or the chicken. The ribs and the brisket were so extremely fatty it was a bust! They also threw all the meats from a sampler platter atop the waffle fries that come with the sampler therefore creating soggy, cold, bbq sauced waffle fries.  We found the large indoor Dragon Fire Grill & pub for dinner and it offers several fast counter service places to choose from plus beverage stations. This worked well and was conveniently located and had tons of seating.
     Ride lines were reasonable from opening time til about 3 or 4 pm when a huge influx of people seemed to enter the park leading to super crowded walkways, seating areas outdoors, and much longer lines for many coasters. A special Christmas Town list of festivities and foods began at 4 we think. The festive foods are exorbitantly priced and appeared to be mere samples. The park sells 12 samples of Christmas Town "specialties" at a separate price if $40 something per person. We hardly saw anyone partaking in this but it's there.

What I love about Busch Gardens is that part of it is a theme park complete with roller coaster rides and the other half is some kind of zoo/animal conservatory. It was huge, it was eye-catching, it was exciting, it was fun! It didn't even feel like a theme park, but more like a fun festival of some sort. (And it was probably expensive, but my parents handled that.)

Busch Gardens has a ton of awesome rides, but for some reason, I will never forget the Scorpion roller coaster. It's just a small red roller coaster, but the cool thing about it is the one loop that goes upside down. Here's the kicker: you're not harnessed in with anything extra beyond the seatbelt and lap bar. I was a bit freaked out but it turned out to be pretty fun.

I really hope I go back again at some point in the near future. If I ever make another vacation trip to Florida, this will be on my list.

[My previous review was removed, so I'm posting this again.]

I live in FL and now and then i visit the park with my friends from out of state when they come to FL to visit, employee and staff there are lacking everything time i visit this play, i understand that the are under staff but the actual staff work DONT care about performing and making guess a great experience at the park I always promise my self not coming back here but my friends and family visit FL hoping to enjoy this place

Love Busch Gardens, but 6 employees walked by on Cheetah Hunt while this is how the people in the line were waiting. Other rides, the staff was enforcing guest mask rule and social distancing. I could have taken more pictures, but figured this gets the point across.
